"summary": {"eng": "World champion Daniel Wiffen says he had his eyes on an Olympic record as he qualified for the men's 800m freestyle finals in first place.\n\nThe Team Ireland swimmer, who won world 800m and 1500m freestyle gold in February, stated before the Games that he would not be leaving Paris without a medal.\n\nHe put down an ominous marker in the 800m heats on Monday morning as he set the fastest time, and he will go into the final on Tuesday night as favourite.\n\n\"I was happy with my time, but I had my eyes "}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, {"uri": "8248771907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "11:15:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T11:15:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T11:14:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/sport/13501598/swimming-daniel-wiffen-olympics-800m-final/", "title": "Wiffen says 'everything is aligning' for Olympic medal after making 800m final", "body": "DANIEL WIFFEN reckons the stars are aligning for him to medal at these Games.\n\nWiffen won the fastest 800m freestyle heat in a time of 7:41.53, his third quickest time of his career.\n\nAnd the 23-year-old is confident of a podium finish in Tuesday evening's final.\n\nWiffen said: \"Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, what is it 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine, especially.\"\n\nOne of the main medal contenders, Sam Short, failed to reach the final. The Australian who took silver at last year's World Championships in this distance finished third in the same heat as Wiffen.\n\nHe and compatriot Elijah Winnington - who took silver in the 400m on Saturday - went out quickly but Wiffen had overhauled Short by the halfway mark and Winnington shortly afterwards and never relinquished the lead.\n\nBut he believes there is more to come.\n\nHe said: \"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100 percent. It's tough to say, but we'll go with it being 95 percent.\n\n\"You didn't see my legs come in at the end so that's where it is, but I was holding a good pace.\n\n\"You see the Australians go out fast, I'm a middle swimmer, like to hold a fast pace no one else can hold.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100 percent effort trying to make the final. I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final.\n\n\"I've never been in this shape before in my life.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, I was just off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that so that would have been pretty cool to get but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"I'm happy with the morning swim and a fast time as well, I'm pretty happy. There's no significance to being the fastest qualifier, just I've got a great lane to look around.\"\n\nWiffen said that, although he cannot normally hear the crowd, it was different in La D\u00e9fense Arena where he was cheered on by considerable Irish support.\n\nAnd he admitted there were nerves before the got in the water.\n\nHe said: \"I was more nervous than I was before the World Championships, but that's just the Olympics, a different kind of level. But I dealt with it quite well. A bit nervous around the first 100m, but then I settled in.\n\n\"It's completely different, in Tokyo I was just there really qualified, and just tried to keep progressing.\n\n\"The past three years have been a blast for me, improving by 15 seconds in the 1500m every time I swam in the water, PBing in every international.\n\nAnd Wiffen intends to spend the evening swotting up on his opponents.\n\nHe said: \"I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them, I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.\n\n\"I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\"\n\nIt was a successful morning in the pool with Ellen Walshe reaching tonight's 400m individual medley after finishing fourth in her heat.\n\nAnd Danielle Hill emerged from her 100m backstroke heat to reach the semi-finals which will also take place this evening when Mona McSharry will also compete in the 100m breaststroke final.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Sun"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8249503335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "20:08:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T20:08:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T20:07:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/what-time-daniel-wiffens-olympic-33350817", "title": "What time is Daniel Wiffen's Olympic 800m Freestyle final on?", "body": "Daniel Wiffen is right where he wants to be as Ireland's first male Olympic finalist on Tuesday night.\n\nWiffen, 23, will dive from the block to start the 800m final in lane four knowing he is the fastest qualifier from the four heats that took place on Monday.\n\nHe knows that the time he finished in - his third fastest ever - may not be good enough to win gold but he also knows that, like some of his biggest rivals, he did not go flat out in his heat.\n\nREAD MORE: Daniel Wiffen makes Armagh All-Ireland reference after storming into Olympic final\n\nREAD MORE: Ellen Walshe celebrates with roomie Mona McSharry as they both make swim final\n\nHe puts his percentage of effort at 95 and hopes that committing 100% to the final will get him an Olympic and World record as he attempts to win a sixth championship final in a row.\n\n\"I've never been in this shape before in my life,\" he said on Monday. \"I was happy with my time, but I had my eyes on the Olympic record.\"\n\nHis time of 7:41.53 was close to the Olympic record mark of 7:41.28 that belongs to Ukraine's Mykhailo Romanchuk. That was set in Tokyo, where the event returned to the Olympics for the first time since 1904.\n\nBut as a double World champion this year - in the 800m and also the 1500m, which he will get to later this week - Wiffen has a big target on his back.\n\nBobby Finke, the reigning Olympic champion, leads the posse who want to take down a swimmer who has improved beyond recognition from the one that finished 14th in Tokyo in the 800, breaking the national record in the process. He has been lowering it ever since.\n\n\"The past three years have been a blast for me,\" said Wiffen. \"I've been dropping 16 seconds every time I swam in the water in the 1500, and I've been PBing at every single international.\n\n\"I wasn't going in there with 100% effort trying to make the final - I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final.\n\n\"I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there.\"\n\nOne of his biggest dangers, the Australian Sam Short, was overtaken and left well behind by Wiffen in the heat. Short didn't make the final and afterwards revealed that a virus had hampered his chances.\n\nWiffen also reeled in another Aussie, the 400m silver medallist Elijah Whittington, who pushed himself into the early lead. The Armagh man beat Whittington to gold in the Worlds six months ago.\n\nSo he is confident but also a little wary of the challenge that could come from not just Finke and from the likes of second fastest qualifier Ahmed Jaouadi of Tunisia, but from some lesser known names.\n\nWiffen planned to spend last night doing his homework on all of his final opponents. \"I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them, I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes,\" he noted.\n\n\"I was more nervous than I was before the World Championships, but that's just the Olympics, a different kind of level. But I dealt with it quite well. A bit nervous around the first 100m, but then I settled in.\"\n\nWiffen hails from Magheralin, on the border of Armagh and Down - and while both counties may claim him he is happy to add Armagh's All-Ireland final triumph on Sunday as more fuel for his bid for two or even three Olympic medals in the days to come.\n\n\"Yeah, Armagh won,\" he smiled. \"My birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day...what is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"\n\nAnd, on the basis of the last few days, the atmosphere tonight in the La Defense Arena could be very special.\n\n\"I never really hear the crowd when I'm swimming, that one I could hear, 100%,\" Wiffen smiled. \"There was a lot of Irish support, I saw a lot of tricolours in the stands so I'm pretty happy.\"\n\nWiffen's medal bid will start at 8.02pm on Tuesday night in the La Defense Arena.\n\nGet the latest sports headlines straight to your inbox by signing up for free email alerts.", "source": {"uri": "irishmirror.ie", "dataType": {"uri": "8248791519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "11:27:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T11:27:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T11:25:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/daniel-wiffen-makes-armagh-ireland-33348554", "title": "Daniel Wiffen makes Armagh All-Ireland reference after making Olympic final", "body": "Ireland's swimming gold medal favourite Daniel Wiffen feels the stars are aligning after he qualified for tomorrow night's Olympic 800m Freestyle final.\n\nWiffen hails from Magheralin, which is on the border of Armagh and Down, and while both counties may claim him he is happy to add Armagh's All-Ireland final triumph on Sunday as more fuel for his bid for two or even three Olympic medals in the days to come.\n\n\"Yeah, Armagh won,\" he smiled. \"My birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day...what is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"\n\nREAD MORE:Ellen Walshe celebrates with roomie Mona McSharry as they both make swim final\n\nREAD MORE:What Irish athletes are in Olympics action on Monday? Full list for day 3 in Paris and day 2 results\n\nIt does, certainly on the basis of the first swim for the 23-year-old at the re-customed La Defense Arena this morning. Wiffen stormed to victory in the fourth of the four heats that doubled up as semi-finals, reeling in and passing two of his main medal rivals Sam Short and Elijah Whittington of Australia.\n\nWhittington, already a silver medal winner at these Games in the 400m Freestyle, went out strong and led for half of the race but Wiffen slowly took control and won in a time of 7:41.53, his third fastest ever.\n\nAfterwards he insisted that he was running at around 95% of his full capacity, but that there was much more to come. \"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100%.,\" said the Loughborough student.\n\n\"You didn't see my legs come in at the end, so that's where it is, but holding a good pace, happy with the morning swim and a fast time as well, I'm pretty happy.\n\n\"I was more nervous than I was before the World Championships, but that's just the Olympics, a different kind of level. But I dealt with it quite well. A bit nervous around the first 100m, but then I settled in.\n\n\"You see the Australians go out fast, I'm a middle swimmer, like to hold a fast pace no one else can hold. I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them, I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, I was only 0.4 off an Olympic record (it was actually 0.25 off it) and no Irishman or woman has ever done that, so that would have been pretty cool to get. But we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100% effort trying to make the final - I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\n\n\"I've never been in this shape before in my life.\"\n\nShort finished third behind Wiffen and Whittington and didn't make the final. Bobby Finke, the reigning champion, may be his biggest rival but there are newer names in the final, too, that the Irish hopeful says he will study as he recovers and gears up for tomorrow.\n\nAt the same time, only Finke and Tunisian teenager Ahmed Jaouadi - who finished second fastest of the qualifiers behind Wiffen this morning - weren't in the World Championship final won by Wiffen in February.\n\nAsked if he would be happy with winning a silver or bronze medal from this position of strength, Wiffen replied: \"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine (the 10,000m open water race), {"uri": "8248863756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "12:12:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T12:12:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T12:12:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://sports.ndtv.com/olympics-2024/irelands-daniel-wiffen-has-eyes-on-historic-swimming-gold-6215304", "title": "Ireland's Daniel Wiffen Has Eyes On Historic Swimming Gold  | Olympics News", "body": "Ireland's Daniel Wiffen posted the fastest time in the heats for the 800m freestyle on Monday, and the world champion now has his sights set on making history in Tuesday's final. Wiffen could become the first Irishman, and just the second Irish athlete ever, to claim Olympic swimming gold -- and his hopes were boosted with challenger Sam Short of Australia, considered the favourite by some analysts, failing to qualify. The 23-year-old Wiffen topped qualifying in 7:41.53, ahead of Tunisia's Ahmed Jaouadi.\n\nBut he will also need to hold off defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke of the United States, in-form Australian Elijah Winnington and experienced Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri, Tokyo silver medallist, in an open field.\n\n\"Any lane has a chance, I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, seeing how everybody swims it, and I'll be making sure that I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night,\" Wiffen told reporters.\n\nMichelle Smith's three golds and a bronze from the Atlanta Games in 1996 remains Ireland's only Olympic medals in swimming.\n\nBut Wiffen, was born in Yorkshire, England, before moving to County Down in Northern Ireland at the age of two, says he isn't fixated on the gold.\n\n\"Any medal's good, it's my first race here, and it's my first time actually being in contention for an Olympic medal, so I'll take any medal, whatever colour,\" he said.\n\nWiffen is in his second Olympics, having entered the 800 and 1500 metre races in Tokyo, but after his rapid rise in the sport he says there is little comparison.\n\n\"It is completely different. In Tokyo, I was just really qualifying and trying to keep progressing. The past three years have been a blast for me -- I've been dropping 16 seconds every time I've swam in the water in the 1500, and I've been PB-ing every single international, I just want to keep that streak up here,\" he said.\n\nThe heats, held in the morning, have drawn impressive crowds and Wiffen says the noise they generate is felt by the swimmers.\n\n\"I very rarely hear the crowd when I'm swimming but this one I can hear 100 percent. There's a lot of Irish support, I saw a lot of tricolours in the stands, so pretty happy,\" he said.\n\nHe is making the most of these Games -- as well as the two races at the La Defense Arena, he also plans to race in the 10km open water race in the River Seine.\n\nIt is a heavy workload, but Wiffen says he is the fittest he has ever been, describing himself as \"100 percent.\"", "source": {"uri": "8251363214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:19:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:19:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:19:26Z", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daniel Wiffen wins 800m freestyle Olympic gold in a dramatic climax", "body": "He finished 0.56 seconds quicker than the USA's Bobby Finke to edge gold\n\nDaniel Wiffen has become the first Northern Irish athlete to win an Olympic gold in 36 years, after a heroic comeback in the men's 800m freestyle final.\n\nTwenty-three-year-old Wiffen set a new Olympic record in the process, with a blistering time of 7:38.19.\n\nWiffen was 0.56 seconds quicker than second-place USA swimmer, Bob Finke, securing gold in a dramatic fashion with an extraordinary burst of pace in the final 50 metres to come from behind.\n\nSupporters for the Northern Irishman erupted in Paris' La Defense Arena, with the gold being the first Ireland has tallied this Games, to add to a solitary bronze.\n\n'I was writing \"I'm going into the history books\", and that's exactly what I've done,' he told BBC Sport.\n\nDaniel Wiffen became the first Northern Irish gold medallist in 36 years\n\nWiffen won Olympic gold in the men's 800m freestyle at the La Defense Arena, on Tuesday\n\n'It was definitely the way I wanted to execute it, it wasn't the time that I wanted, but Olympic finals aren't about getting times, it's about getting your hand on the wall first.'\n\nBefore the finals, Wiffen had already set the fastest time in the heats on Monday, telling press he was in it to win it.\n\nThe crowd in La Defense were heavily backing countryman David Aubrey, but Wiffen received the next loudest cheer.\n\nWiffen started well, taking up third, before edging into the lead halfway through the race.\n\nBut he soon came under attack from Finke and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri, which set up the thrilling climax to the race that stunned the arena.\n\nWiffen slipped to second 50 metres remaining, and had looked like he was going to miss out on gold.\n\nBut with an incredible burst of pace, he passed Finke in the race's finale to touch the timing beam first.\n\nAfter being presented his gold, Wiffen broke into an emotional celebration with his family and friends, including his twin brother, Nathan, who's shared every step of his professional journey with him.\n\nWiffen's gold makes him the first athlete from Northern Ireland to win the medal since Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood in 1988 - although the pair were representing Great Britain in the men's hockey.\n\nWiffen set a new Olympic record in the process with a blistering swim of 7:38:19 in the 800m\n\nThe 23-year-old from County Down was representing Team ireland the Paris 2024 Olympics\n\nYour browser does not support iframes.\n\nIt's also the first individual gold for a Northern Irish athlete since Lady Mary Peters won the pentathlon at the 1972 Games, in Munich.\n\nHis record-breaking swim makes him the the first Olympian from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold for Ireland, and the first Olympian from Team Ireland to win a gold medal in swimming since 1996.\n\nWiffen has now added Olympic gold to his 800m and 1500m accolades at the World Championships in Doha this year.\n\nHe was born England and moved to Northern Ireland at the age of two. Possessing both Irish and British nationality, he represents Ireland at the World, and European levels, and Northern Ireland at the Commonwealth Games.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"\n\nRead next: World champion swimmer Daniel Wiffen confident of gold medal glory at Paris Olympics\n\nRead next: Daniel Wiffen prepares to go for gold again after making history in Doha\n\nWiffen certainly made waves at La Defense Arena earlier today, clinching first place in his heat, which simultaneously served as a semi-final, outpacing major rivals including Aussie duo Sam Short and Elijah Whittington.\n\nWhittington, who has already bagged a silver at these Games in the 400m Freestyle, took the early lead but was overtaken by Wiffen who triumphed with a time of 7:41.53, clocking in his third-fastest performance ever.\n\nSpeaking post-race, the Loughborough University student shared that while the semi-final didn't push him to his limits, there's plenty more in the tank. \"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100%.,\" the young star remarked.\n\n\"You didn't see my legs come in at the end, so that's where it is, but holding a good pace, happy with the morning swim and a fast time as well, I'm pretty happy. I was more nervous than I was before the World Championships, but that's just the Olympics, a different kind of level. But I dealt with it quite well. A bit nervous around the first 100m, but then I settled in.\n\n\"You see the Australians go out fast, I'm a middle swimmer, like to hold a fast pace no one else can hold. I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them, I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, I was only 0.4 off an Olympic record (it was actually 0.25 off it) and no Irishman or woman has ever done that, so that would have been pretty cool to get. But we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100% effort trying to make the final - I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night. I've never been in this shape before in my life.\"\n\nWhen asked if he would be content with a silver or bronze medal from his current position, Wiffen responded: \"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Wiffen has won Ireland's first gold medal of the Games and 12th gold medal in 100 years of competing as an independent nation.\n\nWiffen, the fastest qualifier, was competing from lane four and took the lead at the halfway mark.\n\nThe race turned thrilling from 600m onwards, with a fierce contest between Wiffen, Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri, and American Bobby Finke, the 2021 Olympic champion in this discipline.\n\nWiffen was trailing Paltrinieri going into the final 100m, but dug deep and raced home, recording an Olympic record in the process.\n\nIn the end, Finke claimed silver, finishing 0.56 seconds behind Wiffen, while Paltrinieri took bronze, 1.19 seconds off the pace.\n\nWiffen, the 23-year-old Armagh native, had already made headlines earlier this year by winning both the 800m and 1500m golds at the World Championships in Doha, becoming Ireland's first-ever swimming world champion with his 800m victory.\n\nWith his 800m win in Paris, Wiffen continues to build on his stellar year. {"uri": "8251873686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:30:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:30:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:30:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/bbc-called-out-over-reaction-33363136", "title": "BBC called out over reaction to Daniel Wiffen winning Olympic gold medal", "body": "Daniel Wiffen made history on Tuesday night as he claimed Ireland's first Olympic gold medal of the Paris Games with a stunning victory in the men's 800 metres freestyle final.\n\nThe Magheralin native became Ireland's first male medallist in the pool and third overall after Michelle Smith and Mona McSharry, who won bronze in the women's 100m breaststroke some 24 hours earlier.\n\nAlthough Wiffen was trailing Italy's Gregorio Paltrineri with 50m left, he overhauled the Italian then held off a late surge from Bobby Finke of the United States to take top spot by 0.56 seconds.\n\nREAD MORE:Daniel Wiffen eyeing more glory after overcoming mistakes to win Olympic gold\n\nREAD MORE:Daniel Wiffen credits twin brother for Olympic triumph as tears come for Ireland's swimming sensation\n\nWhile Finke took silver and Paltrineri bronze, Wiffen, who won the world title at the distance in February, was celebrating an Olympic record-winning time of seven minutes and 38.19 seconds.\n\nTokyo 2020 marked the return of the men's event for the first time since 1904 and Wiffen missed out on the final but he laid down a marker in Paris with the fastest qualifying time in Monday's heats.\n\nHe first hit the front just before the halfway stage and while he ceded control to Paltrineri, the 23-year-old was just 0.1 secs adrift and he had plenty left in the tank to mount a final charge.\n\nSo, too, did Finke but Wiffen's management of the race was paced perfectly and he had just enough to hold off the American.\n\nA tweet from BBC's Sport account after the race read: \"History in Paris! Daniel Wiffen becomes the first athlete from Northern Ireland to win an Olympic gold medal since 1988.\"\n\nThat led to a number of people pointing out that Wiffen, who was draped in an Irish tricolour after the race, had won the medal for Ireland.\n\nOne person said: \"Look what it says on his shirt.\"\n\nAnother commented: \"He's Irish and representing Ireland.\"\n\nSomeone else posted: \"That top doesn't say Northern Ireland??\"\n\n\"It clearly says Ireland on his shirt and he's even pointing to it,\" read another comment.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly were among the many people to congratulate Wiffen.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement.\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nWiffen said afterwards said: \"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down - I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\"\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"\n\nGet the latest sports headlines straight to your inbox by signing up for free email alerts.", {"uri": "8251257256", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:51:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:51:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:50:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/30/irelands-daniel-wiffen-wins-olympic-gold-medal-after-stunning-800m-swim-in-paris/", "title": "Ireland's Daniel Wiffen wins Olympic gold medal after stunning 800m swim in Paris", "body": "Armagh swimmer broke the Olympic record and powered home over the closing 100 metres\n\nAfter one massively heroic effort and 16 lengths of glory Daniel Wiffen is the Olympic champion, producing an utterly astonishing display of 800 metres freestyle swimming to carve his name among the greats of swimming history.\n\nOn another wild and rollicking night of swimming inside the Paris La D\u00e9fense Arena, the 23-year-old from Armagh continued his uncanny and confident ability to repeatedly go where no Irish male swimmer had ever gone before - this time on to the top of the Olympic medal podium.\n\nSome Olympic swimming events are decided on a fingertip, and this one wasn't far off, as Wiffen boldly chased down a .78 of second deficit on Gregorio Paltrinieri from Italy inside the last 100m, the 2016 Olympic champion in the 1,500m, who won silver in the 800m in Tokyo.\n\nRefusing to settle for anything other than gold, Wiffen touched home in 7:38.19, smashing the Olympic record of 7:41.28 set by Mykhailo Romanchuk when qualifying for the final in Tokyo.\n\nDefending champion Bobby Finke from the USA was also closing fast, nailing second in 7:38.75, with Paltrinieri holding on for third in 7:39.38.\n\nIn an event dubbed by many as the swimming torture chamber, given the necessary combination of speed and endurance, Wiffen left behind nothing of his effort, briefly moving in front just after halfway, before Paltrinieri powered his way to the fore from just after the 200m mark. Ahmed Jaouadi, the 19-year-old from Tunisia, was fourth in 7:42.83.\n\nFew of us can ever begin to imagine being stuck in this moment. Olympic champion, Olympic gold medal winner, Wiffen now blissfully immortalised in his own event and given that rare and lasting place in the reels of Irish sporting history too.\n\nIn the now century of our Olympic participation, only nine Irish people, six men and three woman, had ever experienced becoming an Olympic champion, Olympic gold medal winner, since the country was first allowed to compete for itself as the Free State in time for the 1924 Olympics in Paris.\n\nWiffen now becomes number 10, also improving his own Irish and European record of 7:39.19, set last summer when finish fourth at the 2023 World Championships.\n\nElijah Winnington from Australia was the early leader at the 100m mark, Jaouadi in second, Wiffen just over a metre down in third, as that leading trio set off at just inside world record pace.\n\nThose fortunate enough to even stand on the Olympic medal podium will also tell you it's a place that must be truly believed in for it ever to be seen, and rarely had any Irish athlete believed he'd soon be standing there more than Wiffen. His four years at Loughborough University in England has also tempered that belief.\n\nWiffen's confidence, however, was not unfounded, his heat time of 7:41.53 inside the Paris La D\u00e9fense Arena on Monday morning was the fastest of the eight finalists, giving him the prime lane four for this medal showdown.\n\nPaltrinieri started in lane three, Jaouadi in five, and Finke in lane two, so Wiffen also had them within view.\n\nWiffen's walkout into the arena was again as cool as he likes it, mimicking it seemed the carving of his own name into history (fingers perhaps crossed just in case). Only Wiffen's time is now Olympic medal-winning gold time\n\nFinke, the 24-year-old from Florida, was back in Paris to defend both the 800 and 1,500m titles he won in Tokyo.\n\nIn getting this far, Wiffen already become the first Irish male swimmer to make an Olympic final, as bold and impressive as he would have liked.\n\nEver since the first session on Saturday, the Paris La D\u00e9fense Arena has been transforming itself into one of the loudest swimming dance halls in Olympic history, and Tuesday night's 19,000-sell-out was no exception.\n\nHis parents Jonathan and Rachal Wiffen watching from the stands, along with twin brother Nathan - as indeed were the parents of Finke, Joe and Jeanne.\n\nAfter turning 23 on Bastille Day, it continues Wiffen's magnificence trajectory of improvement since qualifying for the Tokyo Olympics as a 19-year-old, finishing some distance outside the finals there despite setting then Irish records of 7:51.65 for the 800m (finishing 14th) and 15:07.69 for the 1500m (finishing 20th).\n\nAlso in the now century of Ireland's participation in the Olympics going back to Paris in 1924, only two Irish swimmers had also previously won a medal, Michelle Smith de Bruin becoming the first when winning four in 1996, before McSharry won the race to become just the second on Monday night, with her magnificent bronze in the 100m breaststroke.\n\nWiffen had also won his last five consecutive championship finals, the 800m-1,500m double at the World championships in February, where he was also named best male swimmer, two months after winning the 400m-800-1,500m treble at the European short-course championships, where he also broke the world record.\n\nIn Tokyo, Finke was only fourth at the last turn, but came through to win in 7:41.87. He came close here too, just not close enough to claw back Wiffen.\n\nWiffen still has two more events to come, the 1,500m by his own admission possibly his best distance, before he takes on the 10km marathon swim next Friday week.\n\nAnd move over Tarzan.\n\nA century after Johnny Weissmuller won three gold medals in the pool at the 1924 Olympics also here in Paris, announcing himself as one of the best freestyle swimmers in the world, Wiffen has continued his meteoric trajectory in the sport, with no fear or need to look back now.", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8250454058", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "10:40:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T10:40:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T10:40:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/sport/other-sport/what-time-daniel-wiffen-swimming-29639802", "title": "Daniel Wiffen's 800m final start time and how to watch", "body": "Daniel Wiffen goes in pursuit of gold medal glory on Tuesday night at the Paris Olympics. The Northern Ireland man takes part in the 800m freestyle final.\n\nWiffen will start in lane four as the fastest qualifier from the four heats that took place on Monday at La Defense Arena. He is aiming to become NI's first gold medallists at the Olympics since hockey pair Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood in 1988.\n\nThe signs look positive for the 23-year-old after he recorded his third fastest time ever on Monday night. He also goes into the Olympics as World 800m and 1500m freestyle champion, after he claimed the double success back in February.\n\nRead next: Coleraine delight as they bring 2018 Irish Cup winner back to The Showgrounds\n\nRead next: Manchester United's young stars treated to their first taste of hurling on coach's 'homecoming'\n\nHere's some more info on the final and how to watch it.\n\nWhen and where is the final?\n\nWiffen's medal bid will start at 8.02pm on Tuesday night in the La Defense Arena.\n\nHow can I watch it?\n\nCoverage of the swimming is due to be shown on BBC One and discovery+. RTE will also have live coverage.\n\nWhat he said\n\nDaniel Wiffen: \"I've never been in this shape before in my life. I was happy with my time, but I had my eyes on the Olympic record. The past three years have been a blast for me. I've been dropping 16 seconds every time I swam in the water in the 1500, and I've been PBing at every single international.\n\n\"I wasn't going in there with 100% effort trying to make the final - I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there.\"\n\nIreland's Daniel Wiffen after qualifying for the 800m Freestyle final at the Paris Olympics (Image: \u00a9INPHO/Morgan Treacy)\n\nLead challengers\n\nBobby Finke, the reigning Olympic champion, leads the posse who want to take down a swimmer who has improved beyond recognition from the one that finished 14th in Tokyo in the 800, breaking the national record in the process. He has been lowering it ever since. One of his biggest dangers, the Australian Sam Short, was overtaken and left well behind by Wiffen in the heat. Short didn't make the final and afterwards revealed that a virus had hampered his chances.\n\nWiffen also reeled in another Aussie, the 400m silver medallist Elijah Whittington, who pushed himself into the early lead. The Armagh man beat Whittington to gold in the Worlds six months ago.\n\nDouble celebrations?\n\nWiffen hails from Magheralin, on the border of Armagh and Down - and while both counties may claim him he is happy to add Armagh's All-Ireland final triumph on Sunday as more fuel for his bid for two or even three Olympic medals in the days to come.\n\n\"Yeah, Armagh won,\" he smiled. \"My birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day...what is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"\n\nRace betting odds\n\nMens 800m Freestyle Final\n\n8/11 Daniel Wiffen 4/1 Bobby Finke 13/2 Elijah Winnington 7/1 Ahmed Jaouadi 8/1 Georgio {"uri": "8251842402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:07:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:07:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:06:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/07/31/sports/wiffen-takes-mens-800-freestyle-gold-in-irish-first/", "title": "Wiffen takes men's 800 freestyle gold in Irish first - Stabroek News", "body": "(Reuters) - Daniel Wiffen wiped tears from his eyes on the Paris podium after becoming the first Irishman to win Olympic swimming gold, and a medal of any colour, with a thrilling 800 metres freestyle victory yesterday.\n\nWith his twin brother shouting in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in an Olympic record time of seven minutes 38.19 seconds to secure Ireland's first gold of the Games.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Bobby Finke of the United States took the silver, 0.56 behind, and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri the bronze.\n\n\"Amazing...'What's my name? Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion,\" he told Ireland's RTE television. \"It's really good. I can't believe it.\"\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also Northern Ireland's first gold medallist in 36 years.\n\n\"I mean, I'm not going to lie, I did tell everybody already I was going to do it before. So it's just good to see it on paper,\" Wiffen told reporters later as some measure of calm returned.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350 metres, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off.\n\nWiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri, the Tokyo silver medallist, took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Irishman, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first.\n\nHe turned around in triumph, putting his hands to his head before raising his fists to salute the crowd -- with a vocal Irish contingent -- at the La Defense Arena.\n\nWiffen, who won 800 and 1,500 gold at the world championships in Doha in February, donned his spectacles for the podium and dabbed repeatedly at his eyes as the Irish anthem sounded.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at Olympics before,\" he said.\n\nThe medal was Ireland's second in the pool in Paris, with Mona McSharry taking women's 100 breaststroke bronze on Monday night.\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris posted on X: \"Yes Daniel Wiffin! Masterful. Gold for Ireland. Those last 100 metres were mind blowing!! World class. Olympic record.\n\n\"I met Daniel's parents Rachel & Jonathan & brother Nathan at the weekend so know this is a dream come through for the whole family. {"uri": "8249962022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "05:08:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T05:08:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T05:05:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/30/daniel-wiffen-now-firmly-believes-he-can-make-the-olympic-medal-podium/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen now firmly believes he can make the Olympic medal podium", "body": "The 23-year-old Armagh swimmer qualified fastest of the eight finalists in the 800m freestyle\n\nMost of those fortunate enough to stand on an Olympic medal podium will tell you it's a place that must be truly believed in for it ever to be seen, and rarely has any Irish athlete believed he'll soon be standing there more than Daniel Wiffen.\n\nWiffen also believes he can win the gold, and if the 23-year-old Armagh swimmer can pull that off in Tuesday night's 800m freestyle final he'll join the shortlist of nine Irish names who achieved that feat in our century of Olympic participation. He would also be only the second swimmer after Michelle Smith de Bruin.\n\nHis confidence is not unfounded. Wiffen's heat time of 7:41.53 inside the Paris La D\u00e9fense Arena on Monday morning was the fastest of the eight finalists, giving him the prime fourth lane for the final.\n\nHe is the first Irish male swimmer to make an Olympic final.\n\n\"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100 per cent,\" said Wiffen of his semi-final, where he took over the lead from just after the halfway mark, as the Australian duo of Sam Short and Elijah Winnington set the pace.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100 per cent effort trying to make the final. I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\"\n\nAfter the four heats, defending champion Bobby Finke from the US was only fifth with his 7:43.00, with Ahmed Jaouadi from Tunisia also laying down a marker with his 7:42.07, the second fastest of the lot.\n\nWiffen will also have to contend with Gregorio Paltrinieri from Italy, the 2016 Olympic champion in the 1,500m, who won silver in the 800m in Tokyo. Wiffen will also be aiming for gold in the longer event, plus the 10km marathon swim in the Seine.\n\nHe's also won his last five consecutive championship finals, the 800m-1,500m double at the World Championships in February, two months after winning the 400m-800-1,500m treble at the European short-course championships.\n\n\"One hundred per cent I'm the fittest I've ever been, I've never been in this shape before in my life. The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, only 0.25 off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that, so that would have been pretty cool to get, but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal, so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we've got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine especially.\"\n\nAfter Armagh winning the All-Ireland football title on Sunday, he also believes a medal might be written in the stars.\n\n\"Yeah Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, and 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Olympic champion Wiffen", "body": "Daniel Wiffen says he had been dreaming about winning his first Olympic gold medal \"every day of my life\" after his historic victory in Paris.\n\nWiffen, 23, put in a stunning final 50 metres of the 800m freestyle to claim a first gold medal for an athlete from Northern Ireland in 36 years.\n\nIt was Team Ireland's first gold in Paris and first gold in the pool since the 1996 Games in Atlanta.\n\n\"I'm stuck for words at the moment,\" Wiffen told BBC Sport NI.\n\n\"It's an unforgettable experience, I'll remember this for the rest of my life.\"\n\nWiffen had qualified for the final in first place as he headed into the Games off the back of becoming a double world champion in Doha in February.\n\nAfter settling into the race in third position, Wiffen made his move to the front with 400 metres to go.\n\nHowever, the USA's Bobby Finke and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri responded and Wiffen found himself in a battle for gold with 50 metres remaining as the American edged into the lead.\n\nBut Wiffen is a double world champion for a reason, and dug deep to move back in front as the trio closed on the finish.\n\nThe La Defense Arena, which had been vocal in its support of French swimmer David Aubrey, exploded with colour and noise after what will be considered one of the most exciting finishes of any event at the Paris Games.\n\nWiffen admitted that winning a gold medal was \"definitely greater\" than he had imagined.\n\n\"I didn't want to leave it until the last 50 metres, so I went a bit early, threw it all down in the last 20 metres, and that was it.\n\n\"I walked out and I was so nervous. I didn't really get into my stroke until 300 metres, but I guessed that would happen as it's an Olympic final.\n\n\"I got into my rhythm and knew where the race was coming from.\"\n\nAfter his historic win, Wiffen was struggling to hold back the tears as he received his medal at the end of the Arena where the majority of his family, friends and coaches were cheering him on.\n\n\"I hope nobody saw that, to be honest. It's rare for me to cry, but it just shows you what it means to win an Olympic medal in this sport.\n\n\"Hopefully we have made swimming the number one sport in Ireland now.\n\n\"I'm happy now because it is so heavy. {"uri": "8251314016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:41:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:41:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:40:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/olympics-2024/daniel-wiffen-becomes-first-irishman-to-win-olympic-swim-medal-after-800m-freestyle-victory-1656078.html", "title": "Daniel Wiffen becomes first Irishman to win Olympic swim medal after 800m freestyle victory | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Daniel Wiffen became the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming medal when he struck gold with a thrilling 800 metres freestyle victory at the Paris Games on Tuesday.\n\nWith his twin brother watching in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in an Olympic record time of seven minutes 38.19 seconds to secure Ireland's first gold of the Games.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Bobby Finke of the United States took the silver, 0.56 behind, and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri the bronze.\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also the North's first gold medallist in 36 years.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350 metres, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off.\n\nWiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Armagh man, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first.\n\nHe turned around in triumph, putting his hands to his head before raising his fists to salute the crowd - with a vocal Irish contingent - at the La Defense Arena.\n\nWiffen won 800 and 1,500 gold at the world championships in Doha in February.\n\nTokyo 2020 marked the return of the men's event for the first time since 1904 and Wiffen missed out on the final, but he laid down a marker in Paris with the fastest qualifying time in Monday's heats.\n\nWiffen said: \"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down - I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\"\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breaking News.ie"}, "authors": {"uri": "8251350349", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:09:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:09:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:08:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/daniel-wiffen-credits-twin-brother-33362562", "title": "Wiffen credits twin brother for triumph as tears come for swimming sensation", "body": "One final stroke, one final push for the wall and Daniel Wiffen's red light came on. The colour of the medal was gold.\n\nHis arms were aching, his lungs nearly empty, but nothing was going to stop him on a famous night in Paris.\n\nAt the end, he turned and looked up the at the big screen -- Olympic champion over 800m and the first Irishman ever to win a medal in the pool at the Games.\n\nRead More: Daniel Wiffen strikes gold as the Terminator in his greatest performance yet\n\nRead More: Meet Daniel Wiffen, the Magheralin world champion with Olympic dreams\n\nA new Olympic record too.\n\n\"I was dying in the last 20 metres and I'm not sure if you saw that because my arms were in so much pain,\" said Wiffen.\n\n\"But I knew that the crowd was gonna carry me in and that's exactly what happened.\n\n\"I saw the red light on the block and then that was it.\"\n\nHe always credits his twin brother Nathan for pushing him along, getting under his skin when needed and giving him that extra motivation to get better.\n\nNathan is his training partner for life, his best friend and housemate. And his fellow YouTube star.\n\nLast night he helped settle his nerves too for the biggest race of his life.\n\n\"The only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" said Wiffen.\n\n\"That's what actually kept me level-headed when I walked out. It was just written in the stars.\"\n\nThe pair have nearly 4,000 subscribers to their Wiffen Twins page and post regular updates on everything from training to the 8,000 calories per day needed to fuel their swimming ambitions.\n\nIn their younger days they starred in BBC kids programmes and featured briefly in Game of Thrones.\n\nNathan was there again last night, wearing a green Team Wiffen T-shirt, urging him on as Wiffen took centre stage, this time the headline act. Child's play no more.\n\nAt the final turn it looked like anyone's race as Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri led with 50 metres to go. Then Wiffen got to work, hunting him down and storming to victory.\n\nAbout seven minutes and 38 seconds earlier the 23-year-old from Magheralin stood on the starting blocks in lane four.\n\nEither side of him were 19-year-old Tunisian Ahmed Jaouadi and Paltrinieri -- a three-time Olympic medallist, who won silver in this event in Tokyo.\n\nLurking dangerously on the blocks for lane two was Bobby Finke, the reigning Olympic 800m freestyle champion and the first American swimmer to win gold at 1500m in 37 years when he took that title in Tokyo as well.\n\nWiffen had not faced Finke when he won the world 800m final in Doha. This was a chance to settle that.\n\nWiffen has always been sure of his place at swimming's top table. Confidence is a preference for him. Last night he made good on it.\n\nBut an Olympic medal isn't won just on finals night -- a night of light shows, raucous crowds and glitz and glamour.\n\nWiffen's was won on the dark mornings and evenings in Lurgan and Lisburn and swimming pools up and down Ireland.\n\nIt was won in the countless sessions at Loughborough, the warm-ups, the swim-downs and the hard yards in training. In his case often as much as 80kms a week.\n\nHe set a new Irish record when competing in Tokyo, barely out of his teens and the records have been tumbling ever since.\n\nTwo years ago he finished fourth at the world Championships with a new European record and in February of this year he became world champion at 800m and 1500m.\n\nAt the worlds in February, Wiffen reeled in Paltrinieri over the final 50 to win and it was the same last night.\n\nIn the end, Paltrinieri was caught in the final strokes by Finke, who took silver for USA with the Italian taking bronze.\n\nWhen the medals came and the flags went up there were tears from Wiffen.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I was really hoping nobody was going to see that,\" said the 23-year-old.\n\n\"But it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\"\n\nOne he will never forget.\n\nGet the latest sports headlines straight to your inbox by signing up for free email alerts.", "source": {"uri": "irishmirror.ie", {"uri": "8251576209", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:40:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:40:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:40:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.channelnewsasia.com/sport/wiffen-takes-mens-800m-freestyle-gold-irish-first-4515081", "title": "Wiffen takes men's 800m freestyle gold in Irish first", "body": "PARIS :Daniel Wiffen wiped tears from his eyes on the Paris podium after becoming the first Irishman to win Olympic swimming gold, and a medal of any colour, with a thrilling 800m freestyle victory on Tuesday (Jul 30).\n\nWith his twin brother shouting in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in an Olympic record time of seven minutes 38.19s to secure Ireland's first gold of the Games.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Bobby Finke of the United States took the silver, 0.56s behind, and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri the bronze.\n\n\"Amazing ...'What's my name? Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion,\" he told Ireland's RTE television. \"It's really good. I can't believe it.\"\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also Northern Ireland's first gold medallist in 36 years.\n\n\"I mean, I'm not going to lie, I did tell everybody already I was going to do it before. So it's just good to see it on paper,\" Wiffen told reporters later as some measure of calm returned.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350m, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250m, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off.\n\nWiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri, the Tokyo silver medallist, took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Irishman, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first.\n\nHe turned around in triumph, putting his hands to his head before raising his fists to salute the crowd - with a vocal Irish contingent - at the La Defense Arena.\n\nWiffen, who won 800m and 1,500m gold at the world championships in Doha in February, donned his spectacles for the podium and dabbed repeatedly at his eyes as the Irish anthem sounded.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at Olympics before,\" he said.\n\nThe medal was Ireland's second in the pool in Paris, with Mona McSharry taking women's 100 breaststroke bronze on Monday night.\n\nIrish Prime Minister Simon Harris posted on X: \"Yes Daniel Wiffin! Masterful. Gold for Ireland. Those last 100m were mind blowing!! World class. Olympic record.\n\n\"I met Daniel's parents Rachel & Jonathan & brother Nathan at the weekend so know this is a dream come through for the whole family. {"uri": "8249789394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "01:54:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T01:54:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T01:53:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/other-sports/swimming/stars-aligning-for-daniel-wiffen-as-irish-ace-bids-for-medal-in-800m-final/a651745103.html", "title": "Stars aligning for Daniel Wiffen  as Irish ace bids for medal in 800m final", "body": "The bar was set high for Daniel Wiffen coming to Paris. Being a double world champion, that was only natural. But in the space of seven minutes, 41.53 seconds yesterday, the 23-year-old sent it a whole lot higher.\n\nWiffen came into the 800m freestyle as a contender but ahead of the final, at 8.02pm Irish time tonight, he's the man to beat. That's due to the controlled, classy display he unleashed to win his heat yesterday, his time making him the quickest qualifier and just a quarter of a second shy of the Olympic record.\n\nWhat was more ominous for Wiffen's rivals: he was keeping something in reserve. \"It wasn't at 100 per cent,\" he said. \"We'll go with 95. You didn't see my legs come in at the end so that's where [the extra bit] is, but I was holding a good pace and am happy with the morning swim.\"\n\nWiffen has been building for years towards this peak and said it's \"100 per cent\" the fittest he's ever been. A medal won't come easy, but after a memorable weekend for Armagh, one of their proudest sons now senses he might fulfil what he has long deemed his destiny.\n\n\"Yeah, Armagh won,\" he said. \"My birthday is on July 14, Bastille Day. What is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris [in their first Olympic appearance as an independent nation]? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\".\n\nWiffen is drawn in lane four in tonight's final, with his chief rivals around him: Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri and USA's Bobby Finke to his left, Tunisia's Ahmed Jaouadi and Australia's Elijah Winnington to his right.\n\nWiffen said there was \"no significance\" to having the fastest qualifying time but he's \"got a great lane to look around\" as a result. \"Any lane has a chance,\" he added. \"I'll be doing my homework, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best.\"\n\nHe looked majestic in his heat yesterday, coasting into the lead just after halfway and drawing clear in the third quarter.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster,\" he said. \"I was only off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that so that would have been pretty cool, but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them. I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.\"\n\nOnly nine athletes have ever won gold at the Games for Ireland and no Irishman has ever reached the podium in swimming. He's now on the brink. \"I'll take any medal, whatever colour,\" Wiffen said.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Independent"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8250421074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "10:21:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T10:21:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T10:20:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/sport/13508899/daniel-wiffen-rte-interview-800m-final-paris-olympics/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen makes alarming admission in RTE interview ahead of Olympic final", "body": "STRAIGHT-TALKING Daniel Wiffen came right out and labelled the food in the Olympic Village 'terrible' on Monday.\n\nThe double world champion was speaking after dominating his 800m freestyle heat in a time of 7:41.53, his third quickest time of his career.\n\nThe Loughborough University student is always a candid interviewee and that remained the case even moments after jumping out of the pool.\n\nWhile speaking to RTE about how good of a place he feels he is in the 23-year-old did throw in one eye-catching comment.\n\nWhen asked what he's made of his Olympic experience so, he replied: \"Yeah it's so good...I mean, the food in the Village is a bit terrible honestly.\n\n\"But everything else is class. I love our flat, our team atmosphere, everything.\n\n\"I just love being part of Team Ireland.\"\n\nWhile a bit of a throwaway remark, when RTE cut back to their Montrose studio pundit Earl McCarthy did pick up on that remark.\n\nHe noted that Wiffen's preparation might not be going optimally based on that complaint.\n\nBut the proof is in the...pool and so far, he looks set to justify his pre-Olympics status as one of Ireland's main medal hopes.\n\nIn another media appearance, Wiffen added:\n\n\"Armagh won (the All-Ireland), my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, what is it 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine, especially.\"\n\nOne of the main medal contenders, Sam Short, failed to reach the final.\n\nThe Australian who took silver at last year's World Championships in this distance finished third in the same heat as Wiffen.\n\nHe and compatriot Elijah Winnington - who took silver in the 400m on Saturday - went out quickly but Wiffen had overhauled Short by the halfway mark and Winnington shortly afterwards and never relinquished the lead.\n\nBut he believes there is more to come.\n\nHe said: \"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100 percent. It's tough to say, but we'll go with it being 95 percent.\n\n\"You didn't see my legs come in at the end so that's where it is, but I was holding a good pace.\n\n\"You see the Australians go out fast, I'm a middle swimmer, like to hold a fast pace no one else can hold.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100 percent effort trying to make the final. I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final.\n\n\"I've never been in this shape before in my life.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, I was just off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that so that would have been pretty cool to get but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"I'm happy with the morning swim and a fast time as well, I'm pretty happy. There's no significance to being the fastest qualifier, just I've got a great lane to look around.\"\n\nWiffen said that, although he cannot normally hear the crowd, it was different in La D\u00e9fense Arena where he was cheered on by considerable Irish support.\n\nAnd he admitted there were nerves before the got in the water.\n\nHe said: \"I was more nervous than I was before the World Championships, but that's just the Olympics, a different kind of level.\n\n\"But I dealt with it quite well. A bit nervous around the first 100m, but then I settled in.\n\n\"It's completely different, in Tokyo I was just there really qualified, and just tried to keep progressing.\n\n\"The past three years have been a blast for me, improving by 15 seconds in the 1500m every time I swam in the water, PBing in every international.\n\nAnd Wiffen intends to spend the evening swotting up on his opponents.\n\nHe said: \"I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them, I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.\n\n\"I said before, any lane has a chance. {"uri": "8251350344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:09:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:09:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:08:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/co-down-swimmer-becomes-first-individual-ni-athlete-to-win-olympic-gold-in-52-years/a1857416893.html", "title": "Co Down swimmer becomes first individual NI athlete to win Olympic gold in 52 years", "body": "Co Down swimmer Daniel Wiffen ended Northern Ireland's 52 year wait for an individual Olympic gold medal last night with a stunning victory in the men's 800 metres freestyle final.\n\nThe 23-year-old Team Ireland athlete from Magheralin won the 800m Freestyle Final in Paris on Tuesday night and set a new Olympic record.\n\nIn what was a historic night for local sport, it was just the first of two golds for Northern Ireland.\n\nBelfast swimmer and close friend Jack McMillan also received gold as part of Team GB's 4x200m Freestyle squad as they retained their Olympic title.\n\nBut an hour earlier, Wiffen had stormed to victory with a time of 7.38.19, narrowly beating the USA's Bobby Finke who was defending his gold medal from Tokyo three years ago.\n\nWiffen had made a gesture with his hands as he entered the La Defense Arena, and revealed the meaning after his victory.\n\n\"I was writing 'I am going into the history books' and that's exactly what I've done,\" he said.\n\nThe new Olympian expressed disappointment at his impressive time saying \"it's not the time I wanted\" before adding: \"But the Olympics is not about time, it's about getting your hand on the wall first.\"\n\nThe athlete described it as \"pretty ironic\" that the only voice he could hear cheering him on in the crowd was his identical twin brother Nathan.\n\nWiffen went into the race as the world record holder and was widely tipped as one of Ireland's greatest gold medal hopes at the games.\n\nIt's the first time that anyone from Northern Ireland has stood at the top of the podium since 1988, when hockey greats Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood were part of the victorious Great British squad in Seoul.\n\nBefore that it was Lady Mary Peters who won Britain's only athletics gold at the 1972 Munich Olympics after winning the pentathlon competition - it was decided on the final 200m event with the then 33-year-old claiming the title by one-tenth of a second.\n\nWiffen ended 2023 on a high with the fastest ever 800m freestyle time at the European Short Course Championships back in December.\n\nHe also secured 400m and 1500m Short Course titles after narrowly missing out on a medal at the World Championships last summer despite repeatedly beating his own Irish records at 800m and 1500m.\n\nThe world champion almost set an Olympic record as he qualified for tonight's event, finishing in 7:41:53 on Monday, just a quarter of a second off Mykhailo Romanchuk's Olympic record set in Tokyo.\n\nIn a big surprise the Ukrainian failed to qualify for the final alongside Australia's Sam Short.\n\nAmerican distance swimmer and two-time Olympian Bobby Finke came away from last night's race with a silver medal after failing to chase down Wiffen.\n\nMeanwhile Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri was behind by over a second at the 750-meter mark to take bronze, despite using his signature closing speed technique.\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, I was looking for Bobby Finke the whole time and I was like 'I ain't getting caught last 50... I've been practicing my whole year for this,\" Wiffen said.\n\n\"I was just looking and looking over [my shoulder]... I saw this is over, I've won.\"\n\nWiffen described being referred to as a gold medalist Olympian as \"amazing\" as he thanked his family, coach and Irish teammates.\n\n\"I couldn't to it without everybody, I am not alone out there,\" he said.\n\n\"It's pretty crazy. I have won everything... and now the Olympics.\n\n\"Now I can say that I'm probably the best ever so that's just even better.\"\n\nStormont's Deputy First Minister was among the first to congratulate NI's latest Olympic champion.\n\nEmma Little-Pengelly took to social media to post: \"Amazing!! Well done Daniel Wiffen.\n\n\"Northern Ireland's first individual gold since Lady Mary Peters in 1972! (and from Lagan Valley too!) What a result!\"\n\nAlliance leader Naomi Long also shared her congratulation online, adding: \"What a stunning performance!\"\n\nSport NI's interim chief executive Richard Archibald expressed immense pride.\n\n\"After a 36 year wait Daniel Wiffen is bringing an Olympic gold medal home to Northern Ireland!\" he said.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are immensely proud of Daniel and his achievements.\n\n\"We are proud to have supported Daniel at the start of his career through our National Lottery funded Athlete Award. His progress over the last few years has been incredible, with European and World titles as well as a coveted world record and now an Olympic record.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to us all and I am sure his win will encourage many young people across Northern Ireland to try their hand at swimming. With two more events to come the sky is the limit for Daniel and we wish him all the very best!\"\n\nEarlier, McMillan had competed for Team GB in the semi-finals earlier in the day helping the squad get to the final ahead of their stunning victory.\n\nThe 24-year-old, who previously represented Ireland in the Tokyo Games but switched teams for his shot at Olympic glory, put in a strong leg, securing a time of 1:45.68 to maintain GB's advantage, before Kieran Bird and Tom Dean finished the heat in 7:05.11.\n\nHe dropped out for the final with Matt Richards and Duncan Scott replacing him and Bird in the line-up - but still leaves Paris with a gold medal.", "source": {"uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Belfast Telegraph"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion,\" he told Ireland's RTE television. \"It's really good. I can't believe it.\"\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also Northern Ireland's first gold medallist in 36 years.\n\n\"I mean, I'm not going to lie, I did tell everybody already I was going to do it before. So it's just good to see it on paper,\" Wiffen told reporters later as some measure of calm returned.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350 metres, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off.\n\nWiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri, the Tokyo silver medallist, took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Irishman, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first.\n\nHe turned around in {"uri": "8251317400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:42:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:42:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:41:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/30/in-pictures-daniel-wiffen-strikes-gold-as-ireland-claim-second-medal-of-the-olympic-games/", "title": "In Pictures: Daniel Wiffen strikes gold as Ireland claim second medal of the Olympic Games", "body": "Co Armagh swimmer as good as his word and claims 800m freestyle gold medal in Paris\n\nDaniel Wiffen made history as he claimed Ireland's first, and hopefully not last, Olympic gold medal of the Paris Games with a stunning victory in the men's 800 metres freestyle final.\n\nThe Co Armagh swimmer had spoken after the heats of his confidence of taking gold, and that was not unfounded as he went into the final as the fastest qualifier.\n\n\"I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final,\" he said on Monday. \"Any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\"\n\nWiffen had earned the prime fourth lane for the final at the Paris La D\u00e9fense Arena and settled into a battle with Italy's Gregorio Paltrineri for the lead before holding off a late surge from Bobby Finke of the United States to seal top spot.\n\nWith his twin brother watching in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in an Olympic record time of seven minutes 38.19 seconds to secure Ireland's first gold of the Games. Reigning Olympic champion Finke took the silver, 0.56 behind, and Paltrinieri the bronze.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350 metres, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off. Wiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Irishman, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first. The colour of the medal was gold. His arms were aching, his lungs nearly empty, but nothing was going to stop him on a famous night in Paris.\n\nAt the end, he turned and looked up the at the big screen -- Olympic champion over 800m and the first Irishman ever to win a medal in the pool at the Games. A new Olympic record too.\n\n\"I was dying in the last 20 metres and I'm not sure if you saw that because my arms were in so much pain,\" said Wiffen.\n\nREAD MORE: NI man wins Olympic gold medal 'after 36 year wait'\n\nREAD MORE: Who is Daniel Wiffen? Inside life of Magheralin Olympic sensation\n\n\"But I knew that the crowd was gonna carry me in and that's exactly what happened.\n\n\"I saw the red light on the block and then that was it.\"\n\nHe always credits his twin brother Nathan for pushing him along, getting under his skin when needed and giving him that extra motivation to get better.\n\nNathan is his training partner for life, his best friend and housemate. And his fellow YouTube star.\n\nLast night he helped settle his nerves too for the biggest race of his life.\n\n\"The only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" said Wiffen.\n\n\"That's what actually kept me level-headed when I walked out. It was just written in the stars.\"\n\nThe pair have nearly 4,000 subscribers to their Wiffen Twins page and post regular updates on everything from training to the 8,000 calories per day needed to fuel their swimming ambitions.\n\nIn their younger days they starred in BBC kids programmes and featured briefly in Game of Thrones.\n\nNathan was there again last night, wearing a green Team Wiffen T-shirt, urging him on as Wiffen took centre stage, this time the headline act. Child's play no more.\n\nAt the final turn it looked like anyone's race as Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri led with 50 metres to go. Then Wiffen got to work, hunting him down and storming to victory.\n\nAbout seven minutes and 38 seconds earlier the 23-year-old from Magheralin stood on the starting blocks in lane four.\n\nEither side of him were 19-year-old Tunisian Ahmed Jaouadi and Paltrinieri -- a three-time Olympic medallist, who won silver in this event in Tokyo.\n\nLurking dangerously on the blocks for lane two was Bobby Finke, the reigning Olympic 800m freestyle champion and the first American swimmer to win gold at 1500m in 37 years when he took that title in Tokyo as well.\n\nWiffen had not faced Finke when he won the world 800m final in Doha. This was a chance to settle that.\n\nWiffen has always been sure of his place at swimming's top table. Confidence is a preference for him. Last night he made good on it.\n\nBut an Olympic medal isn't won just on finals night -- a night of light shows, raucous crowds and glitz and glamour.\n\nWiffen's was won on the dark mornings and evenings in Lurgan and Lisburn and swimming pools up and down Ireland.\n\nIt was won in the countless sessions at Loughborough, the warm-ups, the swim-downs and the hard yards in training. In his case often as much as 80kms a week.\n\nHe set a new Irish record when competing in Tokyo, barely out of his teens and the records have been tumbling ever since.\n\nTwo years ago he finished fourth at the world Championships with a new European record and in February of this year he became world champion at 800m and 1500m.\n\nAt the worlds in February, Wiffen reeled in Paltrinieri over the final 50 to win and it was the same last night.\n\nIn the end, Paltrinieri was caught in the final strokes by Finke, who took silver for USA with the Italian taking bronze.\n\nWhen the medals came and the flags went up there were tears from Wiffen.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I was really hoping nobody was going to see that,\" said the 23-year-old.\n\n\"But it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\"\n\nOne he will never forget.\n\nSign up to our f ree sports newsletter to get the latest headlines to your inbox.", "source": {"uri": "belfastlive.co.uk",
