{"uri": "8248759500", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "11:07:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T11:07:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T11:06:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/daniel-wiffen-5-6449379-Jul2024/", "title": "Wiffen puts the Olympic Games on notice on historic morning for Ireland in the pool", "body": "Ireland qualfiied another two swimmers for Olympic finals today - they had never previously had more than one in a single Games. Gavin Cooney reports from La Defense Arena, Paris\n\nIT'S FAIR TO say that that we here on the island of Saints and Yerrahs are unfamiliar with Daniel Wiffen's kind of dominance.\n\nThis morning he cruised into the final of the men's 800m freestyle at the Paris Olympics, posting the competition's fastest time as he did so. Oh, and he effectively pulled up at the line.\n\n\"It's never comfortable, but I wasn't at 100 percent\", said Wiffen. \"You didn't see my legs come in at the end so that's where it is, but holding a good pace, happy with the morning swim and a fast time as well, I'm pretty happy.\"\n\nAsked as to what percentage he was motoring at, Wiffen laughed and said, \"that's a tough one to say, we'll go with 95.\"\n\nWiffen's Australian opponents in his heat, Elijah Winnington and Sam Short, went out hard, but he calmly and gradually scythed them down. He took the lead at the 500 metre mark and left everyone bobbing about in his wake from there.\n\nHe held back his kick for the line, so he has afterburners to thrust in tomorrow's final if he needs it. Those who have worked for Wiffen say his greatest power is not necessarily in his legs, but in the awesome pulling power of his arms.\n\nOthers might look at his remarkable self-confidence as the greatest weapon in his arsenal.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100 percent effort trying to make the final\", he said. \"I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, I was only 0.25 off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that. so that would have been pretty cool to get but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\"\n\nThat time, by the way, was Wiffen's third-fastest ever.\n\nWiffen says the only benefit to posting the fastest time is the fact he will be racing from lane four in tomorrow night's final, from which he says he can have a good look around at his competition.\n\nThat competition is suddenly looking tamed. Aussie Sam Short was deemed one of his biggest medal rivals, but having struggled with illness at last month's national trials, he shockingly failed to make the final. The 2023 world champion meanwhile, Tunisia's Ahmed Hafnaoui, pulled out of the Games a couple of months ago.\n\nWiffen's biggest rivals in tomorrow night's final will be American Bobby Finke and Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri.\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here\", said Wiffen, \"it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this.\"\n\nWiffen will race the 1500m in the pool too, before he takes to the Seine for the 10km open water event.\n\nLook hard enough across the rippling water and you might have seen Ireland's rising tide. Ireland have never before had more than one swimmer make the final of a single Olympic Games, but we qualified two within an hour this morning, as Ellen Walshe followed Mona McSharry and preceded Wiffen in joining the very elite of the elite.\n\nThe qualification process for the longer-distance events is necessarily swift: there are no semi-finals so, like Wiffen, Ellen Walshe had to rank among the eight-fastest times across two heats.\n\nShe initially made a slow start in the opening butterfly section, lagging seventh at the first turn, before then seguing into the backstroke, her weakest discipline of those being examined. But she clung on, and when she glanced to her left - having been landed awkwardly in lane one - she battled through the water.\n\n\"I knew I had 200 to go, I could see the middle of the field and thought, 'Okay, I just need to turn on the gears and fight'\", said Walshe. \"I had a strong finish and I am delighted to go into the final tonight.\"\n\nShe wasn't happy with her time of 4:39.97, more than two seconds off her personal best. Resetting that record is her ambition in a final for which Canada's world record holder Summer Mcintosh is the favourite.\n\n\"It was such a relief\", said Walshe of the moment she realised she had made the cut. \"The time left my head which I wasn't too over the moon with, but I have another chance to have a go at this tonight.\"\n\nDanielle Hill, meanwhile, took care of her business by placing 16th in the heats of the 100m breaststroke to progress to her semi-finals tonight.\n\n\"Pretty cool\", said Wiffen of his team-mate's results.\n\nHe expects more of his own success to follow.\n\n\"Armagh won, my birthday is on 14 July, Bastille Day. What is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"", "source": {"uri": "the42.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "The42"}, "authors": [{"uri": "gavin_cooney@the42.ie", "name": "Gavin Cooney", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-438788978", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:20:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:20:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:20:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/olympics/news/15234/13187726/olympics-2024-daniel-wiffen-wins-swimming-gold-for-ireland-with-800m-freestyle-victory-in-paris", "title": "Olympics 2024: Daniel Wiffen wins swimming gold for Ireland with 800m freestyle victory in Paris", "body": "Ireland's Daniel Wiffen held off Team USA's Bobby Finke to take gold by 0.56 seconds and set a new Olympic record in the men's 800m freestyle final; Wiffen's gold follows compatriot Mona McSharry winning bronze in the women's 100m breaststroke on Monday.\n\nDaniel Wiffen made history as he claimed Ireland's first Olympic gold medal of the Paris Games with a stunning victory in the men's 800m freestyle final.\n\nWiffen became Ireland's first male medallist in the pool and third overall after Michelle Smith and Mona McSharry, who only made it onto the list on Monday with bronze in the women's 100m breaststroke.\n\nAlthough Leeds-born Wiffen was trailing Gregorio Paltrineri with 50m left, he overhauled the Italian then held off a late surge from Bobby Finke of the United States to take top spot by 0.56 seconds.\n\nWhile Finke took silver and Paltrineri bronze, Wiffen, who won the world title at the distance in February, was celebrating an Olympic record-winning time of seven minutes and 38.19 seconds.\n\nTokyo 2020 marked the return of the men's event for the first time since 1904 and Wiffen missed out on the final, but he laid down a marker in Paris with the fastest qualifying time in Monday's heats.\n\nHe first hit the front just before the halfway stage and while he ceded control to Paltrineri, the 23-year-old was just 0.1 secs adrift and he had plenty left in the tank to mount a final charge. Finke did too but Wiffen's management of the race was paced perfectly and he had just enough to hold off the American.\n\n\"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible,\" Wiffen said. \"I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down - I heard my brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"\n\nIreland pays tribute to 'history-maker' Wiffen\n\nWiffen becomes the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first-ever male swimming gold medallist.\n\nThe last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB Hockey team at Seoul in 1988, while Wiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and Deputy First Minister Emma Little Pengelly congratulated the swimming hero.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement. \"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nHow to follow the Olympics on Sky\n\nKeep up to date with the action from the Paris 2024 Olympics across Sky Sports' digital platforms and Sky Sports News every day between now and Sunday August 11.\n\nAlongside live news blogs and updates as records are broken and medals won on skysports.com and the Sky Sports app, Sky Sports News will also have dedicated reporters on the scene in Paris during the Games to gather the latest news both inside and outside the arenas in France as well as reaction to the big moments from medal {"uri": "8251409683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:11:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:11:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:10:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/daniel-wiffen-6-6450843-Jul2024/", "title": "'Can I do this?' - Wiffen beats the nerves and then the world", "body": "Daniel Wiffen explains how he conquered some rare unease to set a new Olympic record and win gold. Gavin Cooney reports from La Defense Arena, Paris\n\nTHE REVELATION OF the night was perhaps less the gold medal or the Olympic Record but that Daniel Wiffen was nervous.\n\nThe man who one went to a sports psychologist to be told he didn't need a sports psychologist woke up this morning feeling a tiny pinprick of doubt.\n\n\"I know that I seem very confident on the outside\" he said, \"but there's always a little percentage of you thinking, 'Can I do this?'\"\n\n800 metres is not quite his favourite distance. No, that's the 1500m. For any other swimmer, the longer the exposure to Daniel Wiffen, the greater the pain.\n\nBut the 800m? Perhaps it wasn't quite long enough. Perhaps one, two, or even three of the world's best swimmers were sufficiently fortified to survive seven-odd minutes looking directly into the sun.\n\nBut Wiffen tackled his nerves as best he could. He went to work. He went for a quick session in the pool and told John Rudd of Swim Ireland that he wanted to hit 1:02. He clocked 1:01.01.\n\n\"It's done\", Wiffen told Rudd. \"We've won.\"\n\nWiffen was last to swagger out for the race, status earned by going fastest in the heats. He was also given the central lane four, from which he could keep a darting eye on his two main rivals, America's Bobby Finke and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri.\n\nLook at the casual swing of those long, limby arms: it's hard to believe the force with which they pull him through the water. They could haul down statues.\n\nBut it seems not all the nerves were gone. He said afterwards that his first 300 metres were \"absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place.\"\n\nTo the rest of us it looked like a standard teeth-clenched tussle for an Olympic gold medal.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAs he did in Wiffen's semi-final, Australia's Elijah Winnington went out fast, and lead for the first half of the race. Wiffen found his rhythm at the 300m mark, and Winnington would soon vacate the premises. He ceased being relevant from 400 metres. He allegedly finished last.\n\nNow was time for Wiffen to worry about Finke and Paltrinieri to his immediate left in lane three.\n\n\"My goal was to keep building, keep building, keep building.\"\n\nBut he couldn't shake Palrinieri.\n\nThe splits were winnowing with every fifty metres.\n\nWiffen's 0.47 second lead at 500 metres became 0.06. Then 0.01. Then they jacknifed. Wiffen was second, 0.57 seconds behind. It got worse. With 100 metres to go, he trailed by 0.78 seconds.\n\nBut then came the recovery. Paltrinieri had made his investment in a subprime mortgage, because soon he was about to be bankrupt. He led Wiffen by a tenth of a second as they hit the wall for the final 50 metres, but then the Italian fell. He managed to hold on for a bronze medal.\n\nBut the final boss wasn't done.\n\n\"I was literally looking at Bobby Finke. That's all I was doing. I was like, 'this guy comes about the fastest, well, not the fastest any more.\"\n\nWiffen's glance at Finke cost him what he described as a \"lopey stroke\", but he quickly ratcheted it tight. Sprint.\n\n\"I was dying last 20 metres and I'm not sure if you saw that. because my arms were in so much pain.\n\n\"But I knew that the crowd was gonna carry me in, and that's exactly what happened.\"\n\nWiffen at the moment of triumph. James Crombie / INPHO James Crombie / INPHO / INPHO\n\nHe hit the wall in 7:38.19, a new Olympic record. The Olympic record he promised on Monday night. That Finke and Paltrinieri both finished within the old record time accentuated what Wiffen had just done. They both brought the best they had and it still wasn't enough.\n\nWiffen climbed out of the pool and pumped his arms with a confident kind of steadiness. He said the only voice in the crowd he heard was his twin brother's. He returned 35 minutes later in his tracksuit, stood atop the podium, and let a few tears roll down his cheek as Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann rang around the arena and the Irish flag began its slow, slow, gorgeously slow ascent in front of him.\n\nThe crowning that awaits all great Irish athletes is to be known nationwide by their first name. Sonia, Kellie, Katie, Roy, Jack, Johnny, Ruby...Mona.\n\nWiffen might be the first to become a verb.\n\nWiffen (verb): to execute brilliantly and in so doing have all your thoughts about your brilliance confirmed.\n\nFind a car parking spot right outside the supermarket on a busy Friday evening? You've Wiffened it.\n\nJump through the Dart doors as they are closing? You've Wiffened it.\n\nFix that leaky tap without calling a plumber? You've Wiffened it.\n\n\"There's a whole saying going around of getting Finked\", Wiffen told RT\u00c9.\n\nNot anymore. This was the night a whole sport shifted, and a country couldn't quite believe it was finally tilting towards us.", "source": {"uri": "the42.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "The42"}, "authors": {"uri": "8248779917", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "11:19:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T11:19:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T11:19:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/daniel-wiffen-armagh-won-my-birthdays-on-bastille-day-everything-seems-to-be-aligning-doesnt-it-YC3LW5SBYNENTP2K65O5RDUZGA/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen: 'Armagh won, my birthday's on Bastille Day - everything seems to be aligning, doesn't it?'", "body": "Magheralin swimmer fastest qualifier to seal place in Tuesday night's 800m final\n\nWHILE Armagh continues to go mad in the wake of Sunday's All-Ireland triumph, Daniel Wiffen is determined to make it a week to remember for the Orchard county.\n\nThe 23-year-old made easy work of Monday's 800m freestyle heat at La Defense Arena, becoming the fastest qualifier as he sealed his place in Tuesday night's final.\n\nElijah Winnington set the early pace in the final heat but Wiffen, a two-time World gold medallist earlier this year, ground the Australian down. In doing so, he recorded his third fastest time ever - 7.41.53 - as Wiffen's dreams of Olympic glory in Paris remain firmly on course.\n\nConsidering the high the county is already on after Kieran McGeeney's men toppled Galway on Sunday, the Magheralin man is hoping to tap into that mood when the final comes around.\n\n\"I mean, Armagh won, my birthday's on July 14th, Bastille Day, it's 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris... just everything seems to be aligning, doesn't it?\"\n\nAnd, despite posting such an impressive time, Wiffen insists there is much more to come when he takes to the water on Tuesday night.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all - I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster.\n\n\"I was only 0.4 off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that so that would have been pretty cool to get, but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100 per cent - you didn't see my legs come in at the end so that's where it is, but holding a good pace, happy with the morning swim and a fast time as well, I'm pretty happy.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100 per cent effort trying to make the final... I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I've got a great lane to look around but, I said before, any lane has a chance.\n\n\"I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\"\n\nWhen he travelled to Tokyo three years ago, Wiffen wasn't in the frame at the top end of competition; as an experience, it was a world away from where he stands now.\n\nMonday's heat affirmed his position as the hunted going into the final and, despite having been on this stage before - albeit in entirely different circumstances - there were nerves as he made the walk poolside.\n\n\"I was more nervous there than when I won the World Championships.\n\n\"That's just the Olympics. It's a different kind of level. Yeah, I was nervous but I dealt with it quite well. You're nervous round the first 100, then you settle in.\n\n\"I never really hear the crowd when I'm swimming, that one I could hear, 100 per cent. There was a lot of Irish support, I saw a lot of tricolours in the stands so I'm pretty happy.\n\n\"In Tokyo I was just there already qualified, trying to keep progressing. The past three years have been a blast for me, I've been dropping 16 seconds every time I swam in the water in the 1500, and I've been PBing at every single international.\n\n\"I just want to keep that streak up here. I've never been in this shape before in my life.\"\n\nThe question of medals has been ever-present in the weeks and months leading towards Paris. Now, with what he hopes will be a first of these Games just around the corner, what are his expectations?\n\n\"Any medal is good.\n\n\"It's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention {"uri": "8251318488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:43:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:43:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:42:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.lmfm.ie/news/news-extra/daniel-wiffen-delivers-olympic-gold-for-ireland/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen delivers Olympic gold for Ireland", "body": "It's been a golden night for Team Ireland at the Olympic Games in Paris.\n\nDaniel Wiffen has won Ireland's first gold medal at the Paris Olympic Games.\n\nHe edged ahead of the field over the final 10m to touch home first in the final of the 800m Freestyle.\n\nThe 23-year old double world champion had signalled his intent, in finishing quickest in the semi-finals on Monday.\n\nWiffen stormed to gold in a time of 7:38.19 setting a new personal best, national record, European record by a full second in the process.\n\nWiffen's stunning performance also set a new Olympic record (OR), knocking over three seconds off the previous one of 7:41.28 set by Mykhalo Romanchuk of Ukraine in Tokyo 2020.\n\nIn a nail-biting race Wiffen beat Tokyo 2020 gold medallist American Bobby Finke into second place, who touched in a time of 7:38.75, with Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri claiming bronze in 7:39.38.\n\nWiffen has had the most remarkable year having become the first Irish swimmer to ever medal at a World Long Course Championships in February, before becoming double world champion in the 800m and 1500m freestyle, and his 14:34.07 in the latter was the fifth fastest in history.\n\nSpeaking poolside afterwards a jubilant Wiffen said: \"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down - I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\"\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"\n\n\"It feels incredible. Inside life of Magheralin Olympic sensation, his twin brother and game of Thrones past", "body": "Daniel Wiffen has long predicted big things for himself and his dreams look set to become a reality at the Paris Olympics. The Magheralin man swims in the 800m freestyle final on Tuesday evening, July 30, at 8pm.\n\nThe former Loughborough University student is favourite for the race having cruised to victory in the semi-final and Wiffen himself is making no bones about his own targets.\n\nIn 2021, he competed in the men's 800m freestyle and 1,500m freestyle at the Tokyo Olympics. In 2022, he won a silver medal representing Northern Ireland in the 1,500m freestyle at the Commonwealth Games.\n\nRead next: Daniel Wiffen storms into Olympic 800m Freestyle final with Armagh's victory on his mind\n\nRead next: Rory McIlroy had 'sense of resentment' surrounding Team Ireland decision over GB\n\nTwo years ago, he became the first Irish swimmer to break a European record in history. Since then, the 23-year-old has added one gold and two silver European U23 medals, three European gold medals - both in 2023 - and two World gold medals.\n\nWiffen is a twin brother with his brother Nathan also a brilliant swimmer in his own right. Earlier this year Daniel became the fourth man to do the distance double when he won the 1500m freestyle by more than 10 seconds at the World Championships up in Doha.\n\nEarlier this week, Wiffen posted the third fastest 800m time of his career to secure a Paris final spot - and the opportunity to win a first individual summer Olympics gold by a Northern Ireland athlete since Lady Mary Peters' 1972 pentathlon triumph.\n\nHow old is Daniel Wiffen?\n\nDaniel Wiffen is 23. He was born on July 14, 2001.\n\nWhere is he from?\n\nHe was born in London, but moved to Magheralin, on the Down Armagh border at the age of two.\n\nWho is his brother?\n\nHsi twin brother is called Nathan and he is also a world class swimmer. He finished fourth in the 1,500m at the 2024 European Championships.\n\nThe siblings once worked as extras in Game of Thrones - in the iconic 'Red Wedding' scene.\n\nSwimming is in the blood for the Wiffens as their mum swam at a high level as did their older brother Ben who now works as a coach.\n\nHis thoughts on his Olympic chances:\n\n\"Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, what is it 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? {"uri": "8251534053", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:44:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:44:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:43:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://thesun.my/sport/2024-paris-olympics/tearful-wiffen-makes-irish-history-with-olympic-gold-DN12797488", "title": "Tearful Wiffen makes Irish history with Olympic gold", "body": "Gold medallist Ireland's Daniel Wiffen poses with his medal follwoing the men's 800m freestyle swimming event during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games - AFPpix\n\nDANIEL Wiffen made history Tuesday as the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming gold medal, shedding tears as the enormity of the achievement sunk in.\n\nThe 23-year-old hit the wall first in 7min 38.19sec, the fifth-fastest time ever, to be crowned 800m freestyle champion in La Defense Arena.\n\nThe only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic pool came at Atlanta in 1996 when Michelle Smith collected three.\n\nWiffen, the first Irish male swimmer to win a medal of any colour, couldn't hide his emotions when the national anthem played as he stood on top of the podium.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope that nobody's gonna see that,\" he said.\n\n\"But, yeah, it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at an Olympics before, and it's just crazy to say that it was me standing on a number one podium here for the first time.\"\n\nWiffen, who also won the 800m at the world championships in Doha this year, came home ahead of American defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) and Tokyo silver medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri (7:39.38) of Italy.\n\nHe took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired and was reeled in.\n\nPaltrinieri made at a move at 600m and led to the final turn before Wiffen came roaring back to rewrite the history books.\n\n\"To be fair, normally I do only train one way and that's just to try hold on, burn everybody out in the middle,\" he said.\n\n\"But I knew I Olympics is completely different. You don't know how you're going to feel in the first 100.\n\n\"So really, my first part of the race was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place, I was just so nervous.\n\n\"But luckily I had a good enough speed to keep it going and I was still in the race. Then my goal was to keep building.\"\n\nWiffen paid tribute to his identical twin brother Nathan, also a distance swimmer who missed out on qualification for Paris, for urging him on.\n\n\"I tell you what, the only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" he said.\n\n\"I've dreamed of this every day of my life.\n\n\"I know that I seem very confident on the outside, but there's He edged a titanic tussle with American Finke, who took silver, and Italy's Paltrinieri who bagged bronze.\n\nWorld champion Wiffen took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired as the Irishman reeled him in.\n\nAlthough Leeds-born Wiffen was trailing with 50m left, he overhauled Paltrineri then held off a late surge from Finke of the United States to seal 7:38.19 was the fifth fastest time in history, although still more than six seconds slower than Zhang Lin's world record set in Rome 15 years ago.\n\nThe only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic {"uri": "8251252776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:47:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:47:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:46:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/olympics/daniel-wiffen-claims-olympic-gold-medal-for-ireland-in-mens-800m-freestyle-final/a963365326.html", "title": "Daniel Wiffen claims Olympic gold medal for Ireland in men's 800m freestyle final", "body": "Daniel Wiffen has won the gold medal in the 800m freestyle to become Ireland first Olympic champion at the 2024 Paris Games.\n\nHe did exactly what he as promised in the Paris La Defense Arena tonight completing an astonishing 24 hours for Irish swimming.\n\nThe 23-year-old, who celebrated his birthday on Bastille Day, is the first male swimmer to secure an Olympic medal of any colour as Ireland won their second medal - both in swimming - on only Day 4 of the 2024 Games.\n\nIn the past, Pat O'Callaghan twice, Bob Tisdall, Ron Delany, Michael Carruth, Michelle Smith, Katie Taylor, Paul O'Donovan, Fintan McCarthy and Kellie Harrington have won Olympic gold medals for Ireland.\n\nWiffen now becomes the tenth member of that most exclusive club. It is the 37th Olympic medal won the Irish athletes since 1928.\n\nWiffen was the last of the eight finalists to be introduced and he received a big reception from the packed arena.\n\nAustralia's Elijah Winnington set the early pace leading the field through the first five laps with Wiffen just behind.\n\nBut the Armagh swimmer took the lead for the first time on lap 8 with the veteran Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri closest.\n\nAt the 600m mark he was still ahead but then the Italian took over with the defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke in third spot.\n\nAs the final reached its climax, Wiffen retook the lead and was second at 750m and then he powered ahead in final 50 to win in an new Olympic record of 7:38.10 ahead of Finke (7.38. 75) with Paltrinieri picking up another Olympic medal in third spot.\n\nBut the evening belonged to Wiffen.\n\nThe double 800m/1500m World champion will attempt to make it an Olympic double in the longer event later this week.\n\nBut for the moment the Loughborough University student from Magheralin, in County Armagh can savour the greatest moment of his career\n\nWiffen, who is coached in Loughborough by Andi Manley posted the fastest time (7.41.53) of the eight finalists including defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (US) and 2016 gold medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri in the heats. But he underlined his class to improving his time when he needed too.\n\nSince accepting a sports scholarship at Loughborough University along with his twin brother Nathan, having previous swam competitively with Lurgan SC, he made remarkable progress.\n\nHe first display his potential as a rookie at the Tokyo Games three years ago setting new Irish records of 7:51.65 and 15:07.09 when placing 14th and 20th respectively in the 800m and 1500m.\n\nHe secured a silver at the 2022 Commonwealth Games in 2022.\n\nA year later in Japan he was fourth in both the 800m and 1500m at World Championships, with a new European record in the 800m.\n\nThen at the European short course championships last year he won three gold medals (400m, 800m, 1500m) where his 7:20.46 smashed Grant Hackett's world record from 2008.\n\nIn February 2024, he not only became the first Irish swimmer to medal at a World LC Championships but became a double world champion in 800m/1500m and his 13:34:07 was the fifth fastest in history.\n\nIt has been quite a week for Armagh. And Wiffen is by no means finished.\n\nHe is out again in the heats of the 1500m on Saturday with the final 24 hours later and has also entered the 10km marathon swim scheduled for the Seine, though with the postponement of the men's triathlon it remains to be seen whether this event will go ahead as scheduled.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish {"uri": "8250911162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "15:21:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T15:21:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T15:20:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/athletics/meet-daniel-wiffen-magheralin-world-33360451", "title": "Meet Daniel Wiffen, the Magheralin world champion with Olympic dreams", "body": "Daniel Wiffen swims in the 800m freestyle final on Tuesday evening, July 30, at 8pm where he can turn his dreams and predictions into a reality.\n\nThe Magheralin man, a former Loughborough University student, is favourite for the race having cruised to victory in the semi-final and Wiffen himself is making no bones about his own targets.\n\nIn 2021, he competed in the men's 800m freestyle and 1,500m freestyle at the Tokyo Olympics. In 2022, he won a silver medal representing Northern Ireland in the 1,500m freestyle at the Commonwealth Games.\n\nREAD MORE: What Irish athletes are in action on Tuesday at the Olympic Games? Full list for day 4 in Paris\n\nREAD MORE: Kellie Harrington's defiant message after opening bout win at the 2024 Olympics\n\nTwo years ago, he became the first Irish swimmer to break a European record in history. Since then, the 23-year-old has added one gold and two silver European U23 medals, three European gold medals - both in 2023 - and two World gold medals.\n\nWiffen is a twin brother with his brother Nathan also a brilliant swimmer in his own right. Earlier this year Daniel became the fourth man to do the distance double when he won the 1500m freestyle by more than 10 seconds at the World Championships up in Doha.\n\nEarlier this week, Wiffen posted the third fastest 800m time of his career to secure a Paris final spot - and the opportunity to win a first individual summer Olympics gold by a Northern Ireland athlete since Lady Mary Peters' 1972 pentathlon triumph.\n\nHow old is Daniel Wiffen?\n\nDaniel Wiffen is 23. He was born on July 14, 2001.\n\nWhere is he from?\n\nHe was born in London, but moved to Magheralin, on the Down Armagh border at the age of two.\n\nWho is his brother?\n\nHsi twin brother is called Nathan and he is also a world class swimmer. He finished fourth in the 1,500m at the 2024 European Championships.\n\nThe siblings once worked as extras in Game of Thrones - in the iconic 'Red Wedding' scene.\n\nSwimming is in the blood for the Wiffens as their mum swam at a high level as did their older brother Ben who now works as a coach.\n\nHis thoughts on his Olympic chances:\n\n\"Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, what is it 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine, especially.\"\n\nDaniel Wiffen will compete in the 1,500m Freestyle and Open Water 10km in Paris.\n\nGet {"uri": "8251428056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:32:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:32:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:31:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/07/30/daniel-wiffen-becomes-first-irishman-to-win-olympic-swim-medal-after-800m-freestyle-victory/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen becomes first Irishman to win Olympic swim medal after 800m freestyle victory | Meath Chronicle", "body": "Daniel Wiffen becomes first Irishman to win Olympic swim medal after 800m freestyle victory RSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 30 Jul 2024, 9:31 PM Last updated: Tue 30 Jul 2024, 11:28 PM\n\nAlan Baldwin, Reuters\n\nDaniel Wiffen became the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming medal when he struck gold with a thrilling 800 metres freestyle victory at the Paris Games on Tuesday.\n\nWith his twin brother watching in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in an Olympic record time of seven minutes 38.19 seconds to secure Ireland's first gold of the Games.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Bobby Finke of the United States took the silver, 0.56 behind, and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri the bronze.\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also the North's first gold medallist in 36 years.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350 metres, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off.\n\nWiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Armagh man, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first.\n\nHe turned around in triumph, putting his hands to his head before raising his fists to salute the crowd - with a vocal Irish contingent - at the La Defense Arena.\n\nWiffen won 800 and 1,500 gold at the world championships in Doha in February.\n\nTokyo 2020 marked the return of the men's event for the first time since 1904 and Wiffen missed out on the final, but he laid down a marker in Paris with the fastest qualifying time in Monday's heats.\n\nWiffen said: \"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down - I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\"\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Tue 30 Jul 2024, 9:31 PM Last updated: Tue 30 Jul 2024, 11:28 {"uri": "8251380924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:39:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:39:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:38:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/daniel-wiffen-eyeing-more-glory-33362634", "title": "Daniel Wiffen eyeing more glory after overcoming mistakes to win Olympic gold", "body": "Daniel Wiffen is living the dream after taking gold last night in Paris. Now he wants more.\n\nIt capped a remarkable few days for his home county after Armagh's All-Ireland success last Sunday.\n\n\"I mean what can we say we're All-Ireland champions and Olympic gold medalists, what a great county!\" said Wiffen.\n\nRead More: Wiffen credits twin brother for triumph as tears come for swimming sensation\n\nRead More: Daniel Wiffen strikes gold as the Terminator in his greatest performance yet\n\nThe 23-year-old is already targeting another medal in the 1500m later this week.\n\nBut first he will savour being the new Olympic 800m champion after holding off American Bobby Finke and Gregorio Paltrinieri in a new Olympic record of 7:38:19.\n\n\"This is going to sound really weird to say but I've dreamed of this moment so many times in my head, I've gone over it so many different ways about how it was going to happen,\" he said.\n\n\"To be fair, in my eyes, I didn't really think I was going to do it in the 800m because it's not my favourite event.\n\n\"My favourite event is the longer distance stuff. The 800m is obviously quite a new event in the Olympics.\n\n\"But obviously I'm an 800m Olympic champion, it definitely feels great and exceeded my expectations.\"\n\nHe shed a tear on the podium as the tricolour went up and the national anthem rang out around the La D\u00e9fense Arena.\n\nWiffen admitted he started the race poorly and it was halfway before he edged in front.\n\nPaltrinieri fought back over the last 400 and the Italian was just ahead at the final turn, but he had burned himself out.\n\nThen it was Wiffen time.\n\n\"Really my first 300m was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place,\" said Wiffen.\n\n\"I was just so nervous that I couldn't get any stroke in. But luckily I had a good enough easy speed to keep it going, I was still in the race.\n\n\"And then, my goal was to keep building, keep building, keep building.\"\n\nDefending champion Bobby Finke was able to reel in Paltrinieri in the final metres, but he couldn't get near Wiffen.\n\n\"I was literally looking at Bobby Finke. That's all I was doing,\" he said.\n\n\"I was doing this weird lopy stroke to try to have a look. Went on the turn last wall turn, put my head down and sprinted last 20.\"\n\nHe wasn't to be denied, reaching the wall first, 0.56 seconds ahead of Finke.\n\nWiffen goes in search of more glory in the 1500m freestyle later in the week -- his favoured event -- and he's already eyeing another gold.\n\n\"Yeah 1500m on Saturday. My goal is obviously to be back on the podium again,\" he said.\n\n\"I'll get the recovery in, I will enjoy myself tonight, I will try to treat myself to whatever they have in the Village -- I don't know what they have -- and we'll see what happens in the 1500.\"\n\nGet the latest sports headlines straight to your inbox by signing up for free email alerts.", "source": {"uri": "irishmirror.ie", {"uri": "8251479741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:37:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:37:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T23:36:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/daniel-wiffen-6-2-6451025-Jul2024/", "title": "'Can I do this?' - Wiffen beats the nerves and then the world", "body": "Daniel Wiffen explains how he conquered some rare unease to set a new Olympic record and win gold. Gavin Cooney The 42, reports from La Defense Arena, Paris\n\nThe 42 Editor's note: This article by Gavin Cooney forms part of The 42's subscriber-only coverage of the Paris 2024 Olympics, with unique insights and fresh perspectives on the biggest stories every single day. If you'd enjoy more great sportswriting like this, you can sign up here for a free one-month trial to The 42.\n\nTHE REVELATION OF the night was perhaps less the gold medal or the Olympic Record but that Daniel Wiffen was nervous.\n\nThe man who once went to a sports psychologist to be told he didn't need a sports psychologist woke up this morning feeling a tiny pinprick of doubt.\n\n\"I know that I seem very confident on the outside\" he said, \"but there's always a little percentage of you thinking, 'Can I do this?'\"\n\n800 metres is not quite his favourite distance. No, that's the 1500m. For any other swimmer, the longer the exposure to Daniel Wiffen, the greater the pain.\n\nBut the 800m? Perhaps it wasn't quite long enough. Perhaps one, two, or even three of the world's best swimmers were sufficiently fortified to survive seven-odd minutes looking directly into the sun.\n\nBut Wiffen tackled his nerves as best he could. He went to work. He went for a quick session in the pool and told John Rudd of Swim Ireland that he wanted to hit 1:02. He clocked 1:01.01.\n\n\"It's done,\" Wiffen told Rudd. \"We've won.\"\n\nWiffen was last to swagger out for the race, status earned by going fastest in the heats. He was also given the central lane four, from which he could keep a darting eye on his two main rivals, America's Bobby Finke and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri.\n\nLook at the casual swing of those long, limby arms: it's hard to believe the force with which they pull him through the water. They could haul down statues.\n\nBut it seems not all the nerves were gone. He said afterwards that his first 300 metres were \"absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place.\"\n\nTo the rest of us it looked like a standard teeth-clenched tussle for an Olympic gold medal.\n\nAs he did in Wiffen's semi-final, Australia's Elijah Winnington went out fast, and lead for the first half of the race. Wiffen found his rhythm at the 300m mark, and Winnington would soon vacate the premises. He ceased being relevant from 400 metres. He allegedly finished last.\n\nNow was time for Wiffen to worry about Finke and Paltrinieri to his immediate left in lane three.\n\n\"My goal was to keep building, keep building, keep building.\"\n\nBut he couldn't shake Palrinieri.\n\nThe splits were winnowing with every fifty metres.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWiffen's 0.47 second lead at 500 metres became 0.06. Then 0.01. Then they jacknifed. Wiffen was second, 0.57 seconds behind. It got worse. With 100 metres to go, he trailed by 0.78 seconds.\n\nBut then came the recovery. Paltrinieri had made his investment in a subprime mortgage, because soon he was about to be bankrupt. He led Wiffen by a tenth of a second as they hit the wall for the final 50 metres, but then the Italian fell. He managed to hold on for a bronze medal.\n\nBut the final boss wasn't done.\n\n\"I was literally looking at Bobby Finke. That's all I was doing. I was like, 'this guy comes about the fastest, well, not the fastest any more.\"\n\nWiffen's glance at Finke cost him what he described as a \"lopey stroke\", but he quickly ratcheted it tight. Sprint.\n\n\"I was dying last 20 metres and I'm not sure if you saw that. Because my arms were in so much pain.\n\n\"But I knew that the crowd was gonna carry me in, and that's exactly what happened.\"\n\nWiffen at the moment of triumph. James Crombie / INPHO James Crombie / INPHO / INPHO\n\nHe hit the wall in 7:38.19, a new Olympic record. The Olympic record he promised on Monday night. That Finke and Paltrinieri both finished within the old record time accentuated what Wiffen had just done. They both brought the best they had and it still wasn't enough.\n\nWiffen climbed out of the pool and pumped his arms with a confident kind of steadiness. He said the only voice in the crowd he heard was his twin brother's. He returned 35 minutes later in his tracksuit, stood atop the podium, and let a few tears roll down his cheek as Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann rang around the arena and the Irish flag began its slow, slow, gorgeously slow ascent in front of him.\n\nThe crowning that awaits all great Irish athletes is to be known nationwide by their first name. Sonia, Kellie, Katie, Roy, Jack, Johnny, Ruby...Mona.\n\nWiffen might be the first to become a verb.\n\nWiffen (verb): to execute brilliantly and in so doing have all your thoughts about your brilliance confirmed.\n\nFind a car parking spot right outside the supermarket on a busy Friday evening? You've Wiffened it.\n\nJump through the Dart doors as they are closing? You've Wiffened it.\n\nFix that leaky tap without calling a plumber? You've Wiffened it.\n\n\"There's a whole saying going around of getting Finked,\" Wiffen told RT\u00c9.\n\nNot anymore. This was the night a whole sport shifted, and a country couldn't quite believe it was finally tilting towards us.\n\nWritten by Gavin Cooney and originally published on The 42 whose award-winning team produces original content that you won't find anywhere else: on GAA, League of Ireland, women's sport and boxing, as well as our game-changing rugby coverage, all with an Irish eye. mark.\n\nElijah Winnington of Australia was out in front early on and turned at the 200m just one second under the world record mark, as Wiffen moved from fourth place into third.\n\n250 metres in, Wiffen was in second place as he chased down Winnington, who remained just out in front 300 metres in.\n\nWiffen took over and grabbed the lead at the halfway point as he looked strong in the water {"uri": "2024-07-438793164", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:25:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.sunherald.com/sports/olympics/article290588964.html", "title": "Great Britain defends 4x200 gold, Daniel Wiffen (Ireland) edges Bobby Finke", "body": "PARIS -- Great Britain retained their men's 4x200 meter freestyle relay gold medal at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday, fending off a dogged challenge by the United States at La Defense Arena.\n\nAustralia took the bronze.\n\nThe British quartet of James Guy, Tom Dean, Matthew Richards and Duncan Scott clocked 6:59.43, edging the Americans by 1.35 seconds.\n\n--American Bobby Finke touched half a second after Ireland's Daniel Wiffen, who claimed the gold medal in the 800-meter freestyle with an Olympic record time on Tuesday.\n\nDaniel Wiffen wiped tears from his eyes on the podium after becoming the first Irishman to win Olympic swimming gold, and a medal of any color, with a thrilling 800.\n\nWith his twin brother shouting in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in seven minutes, 38.19 seconds to set a new Olympic record and secure Ireland's first gold of the Games.\n\nFinke, the reigning Olympic champion in the event, was officially 0.56 behind on the wall touch with Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri in third place to claim the bronze.\n\n\"Amazing... 'What's my name? Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion,'\" he told Ireland's RTE television. \"It's really good. I can't believe it.\"\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also Northern Ireland's first gold medalist in 36 years.\n\n\"I mean, I'm not going to lie, I did tell everybody already I was going to do it before. {"uri": "8251624124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "02:42:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T02:42:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T02:41:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.irishcentral.com/news/daniel-wiffen-gold-ireland", "title": "Team Ireland wins its first Gold medal at 2024 Paris Olympics", "body": "Daniel Wiffen swam his way to clinch Team Ireland's first Gold medal of the Paris 2024 Olympics in the 800m Freestyle on Tuesday, July 30.\n\nWiffen's Gold medal is Ireland's first Olympic medal in any men's swimming event ever.\n\nNot only did Armagh native Wiffen win Gold with his finishing time of 7:38:19, he set a new personal best, national record, and European record by a full second in the process.\n\nWiffen's medal-winning swim also set a new Olympic record, knocking over three seconds off the previous one of 7:41:28 set by Mykhalo Romanchuk of Ukraine in Tokyo 2020.\n\nSilver medallist Bobby Finke of the US finished just behind the Irish swimmer at 7:38:35, while Bronze medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri of Italy finished at 7:39:38.\n\nWiffen's Gold medal is Team Ireland's second medal so far at the Paris 2024 Olympics; it comes the day after Sligo swimmer Mona McSharry won Bronze in the 100m Breaststroke final on Monday night.\n\n23-year-old Wiffen is also set to compete in 1500m Freestyle, which heats begin on Saturday, and intends to compete in the Open Water 10km.\n\nSpeaking to RT\u00c9 Sport after clinching the Gold medal, Wiffen - still out of breath - took great delight in being referred to as the 'Olympic champion.'\n\n\"It's really good, I can't believe it,\" Wiffen said, before thanking his twin brother Nathan, as well as his parents, coaching staff, and Team Ireland.\n\n\"I couldn't have done it without anybody,\" he said. \"I'm not alone out there. It was such a good effort.\"\n\nReflecting on his Gold medal-winning swim, Wiffen said: \"I'm not gonna lie, I was looking for Bobby Finke the whole time... I was 'I can't get caught last 50m. I've been training all f---ing year for this. I will not get caught last 50!'\n\n\"I kept looking over and looking over and I saw I got by him and I knew it was over, I had won,\" he added, before reflecting on an Olympic record.\n\n\"Pretty crazy. Another title in the book. Now I can say I am one of the best ever.\"\n\nWiffen was moved to tears when Ireland's national anthem \"Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann\" was played in La Defense Arena.\n\nIt marked only the 12th time the Irish anthem was played during an Olympic medal ceremony.\n\n\"I ain't much of a crier, I shed a lot of tears there,\" Wiffen admitted to RT\u00c9 Sport.\n\n\"You never really see me cry, so it's a big achievement for that!\n\n\"It's amazing, I love hearing the national anthem,\" he said.\n\n\"I think I've heard it more times in my life now than a lot of people. This is my sixth time this season hearing it, so it's kind of crazy. I'm just so happy.\"\n\nLike his teammate Mona McSharry on Monday, Wiffen was met with a wave of congratulations on Tuesday after securing the Gold medal.\n\nPresident of Ireland Michael D. Higgins extended his congratulations, while Tansite Micheal Martin deemed Wiffen's swim as \"outstanding\" and \"breathtaking.\"\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris sent \"absolute admiration and congratulations\" to Wiffen on behalf of all of Ireland, while First Minister of Northern Ireland Michelle O'Neill commended Wiffen for his history making swim.\n\nOf course, Wiffen's biggest fans might be his parents Rachel and Jonathan who were in attendance - donning green Ireland t-shirts - to watch their son swim to glory.\n\n\"Absolutely electric, it's just brilliant,\" a beaming Rachel {"uri": "8251388448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:47:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:47:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:46:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.independent.ie/sport/olympics/it-was-just-written-in-the-stars-daniel-wiffen-basks-in-olympic-golden-glory-after-absolutely-terrible-first-300m/a14640804.html", "title": "'It was just written in the stars' - Daniel Wiffen basks in Olympic golden glory after 'absolutely terrible first 300m'", "body": "Daniel Wiffen dreamed of this moment all his life. Standing at the top of the podium and having an Olympic gold medal around his neck.\n\nThe twist is he didn't think it would happen in the 800m freestyle but in his preferred longer distance of 1500m. Even Wiffen has the capacity to surprise himself.\n\nBut this is a man who also keeps living up to his own billing. He came to Paris to win gold, never shied away from telling anyone and he backed up those words in the most glorious way inside the La D\u00e9fense Arena as he set a new Olympic record of 7:38.19 to win the 800m freestyle. It is, indeed, Wiffen time.\n\n\"It's going to be really weird to say but I dreamt of this moment so many times in my head. I've gone over it in so many different ways about what's going to happen. To be fair in my eyes I didn't really think I was going to do it in the 800m because it's not my favourite event,\" Wiffen said after with the gold medal around his neck.\n\n\"My favourite event is the longer distance. And the 800m is obviously a new event but obviously I'm an 800m Olympic champion and it definitely feels great.\"\n\nA gold medal in his first ever Olympic final, this is the Wiffen way. For his walkout, he did the action of writing his name into the history books. He was still playing the showman. But he was nervous, he wasn't as calmed as he looked.\n\n\"Uh, definitely not. The only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's. I think that's what actually kept me level-headed when I walked out,\" he said.\n\n\"And, yeah, it was just written in the stars. I said before here it was Bastille day on my birthday, 100 years since Ireland competed, there was also a storm tonight at 9pm. I said to my coach Steve (Beckerleg, national centre Dublin coach), I was like, oh yeah, we're renaming our storm Storm Daniel.\"\n\nIt was a fascinating race. Wiffen took-over the lead from Australia's Elijah Winnington at the half-way point for the first time in the race.\n\nThen Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri - in lane three next to him - took charge and Wiffen just sat on him. It was all building up to the last 50m and then is when Wiffen emptied himself into a finishing kick.\n\nTokyo gold medallist Bobby Finke took silver with Paltrinieri in third. In Wiffen's assessment, it was far from the perfect race.\n\n\"So I had been training every different scenario that is going to happen. Normally I would only train one way and that's to try to hold on, burn everybody out in the middle, but I knew that the Olympics is completely different and you don't know how you are going to feel in the first 100m,\" he said.\n\n\"Really my first 300m was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place. I was just so nervous that I couldn't get any stroke in. But luckily I had a good enough easy speed to keep it going, I was still in the race.\n\n\"And then, my goal was to keep building, keep building, keep building. Got to the 150m in my head, it went so fast so that was lucky.\n\n\"And then I was literally looking at Bobby Finke, that's all I was doing. I was like, this guy comes back the fastest, well, not the fastest anymore. He comes back the fastest.\n\n\"I was like we need to have at least a body length on him. I was doing this weird loopy stroke to try to have a look. Went on the last wall turn, put my head down and sprinted the last 20.\n\n\"I was dying the last 20m and I'm not sure if you saw that because my arms were in so much pain. But I knew that the crowd was going to carry me in and that's exactly what happened. I saw the red light on the block and then that was it.\"\n\nThe double world champion has another job to come in these Olympics in the pool. He's back for the 1,500m heats on Saturday with the final on Sunday. This is his favoured event. And boy, is he just getting started.\n\n\"This is 100 per cent not the end. I'm only 23. Peak age for my event is 27, but you saw Paltrinieri there in the last 100m and he's like 29. Who knows what's going to happen in the future, but I'm very happy today to say that I'm Olympic champion,\" he said.\n\n\"Yeah, 1500m on Saturday. My goal is to obviously be back on the podium again and my goal now is just to get the recovery in. I will enjoy myself tonight.\n\n\"I will try to treat myself to maybe whatever they have in the village, I don't know all that. We'll see what happens in the 1500m, just get through the heats and see what happens.\"\n\nIt's Wiffen's time indeed and he's not done yet in the City of Light.", "source": {"uri": "independent.ie", Tuesday.\n\nThe 23-year-old hit the wall in 7min 38.19sec, the fifth-fastest time ever, ahead of American defending champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) and Tokyo silver medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri (7:39.38) of Italy.\n\nWorld champion Wiffen took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired as the Irishman reeled him in.\n\nPaltrinieri made at a move at 600m and led to the final turn before Wiffen came roaring back to make history for his nation.\n\nThe only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic pool came at Atlanta in 1996 when Michelle Smith collected {"uri": "2024-07-438847831", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:09:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:09:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:03:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/2024olympics/daniel-wiffen-of-ireland-wins-olympic-gold-and-also-hopes-to-pick-up-some-new/article_1c96000d-3dbc-5685-ab0c-9805f58abd7e.html", "title": "Daniel Wiffen of Ireland wins Olympic gold and also hopes to pick up some new YouTube followers", "body": "NANTERRE, France (AP) -- Daniel Wiffen won Ireland's first Olympic gold medal in the pool in 28 years. That was thrilling enough as he wiped away tears standing on the podium, the Irish flag draped over his shoulders.\n\nPerhaps just as importantly, the 23-year-old Irishman is sure to pick up some new followers on his YouTube channel -- a pitch he made when asked how people can learn more about a swimmer who is largely unknown outside his country.\n\n\"People should watch,\" Wiffen said after winning the 800-meter freestyle on Tuesday night. \"I blog every week -- show you exactly what an Olympic champion does day-in, day-out in the pool.\"\n\nGet ready for a flood of fans, Daniel.\n\nWearing round glasses and looking studious, Wiffen cried as the Irish anthem played in La Defense Arena. He may not look the part of an Olympic champion, but his performance in the pool says otherwise.\n\nWiffen will be back later in the Paris Games, hoping to win another gold on Sunday in the 1,500 meters -- the final day of competition in the pool.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope nobody is going to see that,\" Wiffen said. \"But it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment. I've never heard that national anthem from an Olympics before.\"\n\nWiffen surged past Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri on the final lap, looking as fresh as he did at the beginning of the grueling race. He won in 7 minutes, 38.19 seconds, overpowering defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) of the United States and Paltrinieri (7:39.38).\n\nMona McSharry won bronze for Ireland's first medal of these Games on the previous night in the 100 breaststroke.\n\n\"I was dying the last 20 meters,\" Wiffen said. \"I'm not sure if you saw that, because my arms are in absolutely so much pain. But I knew that the crowd is gonna carry me in, and that's exactly what happened. Then I saw the red light on the block, and that was it.\"\n\nUntil these Olympics, Ireland's swimming history was essentially confined to Michelle Smith de Bruin, who surprisingly claimed three golds and a bronze at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics amid suspicions she was doping.\n\nShe later received a drug ban that essentially ended her career, but she kept her medals.\n\nWiffen was not asked about Smith de Bruin as he huddled with reporters, primarily Irish who were not looking to spoil a special night.\n\n\"To be honest -- it's going to sound really weird to say -- I've dreamt of this moment so many times in my head, I've gone over it so many different ways of how it was going to happen,\" he said. \"But to be fair, I didn't think I was going to do it in the 800 because it wasn't my favorite. I prefer the longer distance.\"\n\nSo, get ready for his shot at another Irish medal on Sunday -- and more tears.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "8251268994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:02:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:02:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:01:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/daniel-wiffen-strikes-gold-terminator-33362145", "title": "Daniel Wiffen strikes gold as the Terminator in his greatest performance yet", "body": "He talks the talk and he walks the walk. Better than that, he swims the swim on the greatest of all stages.\n\nDaniel Wiffen, ladies and gentlemen. Ireland's first Paris 2024 gold medalist.\n\nWiffen became Ireland's first ever male Olympic pool finalist on Monday. He is now Ireland's first ever male Olympic gold medal winner, reaching and touching first in a dramatic 800m Freestyle final at the La Defense Arena.\n\nREAD MORE: Mona McSharry targets more Olympic glory on back of landing first Irish medal\n\nREAD MORE: Meet Daniel Wiffen, the Magheralin world champion with Olympic dreams, a twin brother and Game of Thrones past\n\nHe told us that he would break the Olympic record in the final, then went ahead and did it, taking the lead at halfway then losing it with 200m to go, only to regain it again from the Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri.\n\nIt wasn't over. The reigning champion, Bobby Finke of the USA, has a fast finish and found a late surge.\n\nBut Wiffen has been like the Terminator in this raucous arena, reeling in his rivals and eliminating them mercilessly. There was only going to be one winner as the block surged into view.\n\nAmidst the roars of acclaim that followed the 6'3\" Magheralin machine eventually - calmly - emerged from the water, then declared himself as one of the best ever in the sport before he shed a tear as he stood on the podium and the national anthem played.\n\nThen, after posing for photos with the tricolour wrapped around him, he joyously greeted his family before a quick lap of honour.\n\nHas Ireland ever had an athlete like Daniel Wiffen? We are not used to our Olympic hopefuls bigging themselves up the way this 23-year-old does.\n\nIt makes us a bit uncomfortable, yet there's nothing unnatural about his declarations and pronouncements. Wiffen has backed them up, using his World Championship fourth place a year ago as fuel to become a double Worlds champion in December.\n\nThat's just not how Irish people are built and yet it's how Wiffen is built. His progression since the Tokyo Games, when he made his Olympic debut, has been astonishing in terms of lopping great chunks of national records and yet he made his improvements on a consistent level.\n\nHe is just different, from that appearance with his twin brother Nathan in the famous Red Wedding episode of Game of Thrones to breaking records that Irish swimmers have never before threatened.\n\nGo back to December 2022 and the Irish Winter Championships at the Aquatic Centre in Blanchardstown.\n\nWiffen, whose main focus was the 1500m Freestyle, broke the European short course 800m record. In doing so, he broke through the glass ceiling as the first Irish swimmer to hold a European record.\n\nA few days shy of a year later, the Loughborough student broke the longest standing World short course record and Aussie Grant Hackett congratulated him for swiping him off the top spot. All of it was building to this moment.\n\nAround La Defense Arena there are no whispers of anything amiss in what he is doing. \"I would like to say that I'm probably one of the most-tested athletes in the world right now,\" declared Wiffen earlier this month.\n\n\"I'm not really surprised when you have the results that I've had and the time progressions. I hope everybody gets tested the same as I do. I'd like to say that's the case, but I don't know.\"\n\nHe's not done in Paris, either, with the 1500m and Open Water race to come. {"uri": "8251297915", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:37:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:37:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:26:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13690341/Olympics-Swimming-Wiffen-takes-mens-800-freestyle-gold-Irish-first.html", "title": "Olympics-Swimming-Wiffen takes men's 800 freestyle gold in Irish first", "body": "By Alan Baldwin\n\nPARIS, July 30 (Reuters) - Daniel Wiffen became the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming medal when he struck gold with a thrilling 800 metres freestyle victory at the Paris Games on Tuesday.\n\nWith his twin brother watching in the crowd, the 23-year-old world champion touched out in an Olympic record time of seven minutes 38.19 seconds to secure Ireland's first gold of the Games.\n\nReigning Olympic champion Bobby Finke of the United States took the silver, 0.56 behind, and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri the bronze.\n\nThe only other Irish swimmer to win an Olympic swimming title was women's triple champion Michelle Smith in 1996, and Wiffen was also Northern Ireland's first gold medallist in 36 years.\n\nElijah Winnington led for the first 350 metres, with Wiffen easing into second place only at 250, but the Australian faded and the battle between the top three took off.\n\nWiffen led at the halfway point with Finke second but Paltrinieri took the lead at 650 and stayed there until the final 50.\n\nThe Irishman, who had appeared to be spent, then turned on the afterburners and blasted down the final length to touch the wall first.\n\nHe turned around in triumph, putting his hands to his head before raising his fists to salute the crowd -- with a vocal Irish contingent -- at the La Defense Arena.\n\nWiffen won 800 and 1,500 gold at the world championships in Doha in February. {"uri": "8251729698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "04:33:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T04:33:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T04:29:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-daniel-wiffen-of-ireland-wins-olympic-gold-and-also-hopes-to-pick-up-some-new-youtube-followers-6151290.html", "title": "Sports News | Daniel Wiffen of Ireland Wins Olympic Gold and Also Hopes to Pick Up Some New YouTube Followers | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Daniel Wiffen won Ireland's first Olympic gold medal in the pool in 28 years. That was thrilling enough as he wiped away tears standing on the podium, the Irish flag draped over his shoulders.\n\nNanterre, France, Jul 31 (AP) Daniel Wiffen won Ireland's first Olympic gold medal in the pool in 28 years. That was thrilling enough as he wiped away tears standing on the podium, the Irish flag draped over his shoulders.\n\nPerhaps just as importantly, the 23-year-old Irishman is sure to pick up some new followers on his YouTube channel -- a pitch he made when asked how people can learn more about a swimmer who is largely unknown outside his country.\n\nAlso Read | Paris Olympics 2024: Olympic Triathletes Will Swim in France's Seine River After Days of Concerns About Water Quality.\n\n\"People should watch,\" Wiffen said after winning the 800-meter freestyle on Tuesday night.\n\n\"I blog every week -- show you exactly what an Olympic champion does day-in, day-out in the pool.\"\n\nAlso Read | ISL 2024-25: Mumbai City FC Announce Contract Extension of Syrian Defender Thaer Krouma Till 2025 Season.\n\nGet ready for a flood of fans, Daniel.\n\nWearing round glasses and looking studious, Wiffen cried as the Irish anthem played in La Defense Arena. He may not look the part of an Olympic champion, but his performance in the pool says otherwise.\n\nWiffen will be back later in the Paris Games, hoping to win another gold on Sunday in the 1,500 meters -- the final day of competition in the pool.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope nobody is going to see that,\" Wiffen said.\n\n\"But it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment. I've never heard that national anthem from an Olympics before.\"\n\nWiffen surged past Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri on the final lap, looking as fresh as he did at the beginning of the grueling race. He won in 7 minutes, 38.19 seconds, overpowering defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) of the United States and Paltrinieri (7:39.38).\n\nMona McSharry won bronze for Ireland's first medal of these Games on the previous night in the 100 breaststroke.\n\n\"I was dying the last 20 meters,\" Wiffen said.\n\n\"I'm not sure if you saw that, because my arms are in absolutely so much pain. But I knew that the crowd is gonna carry me in, and that's exactly what happened. Then I saw the red light on the block, and that was it.\"\n\nUntil these Olympics, Ireland's swimming history was essentially confined to Michelle Smith de Bruin, who surprisingly claimed three golds and a bronze at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics amid suspicions she was doping.\n\nShe later received a drug ban that essentially ended her career, but she kept her medals.\n\nWiffen was not asked about Smith de Bruin as he huddled with reporters, primarily Irish who were not looking to spoil a special night.\n\n\"To be honest -- it's going to sound really weird to say -- I've dreamt of this moment so many times in my head, I've gone over it so many different ways of how it was going to happen,\" he said.\n\n\"But to be fair, I didn't think I was going to do it in the 800 because it wasn't my favorite. I prefer the longer distance.\"\n\nSo, get ready for his shot at another Irish medal on Sunday -- and more tears. Mandatory Credit: Grace Hollars-USA TODAY Sports\n\nSwimming events at the Paris Olympics have been witnessing intense competition and remarkable achievements among various nations. With athletes vying for glory in multiple categories, there's ample opportunity for redemption and rewards.\n\nIreland, facing stiff competition from powerhouses like the US, Australia, and Italy, found its champion in Daniel Wiffen for the 800m freestyle event. The 23-year-old swimmer, still early in his career, has already made a significant impact.\n\nIn the Men's 800m Freestyle finals at the Paris Olympics, Wiffen surged through the grueling race to claim victory. He not only secured gold for Ireland, creating history for his country but also shattered the Olympic record for the event.\n\nClocking an impressive time of 7:38.19, Wiffen celebrated his monumental win with a triumphant pose, symbolizing his dominance in the pool. While he may achieve more accolades in Paris, Wiffen's accomplishments extend beyond the swimming arena, marking him as a noteworthy figure in Irish sports.\n\nBorn in Leeds, UK, Wiffen has a twin brother, Nathan, who is also a swimmer. Nathan specializes in the 1500m freestyle category, and the brothers aspire to make waves together in the future.\n\nThe 23-year-old has participated in several national and international competitions, including the World Championships, European Championships, and the Commonwealth Games.\n\nThroughout his career as an elite swimmer, he has made a significant impact across the nation. However, Daniel Wiffen initially rose to fame for a different reason, long before swimming became a crucial part of his life.\n\nAs a pre-teen, Wiffen had a brief brush with the entertainment industry, appearing as an extra on HBO's popular fantasy series 'Game of Thrones'. While this early experience with stardom was fleeting, it foreshadowed the greater acclaim he would achieve in the world of competitive swimming.\n\nWiffen's true claim to fame came years later when he secured an Olympic gold medal and set an Olympic record, cementing his place in sports history.\n\nCurrently training at Loughborough University in England under the guidance of their Director of Swimming, Wiffen has his sights set on other events at the Paris Olympics. With expert coaching and a proven track record, expectations are high for his future performances.\n\nThe Irish swimmer, who finds his greatest support in his twin brother, is now focusing on the 1500m freestyle event. {"uri": "8251318912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:44:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:44:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:43:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.balls.ie/olympics/who-is-daniel-wiffen-this-is-irelands-new-olympic-superstar-606249", "title": "Who Is Daniel Wiffen? - Meet Ireland's Olympic Superstar | Balls.ie", "body": "Mona McSharry has kicked off team Ireland's medal haul in the pool with a fantastic performance in last night's 100m breaststroke final to claim bronze and Down native Daniel Wiffen has followed that up with a gold medal performance and a new Olympics record in tonight's 800m freestyle final.\n\nThe 23-year-old made the Irish team for Tokyo 2020, where he was one of eight on the nine-strong Irish Olympic Swimming roster making his Olympic debut. He won his heat in 7:51.65, which was good enough to place him 14th overall but unfortunately not enough to make the final.\n\nBut he's been a different animal since then, to qualify for tonight's final, Wiffen won his heat with an impressive time of 7:41:53 to book his place in the 800m freestyle final. The Irish athlete set the fastest time across all four heats, in his heat, the Australian duo of Elijah Winnington and Sam Short raced into the lead only for Wiffen to hunt them down.\n\nMagheralin is Daniel's home, a small village between Moira and Lurgan on the border between Down and Armagh. Though their home is in Armagh, the nearest GAA club St Michael's, who Daniel played for at underage level, is affiliated to the Down County Board.\n\nA sibling rivalry with his twin Nathan has helped push Wiffen to such great heights that has seen him recognised worldwide as a swimming superstar.\n\nEach week the twins spend a combined 50 hours plus in the pool and gym and believe that skills gained now, such as time management and discipline, will last them a lifetime.\n\nBoth are currently studying computer science degrees at Loughborough University in Leicestershire, England.\n\nAside from being a champion swimmer, Wiffen also has the distinction of featuring in one of the most popular TV shows of all time, Game of Thrones.\n\nThe hit TV series was partly filmed in Belfast, with Wiffen and his twin brother having the opportunity to appear as extras in one of the series' most memorable episodes, the infamous Red Wedding.\n\nThe 7:39.19 he set when finishing fourth in last
