{"uri": "8251536821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "00:48:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T00:48:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:47:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://time.com/7005699/daniel-wiffen-ireland-paris-olympics-gold-800-free/", "title": "Ireland Has Its Own Olympics Hero Who Wears Glasses", "body": "The morning that Irish swimming star Daniel Wiffen won his country's first-ever men's Olympic swimming gold medal started out in typical fashion. He woke up, ate breakfast, and went for a swim. But in the hours before his 800-m freestyle final at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday, butterflies -- or something like it -- started to set in.\n\n\"The only difference from a normal day is that I was like, sh-tting myself, honestly,\" said Wiffen after his thrilling victory at La D\u00e9fense Arena in Nanterre, France on Tuesday night. \"I've never been this nervous.\"\n\nWiffen fought off the jitters to hold on to victory, setting a new Olympic record in the event with a time of 7 minutes, 38.19 seconds. (Finally, there was some kind of record in the pool, whose shallow depth has been the subject of consternation for creating waves that may be slowing swimmers down). American Bobby Finke, the defending Olympic champ, made his typical charge in the last 50 m -- Finke is known for his finishing speed -- but Wiffen touched the wall first, barely: Finke finished with a time of 7 minutes, 38.75 seconds, just .56 seconds behind the winner.\n\nTo Wiffen, the stars were aligned for victory. His birthday, he noted after the race, is July 14 -- the same as Bastille Day. He noticed there was a storm outside the arena at 9 p.m,, a few minutes before the start of his race. \"We're renaming that storm 'Storm Daniel,'\" Wiffen told his coach.\n\nIreland is reveling in its Paris aquatic moment. Going into the men's 800 free, the country has just three swimming gold medals in its history; they were all won by Michelle Smith at the 1996 Games. Irish officials and fans were already buzzing around town thanks to the bronze won on Monday by Mona McSharry, in the women's 100-m breaststroke.\n\nWith Wiffen's win, Paris should expect even more Irish energy these next few nights. A fair number of green-clad fans have descended upon Paris. \"It's as close as we'll get to a home Games, outside of London,\" says Trish Mayon, Ireland's press attach\u00e9 for swimming.\n\nTeam USA has done less celebrating than usual at these Games. After winning a gold in the men's 4x100 freestyle relay on Saturday, and Torri Huske's 100-m butterfly victory on Sunday, the Americans have gone without first place hardware the past two nights. Team USA won three silvers on Tuesday, as Regan Smith, the world-record holder in the 100-m backstroke, finished second to her rival Kaylee McKeown of Australia, who also set an Olympic record with a time of 57.33 seconds. \"Other people's performances are completely out of my control,\" said Smith after the race. \"Kaylee is one of one. She is an absolutely incredible racer, and she knows what to do when it matters. But I'm really proud of myself.\"\n\nIn the last race of the evening, Team Great Britain fended off the United States in the 4x200 freestyle relay. In a post-race press conference, Finke attributed the relative drought to the growth of the sport around the world, and the inevitable improvement in competition that results.\n\nPlus, American swimming fans needn't grow too anxious: Katie Ledecky races in the 1,500-m on Wednesday. She owns history's 19 fastest times in that event.\n\nPlus, Wiffen's worth your cheers. Like overnight U.S. gymnastics sensation Stephen Nedoroscik, he's a nerdy-looking athlete who wears glasses. Isn't that enough to love the guy?\n\nWiffen is known for exuding confidence, which is relatively rare for an Irish athlete, according to journalists at the race. UFC heel Conor McGregor aside.\n\n\"To me, he's the most unique sports person in Ireland there's ever been, because of the way he expresses himself,\" says Michael Foley, a reporter at the Sunday Times of Ireland. \"He's very confident, very brash, not very Irish.\"\n\nBefore Tuesday night, Wiffen's claim to fame was may have been his role as an extra, along with his twin brother Nathan -- also an elite swimmer -- as an extra in the controversial \"Red Wedding\" episode of the HBO hit show Game of Thrones. (Many main characters were killed off in that episode, which aired in 2013). He'd be up for a House of the Dragon role, he says.\n\nIn swimming circles, his YouTube channel -- in which he gives a behind-the-scenes look on what it takes to be an Olympic-level swimmer -- even inspires his competitors. \"Sometimes I use it to motivate me in practice,\" says Finke.\n\nWiffen, who was born in Great Britain but grew up in Northern Ireland, in County Down, expects a warm welcome once he returns home. \"I'm sure it's gonna be massive,\" said Wiffen, when asked about the potential reaction to his win. \"I remember last Olympics, when the rowing boys pulled up with their gold, it was crazy. I mean, we'll see what happens.\" Though he's scheduled to compete in the 1,500-m freestyle, whose heats begin on Aug. 3 -- \"I'm sure there's going to be fireworks,\" he promises -- and the 10K open-water marathon swim on Aug. 9, he said he'd allow himself to celebrate tonight.\n\n\"Half the Irish team is still going to be waiting for me when I get back [to the Olympic village],\" says Wiffen. \"The dining hall has some great chocolate muffins. {"uri": "2024-07-438916871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:42:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:42:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T00:10:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_2551c1b4-64bb-5c63-be9b-7427e498bd10.html", "title": "Tearful Wiffen makes Irish history with Olympic gold", "body": "Daniel Wiffen made history Tuesday as the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming gold medal, shedding tears as the enormity of the achievement sunk in.\n\nThe 23-year-old hit the wall first in 7min 38.19sec, the fifth-fastest time ever, to be crowned 800m freestyle champion in La Defense Arena.\n\nThe only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic pool came at Atlanta in 1996 when Michelle Smith collected three.\n\nWiffen, the first Irish male swimmer to win a medal of any colour, couldn't hide his emotions when the national anthem played as he stood on top of the podium.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope that nobody's gonna see that,\" he said.\n\n\"But, yeah, it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at an Olympics before, and it's just crazy to say that it was me standing on a number one podium here for the first time.\"\n\nWiffen, who also won the 800m at the world championships in Doha this year, came home ahead of American defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) and Tokyo silver medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri (7:39.38) of Italy.\n\nHe took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired and was reeled in.\n\nPaltrinieri made at a move at 600m and led to the final turn before Wiffen came roaring back to rewrite the history books.\n\n\"To be fair, normally I do only train one way and that's just to try hold on, burn everybody out in the middle,\" he said.\n\n\"But I knew I Olympics is completely different. You don't know how you're going to feel in the first 100.\n\n\"So really, my first part of the race was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place, I was just so nervous.\n\n\"But luckily I had a good enough speed to keep it going and I was still in the race. Then my goal was to keep building.\"\n\nWiffen paid tribute to his identical twin brother Nathan, also a distance swimmer who missed out on qualification for Paris, for urging him on.\n\n\"I tell you what, the only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" he said.\n\n\"I've dreamed of this every day of my life.\n\n\"I know that I seem very confident on the outside, but there's {"uri": "8249964866", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "05:09:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T05:09:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T05:08:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/othersport/arid-41446324.html", "title": "Daniel Wiffen prepared and poised to swim into Olympic history", "body": "The wardrobe in Daniel Wiffen's basic college dorm in Loughborough is still decorated with pictures of the Armagh man in the Tokyo Aquatics Centre three years ago. They are reminders of his first experience of the big show, motivations every time he needs a shirt.\n\nHis teenage years had only ended earlier that month. The national records he set in the 800m and 1500m were mere footnotes at the back end of a swim meet where Mona McSharry's achievement in making an actual Olympic final had demanded the attention.\n\nWe talk about shaving fractions of seconds off times in the pool. Wiffen has taken a hacksaw to his - admittedly in a much longer event that lends itself to greater advances - but there is no denying the difference between then and now.\n\nHe has taken over 16 seconds off his 800m freestyle mark since. The 7:39.19 he set when finishing fourth in last year's World Championships in Fukuoka stands as a European record. He's also stripped over 33 seconds from his 1500m freestyle time.\n\nTokyo and Paris? Worlds apart.\n\n\"Completely different,\" he said on Monday shortly after dominating his 800m heat at the La Defense Arena. \"In Tokyo I was just there really [as a qualifier], and just tried to keep progressing. The past three years have been a blast for me.\"\n\nIt's in the 800 on Tuesday night where he will go for gold in what is, lets not forget, his first Olympic final. He made it there by finishing fastest of the 31 swimmers in the heats, his 7:41.53 over half-a-second better than his closest rival.\n\nHis reaction impressed more than the time. The Olympic record, set in Tokyo by Ukraine's Mykhailo Romanchuk, is just 0.25 seconds better. Wiffen emerged from the pool having recorded his third fastest time ever and then proceeded to pick holes in it.\n\nThe message was simple and without conceit: there's more to come. Better.\n\n\"We'll save that for tomorrow night,\" he said of Romanchuk's mark. There is a matter-of-factness about Wiffen that delivers searing honesty without a shred of boastfulness, or its mirror image, false modesty. He says it as he sees it.\n\nJohn Rudd, the high-performance director for Swim Ireland describes a \"binary\" type of character who will tell you what he feels and thinks, someone of boundless confidence whose work ethic has delivered improvements to his technique and his tactics and strategy.\n\n\"If he feels he can win he will tell you he can win,\" said Rudd.\n\nThe Englishman was speaking after Wiffen's 800m and 1500m golds at the 2024 World Championships in Doha at the start of the year. Five of the eight 800m finalists in Doha, Wiffen included, will line up again here.\n\nThat includes the silver and bronze medallists, Elijah Winnington of Australia and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri. Germany's Sven Schwarz came fourth that day and another Italian, Luca De Tullio, came in seventh.\n\nBobby Finke, the American who was marked absent at the Worlds, is the reigning Olympic champion and the 2022 world champion. He recorded the fifth fastest time in the heats on Monday but his PB, 7:38.67, is the best in the field.\n\nThat's just over half-a-second better than Wiffen's. Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri's best is only 0.08 behind that, although his was set five years ago, and there are a few other names notable by their absence this time.\n\nTunisia's Ahmed Hafnaoui, who claimed gold at the 2023 Worlds in Fukuoka, is not in Paris. Australia's Sam Short, who took silver in a race where Wiffen came fourth, failed to make this final having finished one place outside the top eight.\n\nSo, talk of gold and giddiness at the thought of Ireland continuing to flex its muscles in the Olympic pool after years of treading water is valid, but there is no guarantee of that or any other step on the podium at the evening's end.\n\n\"Any medal is good,\" said Wiffen. \"It's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal, so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we've got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine, especially.\"\n\nThat's the 1500m and the 10k open water swim but there won't be any more talk of that until the 800 is come and gone with Wiffen stressing the point that any one of the eight swimmers can do something special here.\n\nHe wasn't just throwing that out there. The 23-year doesn't need a picture of the men's 400m freestyle on his wardrobe. The race, when Hafnaoui stormed to a completely unforeseen gold medal from an outside lane is tattooed in his mind.\n\nThe Tunisian was 18 at the time and 16th in the ranking entering that meet. His gold medal-winning performance made him the lowest-seeded winner in an Olympic pool since Athens in 2004. Wiffen will be keeping tabs on the full pool from his middle lane.\n\n\"I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them,\" he said.\n\nEveryone knows Wiffen now. Medal here and it will be his picture on walls all over the country.", "source": {"uri": "irishexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irish Examiner"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/wiffen-makes-history-olympic-800m-194144148.html", "title": "Wiffen makes history with Olympic 800m freestyle gold", "body": "Daniel Wiffen has become the first athlete from Northern Ireland to win an Olympic gold medal in 36 years in a thrilling 800m freestyle final in Paris.\n\nThe Team Ireland swimmer edged the USA's Bobby Finke to take gold after a stunning burst of pace over the final 50 metres.\n\nThe 23-year-old also set an Olympic record with his blistering finish as he recorded a time of 7:38.19.\n\nThe pockets of support for Wiffen erupted around the La Defense Arena as he secured a first gold medal of the Games for Ireland.\n\nWith his gold medal, he becomes the first athlete from Northern Ireland to triumph since Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood with GB's hockey team in 1988.\n\nIt is also the first individual gold medal since Lady Mary Peters won the pentathlon at the 1972 Games in Munich.\n\nHe also becomes the first Olympian from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold for Ireland and the first Olympian from Team Ireland to win a gold medal in swimming since 1996.\n\nAfter setting the fastest time in the heats on Monday, where he said he had one eye on an Olympic record, he duly delivered in spectacular fashion.\n\nWiffen has now added Olympic gold to his 800m and 1500m triumphs at the World Championships in Doha.\n\nOn a day where the temperature in Paris hit 36 degrees, it was Wiffen who kept his cool in the biggest race of his life.\n\nAfter taking the lead at the midpoint of the race, he slipped to second with 50 metres remaining but dug deep and his finish was worthy of any Olympic medal as he passed Finke in the closing stages to touch the timing beam first.\n\nAfter stating he {"uri": "8248831856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "11:53:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T11:53:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T11:52:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/29/daniel-wiffen-storms-into-800m-final-with-fastest-qualifying-time/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen storms into 800m final with fastest qualifying time", "body": "Armagh swimmer becomes first Irish man to reach an Olympic final and will have a central lane in Tuesday's final\n\nAnother small piece of Irish swimming history for Daniel Wiffen, and the chance now for another golden one to come, with his progression to the men's 800m freestyle final every bit as bold and impressive as he would have liked.\n\nAfter four heats, each of 16 lengths which invariably separates the true medal contenders from the rest, Wiffen's 7:41.53 was the fastest of the lot, just 0.25 of a second off the Olympic record - and giving him a prime lane for the medal showdown.\n\nThe 23-year-old becomes the first Irish male swimmer to make an Olympic final, that set for Tuesday night back inside the Paris La D\u00e9fense Arena (8.02 Irish time), and by Wiffen's own admission here he was only at \"95 per cent\".\n\nThe Armagh swimmer will have defending champion Bobby Finke from the US to contend with, fifth fastest of the qualifiers with his 7:43.00, with Ahmed Jaouadi from Tunisia also laying down a marker with his 7:42.07, the second fastest of the lot.\n\nNo surprise though that Wiffen was talking up his own medal hopes, as he has since he won a double World title in February, in both the 800m and the 1,500m.\n\n\"It's never comfortable, but it wasn't at 100 percent,\" he said, Wiffen taking over the lead from just after the halfway mark, as the Australia duo of Sam Short and Elijah Winnington set the pace.\n\n\"You didn't see my legs come in at the end, but holding a good pace, happy with the morning swim, and a fast time as well.\n\n\"I'm not going in there with 100 percent effort trying to make the final. I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final. I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.\n\nSo what was his effort here?\n\n\"That's a tough one to say, we'll go with 95... but 100 per cent I'm the fittest I've ever been, never been in this shape before in my life.\n\nHe then added: \"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster, I was only 0.25 off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that so that would have been pretty cool to get but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal, so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine [the 10km marathon], especially.\"\n\nAfter Armagh winning the All-Ireland on Sunday, he also feels his stars are aligning.\n\n\"Yeah Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, what is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\"\n\nEarlier, Ellen Walshe produced a brilliant finish to snatch fourth place in her heat of the 400m individual medley, and a spot in that final tonight (7.30 Irish time).\n\nHer time of 4:39.97 seconds placed her seventh overall, the 22-year-old from Dublin just off her best of 4:37.18, with Canada's Summer McIntosh, one of the favourites for the event, winning the heat in 4:37.35\n\nDanielle Hill also touched home in fourth in the women's 100m backstroke, and good enough to see her make the semi-final tonight too (7.57 Irish time).\n\nFor Walshe, who came to Paris ranked 15th, making the final - and joining her roommate Mona McSharry - was indeed most satisfying: \"It's a bit of a shock, I saw fourth on the board and I was like, 'Oh, I don't know', it's just a waiting game,\" she said. \"I hadn't seen the results from the heats before and once I saw it, it was such a relief.\n\n\"And Mona is my roomie, she came back at all hours this morning after recovery and physio and swim down. We had joked about hopefully us all being in the final tonight, I am so glad to join her there. I can go back to the room and we can do the exact same thing tonight. I am super excited.\"\n\nHill will also be back in the pool later on Monday for her 100m backstroke semi-final: \"What an incredible experience, the noise is just deafening, we went from Covid times, to this, so you have to soak it up as well,\" she said.\n\n\"But everything we've been working on is there, and now we've just got to utilise all the stuff I've been working on. We reset, and see it there another gear there. I'm happy to have made the semi-final, still a bit job to do. But very happy with the decision to come back this year.\"\n\nThen it's over to McSharry, who qualified for 100m breaststroke final ranked second fastest overall, and ahead of some of the best event specialists of all time, improving her Irish record to 1:05.51. And no reason whatsoever to stop thinking about that medal chance now - her final is set for 8.25pm Irish time.", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, {"uri": "8251326362", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:50:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:50:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:49:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/storm-daniel-arrives-in-paris-as-wiffen-claims-olympic-gold-YZY66KH6DJAHNMVPBQTXFFFS64/", "title": "'Storm Daniel' arrives in Paris as Wiffen claims Olympic gold", "body": "Armagh swimmer holds off defending champion Bobby Finke to top podium\n\nFirst Sligo's Mona McSharry got Ireland off the mark with a first medal at this Olympics on Monday and, last night, Daniel Wiffen made it a dream couple of days in the pool when claiming a dramatic gold in the 800m freestyle.\n\nThe Armagh ace blazed home in a time of 7:38.19 to bring La Defense Arena to its feet - setting a new Olympic record in the process as well as a new personal best, national record and European record by a full second.\n\nIn a nail-biting finale the 23-year-old beat Tokyo 2020 gold medallist American Bobby Finke into second place, with Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri taking bronze.\n\nComing just a few days after Armagh's All-Ireland win, Wiffen's win capped an unforgettable week for the Orchard County. And he never doubted what was going to happen when he walked into the arena.\n\n\"I'm not going to lie,\" he smiled, \"I did tell everybody already what was going to happen. It's just good to see it on paper.\"\n\n\"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"There was supposed to be a storm tonight at nine o'clock, I said to my coach Steve they'll have to rename that 'Storm Daniel' after the 800's done.\"\n\nAnd yet Wiffen claims nerves hindered him for the first 300m of the race, with the only voice that could calm him before the start the most familiar of all - twin Nathan.\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down? I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\n\n\"It feels incredible. Andrew Bree said it just as I want to say it -'lights, camera, action' - that's exactly what I did - I'm writing myself into the history books!\"\n\nThe term 'Finked' was in reference to the American's renowned fast finishes, but he had no answer as Wiffen turned on the after-burners.\n\n\"It's amazing. What's my name? Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion... it's really good, I can't believe it.\n\n\"I want to thank my brother Nathan, my parents, my whole coaching staff in Loughborough University and Team Ireland. I couldn't have done it without anybody. I'm not alone out there. It was such a good effort.\n\n\"I'm not gonna lie, I was looking for Bobby Finke the whole time... I was 'I can't get caught last 50m. I've been training all f***ing year for this. I will not get caught last 50!\n\n\"I kept looking over and looking over and I saw I got by him and I knew it was over, I had won. Now I can say I am one of the best ever.\"\n\nWiffen has had the most remarkable year having become the first Irish swimmer to ever medal at a World Long Course Championships in February, before becoming double world champion in the 800m and 1500m freestyle, and his 14:34.07 in the latter was the fifth fastest in history.\n\nHe will attempt to add another medal when he competes in the 1500m freestyle heats on Saturday morning, with the final on Sunday evening. Wiffen will be in heat three alongside Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri and Australia's Samuel Short.\n\nHe will then bid to another medal in the 10km marathon swim in the Seine on August 9.", "source": {"uri": "8250246276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "08:34:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T08:34:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T08:32:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/it-seems-everything-is-aligning-daniel-wiffen-feeling-confident-ahead-of-bid-for-historic-olympic-gold/a870708349.html", "title": "'It seems everything is aligning': Daniel Wiffen feeling confident ahead of bid for historic Olympic gold", "body": "The bar was set high for Daniel Wiffen coming to Paris. Being a double World Champion, that was only natural. But in the space of seven minutes, 41.53 seconds on Monday, the 23-year-old sent it a whole lot higher.\n\nWiffen came into the 800m Freestyle as a contender but ahead of the Final, at 8.02pm UK time on Tuesday night, he's the man to beat. That's due to the controlled, classy display he unleashed to win his heat yesterday, his time making him the quickest qualifier and just a quarter of a second shy of the Olympic record.\n\nWhat was more ominous for Wiffen's rivals: he was keeping something in reserve. \"It wasn't at 100 per cent,\" he said.\n\n\"We'll go with 95. You didn't see my legs come in at the end so that's where [the extra bit] is, but I was holding a good pace and am happy with the morning swim.\"\n\nWiffen has been building for years towards this peak and said it's \"100 per cent\" the fittest he's ever been. A medal won't come easy, but after a memorable weekend for Armagh, one of their proudest sons now senses he might fulfil what he has long deemed his destiny.\n\n\"Yeah, Armagh won,\" he said. \"My birthday is on July 14, Bastille Day. What is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris [in their first Olympic appearance as an independent nation]? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\".\n\nWiffen is drawn in lane four in Tuesday night's Final, with his chief rivals around him: Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri and USA's Bobby Finke to his left, Tunisia's Ahmed Jaouadi and Australia's Elijah Winnington to his right.\n\nWiffen said there was \"no significance\" to having the fastest qualifying time but he's \"got a great lane to look around\" as a result. \"Any lane has a chance,\" he added.\n\n\"I'll be doing my homework, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best.\"\n\nHe looked majestic in his heat yesterday, coasting into the lead just after halfway and drawing clear in the third quarter.\n\n\"The time didn't surprise me at all, I actually thought I'd be a little bit faster,\" he said. \"I was only off an Olympic record and no Irishman or woman has ever done that so that would have been pretty cool, but we'll save that for tomorrow night.\n\n\"I don't know some of the names in the Final, I'll need to look out for them. I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m Final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.\"\n\nOnly nine athletes have ever won gold at the Games for Ireland and no Irishman has ever reached the podium in swimming. He's now on the brink. \"I'll take any medal, whatever colour,\" Wiffen said.\n\nSadly, Larne's Danielle Hill will not be in Tuesday night's 100m Backstroke Final.\n\nHill finished eighth in 1:00.80 marginally slower than the 1:00.40 she swam earlier in the heats. It was outside her personal best of 59.11 and wasn't fast enough to secure her a place in the Final.\n\nMeanwhile, Matt Richards defied being in an outside lane to claim Olympic silver in the men's 200m Freestyle.\n\nRichards claimed Team GB's second runner-up spot of these Paris Games in the pool but like Adam Peaty 24 hours earlier, he was 0.02 seconds adrift of the winner -- Romanian sensation David Popovici.\n\nDuncan Scott, who won silver in the event at Tokyo 2020, finished fourth in a frenetic finish, just 0.08 secs adrift of bronze medallist Luke Hobson.\n\nIreland's Ellen Walshe finished eighth in last night's 400m Individual Medley Final.\n\nThe 22-year-old Dubliner became only the third swimmer in Irish history to reach an Olympic Final.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251252275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:47:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:47:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:45:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/ive-written-my-name-into-history-magheralins-daniel-wiffen-becomes-first-northern-irish-athlete-to-win-olympic-gold-since-1988/a84243612.html", "title": "'I've written my name into history' : Magheralin's Daniel Wiffen becomes first Northern Irish athlete to win Olympic Gold since 1988", "body": "Northern Ireland's 52-year wait for an individual gold medal at the Summer Olympics is over.\n\nMagheralin's Daniel Wiffen joined Lady Mary Peters and hockey stars Jimmy Kirkwood and Stephen Martin in the history books with a stunning performance inside La Defense Arena.\n\nThe Ireland swimmer stormed to victory in the 800m Freestyle Final in Paris with a time of 7.38.19, just 0.56 ahead of silver medalists American Bobby Finke. Wiffen's time set a new Olympic record. Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri took the bronze medal after leading the race for much of the way.\n\nBefore the race, Wiffen made a writing gestured to the crowd.\n\nAfter the race, he explained: \"I was saying that I am going to write my name into the history books and that is exactly what I've done.\n\n\"I executed my plan well but it wasn't the time I wanted. But Olympic finals aren't about the time, it's about getting your hand on the wall first.\"\n\nWiffen also said the last person he heard calling out from the crowd before the race was his twin brother Nathan.\n\n\"I actually heard Nathan before I dived in. I can't believe the only person I heard from the entire crowd was my twin brother!\"\n\nThe 23 year-old is just the fourth person from Northern Ireland to win a gold medal at the Summer Games, and the first to strike gold in an individual event since Mary Peters won the Pentathlon in Munich in 1972.\n\nWiffen is also the first athlete raised in Northern Ireland to win an Olympic title in the green of Ireland.\n\nThe 800m Freestyle world champion qualified fastest for the final with an impressive time of 7:41.53 in Monday's heats.\n\nWiffen has a realistic chance of winning a second medal this weekend. He will compete in the heats of the 1500m on Saturday morning, with the final set for 5.36pm on Sunday evening. He is also the current world champion over that distance.\n\nThe Irish swimmer will round-off his Olympic journey on Friday August 9 when he competes in the Men's Swimming Marathon.", "source": {"uri": "8251318913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:43:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:43:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:43:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.balls.ie/olympics/daniel-wiffen-olympics-final-606361", "title": "'What's My Name?' What's my name? Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion. It's really good. I can't believe it,\" he said.\n\n\"I want to thank my brother Nathan, my parents, all the staff at (Loughborough University) and the Irish team. I can't do it without anybody. By the last 150 metres we were all on our feet.\"\n\nDespite the pressure on their son, they said he doesn't let it get to him. \"He is very very calm,\" said the mother of the Olympic champion.\n\n\"Daniel rings us all the time, we were having lunch yesterday in the local town and Daniel rang us and was really jealous of what we were eating. We're very lucky that he does keep us involved.\"\n\nAhead of another race for the swimmer, when he will attempt to win a historic double when he competes in the men's 1500m heats on Saturday, with a potential final to come on Sunday, hopes are high for his parents.\n\nDaniel's father said: \"That's his favourite race and that's the one he really wants to attack, it'll be another tight race with the three guys at the top.\"\n\nHis mother spoke of when they first knew Daniel was destined for big things in the world of swimming. \"I realised when he was about 14 or 15 but it's hard to say because Daniel didn't start winning things until he went to Loughborough.\n\n\"He was winning the local galas and things like that - before that, he was as good as any of the swimmers in the club and the competition between him and [twin] Nathan was rife.\"\n\nThe twins have a Youtube channel Wiffen Twins and Nathan was \"signing autographs and just wanted to watch the race,\" said Mrs Wiffen.\n\nA debate has ensued over whether Daniel is from Co Down or Co Armagh but Mr Wiffen gave a definitive answer. \"Our house is Co Armagh. {"uri": "8250450592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "10:39:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T10:39:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T10:38:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/sport/13508619/olympics-daniel-wiffen-twin-nathan-game-of-thrones/", "title": "Inside life of Olympic ace Daniel Wiffen from identical twin to Game of Thrones", "body": "DANIEL WIFFEN will bid for an Olympic gold medal in the 800m freestyle final this evening.\n\nThe Irishman will be among the favourites for glory in the race which takes place at 8pm tonight, live on RTE 2.\n\nA medal in Paris is two years in the making, having becoming the first Irish swimmer to break a European record in 2022.\n\nSince then, the 23-year-old has hoovered up medals, namely one gold and two silver European U23 medals, three European gold medals - both in 2023 - and two World gold medals.\n\nThe Down man comes from fine swimming stock, with his brother a prodigious athlete in his own right.\n\nHere, SunSport takes a look at Daniel Wiffen's life outside of the pool.\n\nDaniel Wiffen was born on July 14, 2001, making him 23 years of age.\n\nHe was originally born in London, but moved to Magheralin, Co Down at the age of two and chose to represent Ireland.\n\nDaniel has an identical twin brother, named Nathan, who is also a swimmer, who finished fourth in the 1,500m at the 2024 European Championships.\n\nThe Wiffen brothers have a YouTube channel together, named the Wiffen Twins and through which Daniel has been charting his Olympics journey.\n\nAs well as being promising athletes from a young age, they could have had a career in acting.\n\nThey worked as extras in Game of Thrones, namely in the iconic 'Red Wedding' scene.\n\nBoth attend Loughborough University, where they study computer sciences.\n\nSwimming is in the blood for the Wiffens as their mum swam at a high level as did their older brother Ben who now works as a coach.\n\nThey grew up training in different lengths, before Daniel specialised in 400m, 800m, and 1,500m.\n\nThe standard training regiment was intense and unrelenting, including swimming 75km while a max programme would mean they're topping 100km over a seven-day stretch.\n\nIn spite of the intensity, the Wiffen twins' passion for swimming never wavered.\n\nIn 2023, Daniel said: \"We're training every day with thirteen pool sessions in total. Each one is two hours long.\n\n\"On top of that I do three strength and conditioning sessions in the gym per week as well as two core sessions and also a circuit one.\n\n\"This is a particularly heavy training block. The minimum one we'd follow would still be ten pool sessions a week.\"\n\nHe added: \"I love the training regime and how it keeps you active all of the time.\n\n\"Even with the travelling we do for it I don't mind because you get to see all of these nice countries.\n\n\"It almost feels like we're going on holidays despite all of the work we have to put in.\"\n\nThe work has paid off and then some for Daniel Wiffen, who has emerged as a true Irish superstar in recent years.\n\nIn 2021, he competed in the men's 800m freestyle and 1,500m freestyle at the Tokyo Olympics.\n\nIn 2022, he won a silver medal representing Northern Ireland in the 1,500m freestyle at the Commonwealth Games.\n\nThat December, he broke the European record for the 800m freestyle short course, becoming the first Irishman to hold a Euro record.\n\nThe following year would be a landmark one for the Down swimmer.\n\nHe became the 2023 European short-course champion over 400, 800 and 1,500m freestyle, the first Irish swimmer to do so.\n\nWiffen claimed U23 European gold in the 1,500m freestyle in Dublin in August, as well as silver in the 400m and 800m freestyle disciplines.\n\nFour months later, he won gold in the 400m, 800m, and 1,500m at the European Championships.\n\nHe warmed up for the 2024 Olympics in the best way possible, by winning gold in the 800m and 1,500m freestyle at the World Championships in February.\n\nAlong with the medals, he holds a whole host of records.\n\nDaniel shattered the world record at 800m at the European Short Course Championships in December, having claimed the European record five months earlier.\n\nWiffen won the fastest 800m freestyle heat in a time of 7:41.53, his third quickest time of his career.\n\nAnd the 23-year-old is confident of a podium finish in Tuesday evening's final.\n\nWiffen said: \"Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14th, Bastille Day, what is it 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? It just seems everything is aligning, doesn't it?\n\n\"Any medal is good, it's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine, especially.\"\n\nThere have been some hiccups along the way, however, with Wiffen adding: \"Yeah it's so good...I mean, the food in the Village is a bit terrible honestly.\n\n\"But everything else is class. I love our flat, our team atmosphere, everything.\n\n\"I just love being part of Team Ireland.\"\n\nWhile a bit of a throwaway remark, when RTE cut back to their Montrose studio pundit Earl McCarthy did pick up on that remark.\n\nHe noted that Wiffen's preparation might not be going optimally based on that complaint.\n\nBut the proof is in the...pool and so far, he looks set to justify his pre-Olympics status as one of Ireland's main medal hopes.\n\nAlong with the 800m freestyle, Daniel will be competing in the 1,500m Freestyle and Open Water 10km", "source": {"uri": "thesun.ie", {"uri": "8248947893", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "13:04:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T13:04:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T13:03:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/articles/cy68e86wx66o", "title": "Olympics swimming: Wiffen 'had eyes on Olympic record' in 800m heats", "body": "World champion Daniel Wiffen says he had his eyes on an Olympic record as he qualified for the men's 800m freestyle finals in first place.\n\nThe Team Ireland swimmer, who won world 800m and 1500m freestyle gold in February, stated before the Games that he would not be leaving Paris without a medal.\n\nHe put down an ominous marker in the 800m heats on Monday morning as he set the fastest time, and he will go into the final on Tuesday night as favourite.\n\n\"I was happy with my time, but I had my eyes on the Olympic record,\" the 23-year-old said.\n\n\"But it's only the heats, so it doesn't really matter.\"\n\nWiffen's time of 7:41.53 was just outside the Olympic record of 7:41.28, which was set by Mykhailo Romanchuk of Ukraine.\n\nThe 23-year-old admitted he was \"very nervous\" ahead of his heat in a packed La Defense Arena as he embarked on his second Games.\n\n\"I was more nervous than when I walked out for the World Championship final, I think it's just the crowd size and knowing that I have a lot of support in the crowd.\"\n\nWiffen added there was \"no expectation at all\" as he looks to become the first athlete from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold since Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood in 1988, who triumphed with Team GB's hockey team in Soeul.\n\n\"I'm looking forward to it, 100%,\" Wiffen said ahead of Tuesday's final.\n\n\"I've got to try and calm down a bit now. The field at the Olympics is stronger than the one he competed against during that event in Qatar, meaning it was always going to be interesting to see how he stacked up against the competition.\n\nAfter this race, it's fair to say that he is well positioned to be in among the medals.\n\nWiffen produced a stunning performance in the race. He found himself behind the leader for the opening half of the swim, with his Australian opponent going out at a very quick pace in the longer distance format.\n\nThe Irishman would take control of the race from that point onwards, going on to ease to victory. His time of 7:41:53 was over a second quicker than everyone else in the field, meaning he will be in the centre lane for tomorrow's medal race.\n\nREAD HERE: Odd Paul O'Donovan Comments Drew A Cringe From Fintan McCarthy At Olympics\n\nWhile he is still just 23-years old, Daniel Wiffen certainly seems ready to do the business on the biggest stage.\n\nHis performance at the World Championships made him a household name in Ireland and he now looks on course to win the nation's first ever Olympic medal in men's swimming.\n\nSpeaking to RT\u00c9 after this morning's race, Wiffen shared his belief that he will win an Olympic medal, even if the food in the athlete's village isn't doing him any favours.\n\nVery happy. It was very close to my World Championship winning time that I only did six months ago and it felt a hell of a lot easier than that one...\n\nI can't ask for more. I love the centre lane, it's my favourite lane. We will wait and see tomorrow night, it's all about this 36-hour recovery period that I've got to get right...\n\nI expect that if anybody has got a lane in the final, anybody can win from anywhere. I will be well aware of every lane and I'm looking forward to the final...\n\nI said I wanted a medal, and I will be coming away with one eventually at some point. I just can't wait to race again honestly, I love that.\n\nI was a bit nervous kind of walking out, but after the first 100 metres I settled in nicely and felt quite good...\n\nIt's so good. I mean, the food is a bit terrible honestly in the village, but everything else is class. I love the flats, I love everything, I love the team atmosphere, it's great. I love being part of Team Ireland...\n\nI walked out and got a big cheer. I could hear people cheering my name, so there's quite a lot of Irish support here.\n\nI'm really looking forward to the final, because I hear that a lot of people coming. That will be good to see.\n\nDaniel Wiffen will certainly have everyone in Ireland behind him for tomorrow night's final, which takes place at 8.02pm Irish time.\n\nIt would be incredible to see him {"uri": "8251443845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "23:00:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T23:00:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:50:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13690959/Daniel-Wiffen-Ireland-wins-Olympic-gold-hopes-pick-new-YouTube-followers.html", "title": "Daniel Wiffen of Ireland wins Olympic gold and also hopes to pick...", "body": "NANTERRE, France (AP) - Daniel Wiffen won Ireland's first Olympic gold medal in the pool in 28 years. That was thrilling enough as he wiped away tears standing on the podium, the Irish flag draped over his shoulders.\n\nPerhaps just as importantly, the 23-year-old Irishman is sure to pick up some new followers on his YouTube channel - a pitch he made when asked how people can learn more about a swimmer who is largely unknown outside his country.\n\n\"People should watch,\" Wiffen said after winning the 800-meter freestyle on Tuesday night. \"I blog every week - show you exactly what an Olympic champion does day-in, day-out in the pool.\"\n\nGet ready for a flood of fans, Daniel.\n\nWearing round glasses and looking studious, Wiffen cried as the Irish anthem played in La Defense Arena. He may not look the part of an Olympic champion, but his performance in the pool says otherwise.\n\nWiffen will be back later in the Paris Games, hoping to win another gold on Sunday in the 1,500 meters - the final day of competition in the pool.\n\nGold medalist Daniel Wiffen, of Ireland, poses for a photo with his national flag on the podium following the men's 800-meter freestyle final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 30, 2024, in Nanterre, France. (AP Photo/Ashley Landis)\n\n\"I don\u00b4t normally cry, so I really hope nobody is going to see that,\" Wiffen said. \"But it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment. I've never heard that national anthem from an Olympics before.\"\n\nWiffen surged past Italy\u00b4s Gregorio Paltrinieri on the final lap, looking as fresh as he did at the beginning of the grueling race. He won in 7 minutes, 38.19 seconds, overpowering defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) of the United States and Paltrinieri (7:39.38).\n\nMona McSharry won bronze for Ireland's first medal of these Games on the previous night in the 100 breaststroke.\n\n\"I was dying the last 20 meters,\" Wiffen said. \"I\u00b4m not sure if you saw that, because my arms are in absolutely so much pain. But I knew that the crowd is gonna carry me in, and that\u00b4s exactly what happened. Then I saw the red light on the block, and that was it.\"\n\nUntil these Olympics, Ireland's swimming history was essentially confined to Michelle Smith de Bruin, who surprisingly claimed three golds and a bronze at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics amid suspicions she was doping.\n\nShe later received a drug ban that essentially ended her career, but she kept her medals.\n\nWiffen was not asked about Smith de Bruin as he huddled with reporters, primarily Irish who were not looking to spoil a special night.\n\n\"To be honest - it\u00b4s going to sound really weird to say - I\u00b4ve dreamt of this moment so many times in my head, I\u00b4ve gone over it so many different ways of how it was going to happen,\" he said. \"But to be fair, I didn't think I was going to do it in the 800 because it wasn't my favorite. I prefer the longer distance.\"\n\nSo, get ready for his shot at another Irish medal on Sunday - and more tears.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nGold medalist Daniel Wiffen of Ireland reacts after receiving his gold medal for the men's 800-meter freestyle final at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Monday, Tuesday, July 30, 2024. {"uri": "8252199626", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:04:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:04:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:03:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13692635/It-just-electric--Parents-share-pride-gold-medal-swimmer-Daniel-Wiffen.html", "title": "'It was just electric\u00b4: Parents share pride in gold medal swimmer...", "body": "The parents of gold medal swimmer Daniel Wiffen have spoken of their pride at his history-making win at the Olympics.\n\nWiffen, who grew up in the village of Magheralin, near Lurgan, Co Armagh, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nOnly an hour after Wiffen's success another Northern Ireland swimmer secured a gold medal.\n\nRacegoers at Galway Racecourse watch Ireland\u00b4s Daniel Wiffen on the big screen as he wins the men\u00b4s 800m freestyle final at the Paris Olympic Games (Niall Carson/PA)\n\nWhile Jack McMillan did not participate in the Olympic 4x200m freestyle final that was won by Team GB swimmers Matt Richards, James Guy, Tom Dean and Duncan Scott, the 24-year-old from Co Down still secured a medal having swum for the team in the qualifying heats.\n\nEarlier, Wiffen, 23, became the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first male swimming gold medallist.\n\nPrior to his gold medal swim, the last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nHis parents Rachel and Jonathan were in the La Defense Arena to witness the thrilling win.\n\nOther family members, including Wiffen's twin brother Nathan - a talented swimmer in his own right - were also there.\n\nNathan and Daniel's love of the water started when they were just three months old when their parents took them along to Water Babies classes.\n\n\"It was just electric,\" mum Rachel told BBC Radio Ulster.\n\nIreland\u00b4s Daniel Wiffen celebrates after winning the men\u00b4s 800m freestyle final at the Paris Olympics (John Walton/PA)\n\n\"We were very, very high up, so we were way away from the pool, and I had a bit of a wobble at 400 metres, and I was thinking this isn't going how I thought it was going to go.\n\n\"And then that last 50m it was just amazing. Just he did everything he was going to do. It was just brilliant.\"\n\nHis dad Jonathan said: \"Stroke after stroke, we were watching him, we're watching the board, we're watching the time, we're watching each other. We're sort of saying how are the others doing?\"\n\nHe added: \"By the last 150 metres, we were all on our feet. All the people around us were cheering Daniel on and shouting for him in the stadium. It was absolutely amazing.\"\n\nMeanwhile, McMillan's brother Leo said the fact he did not get his medal on the podium did not take away from his amazing performance in the heat.\n\n\"He really didn't have any nerves and neither did I going into it, I just have full confidence in him,\" he told Radio Ulster.\n\n\"I thought he was going to do really well and he did. We were absolutely ecstatic last night and even this morning. I'm just so proud of him. Obviously, it would have been nice to see him stand on the podium, but the performance itself in the heat was amazing. And he really did put on a show.\"\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly have congratulated both swimmers while Taoiseach Simon Harris and Tanaiste Micheal Martin hailed Wiffen's achievement in becoming Ireland's first ever male swimming gold medallist.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, and Sam Short, who missed out on finals spots by the narrowest of margins.\n\nWinnington was upstaged by Irish world champion Daniel Wiffen in their heat, but did enough to make it through to the final.\n\nKnow the news with the 7NEWS app: Download today\n\nShort finished third behind the top two, but just missed out on a spot in the final with the ninth-fastest time.\n\nWinnington, who won {"uri": "8252088001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:58:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:58:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:55:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/2024/0731/1462740-daniel-wiffen-reaction/", "title": "Parents 'over the moon' with Wiffen's gold medal triumph", "body": "The parents of Olympic champion swimmer Daniel Wiffen are \"over the moon\" with their son's gold medal triumph in Paris last night.\n\nThe Armagh man staged a storming final stretch in the men's 800m freestyle final to clinch gold at the Games in an Olympic record time.\n\nHis success marks a second medal in the pool in as many days for Ireland at Paris 2024 following Mona McSharry's bronze medal feat the previous night.\n\nHaving been presented with his gold medal, Wiffen said it was special to hear Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann play from the podium.\n\nWe need your consent to load this comcast-player contentWe use comcast-player to manage extra content that can set cookies on your device and collect data about your activity. Please review their details and accept them to load the content.Manage Preferences\n\n\"I ain't much of a crier, I shed a lot of tears there. You never really see me cry, so it's a big achievement for that! It's amazing, I love hearing the national anthem.\"\n\nHis mother told RT\u00c9's Morning Ireland that it was \"unbelievable\" to be able to say, \"you're a mum of an Olympian, gold medallist.\"\n\nShe recounted that the family were calm while watching the race in the La D\u00e9fense Arena.\n\nMs Wiffen added that they met the parents of US swimmer Bobby Finke - who ultimately finished in second place - before the race, which \"set the scene\".\n\n\"The race started and ... the crowd was just electric and then I had a wobble about 400m because I just didn't know how the race was going to go.\"\n\n\"His last race that we saw was the World Championships in Doha and there he was just out in front and, as a parent, that's the best position to be in because you just know when he's that far in front it's going to be a win,\" she said.\n\nHowever, Ms Wiffen did not realise how close the end of the race was until this morning when she watched it back.\n\n\"All of a sudden, I don't know what happened, it was just as we cheered and we knew he'd won and the next is I couldn't see and my contact lens had fallen out,\" Ms Wiffen joked.\n\nAfter the race \"everyone wanted a bit of Daniel Wiffen\", Ms Wiffen said, but his family \"wanted him more than anyone else\".\n\n\"Nathan had said to me 'I want to hug him first' so we had to wait for Nathan to hug him too.\"\n\nWhile congratulating their son he told them to feel his medal \"and my goodness, I didn't expect it to be so heavy\", she said.\n\nMs Wiffen added that while they would have been happy with a \"medal of any colour\" deep down they wanted gold.\n\nHis father, Jonathan, explained that emotions were high during the celebrations last night but the best moment for him was when Wiffen hugged his brother Nathan.\n\n\"Because he has been with Daniel all the way, and it was just lovely,\" Mr Wiffen said.\n\n\"Nathan and Daniel, when they're not together, speak almost hourly on Facetime and he speaks with his other brother and sister quite regularly.\"\n\nMr Wiffen added: \"Nathan has been his training partner. Nathan's season had finished at the European championships, but Nathan then went back in the water to continue to help train Daniel in Dublin for the pre-camp.\"\n\n'Once-in-a-generation athlete'\n\nPresident Michael D Higgins congratulated the Olympic swimmer and said it was a \"wonderful achievement of which he can be so proud\".\n\nTaoiseach, Simon Harris said the swimmer's power and grit under pressure confirmed him as a once-in-a-generation athlete.\n\nFirst and Deputy First Ministers of Northern Ireland Michelle O'Neill and Emma Little-Pengelly also congratulated Mr Wiffen on his win.\n\n'Crest of a wave'\n\nPrincipal of St Patrick's Grammar School in Armagh, Dominic Clarke, where Daniel and his twin brother Nathan attended, said they had always been clear about their ambitions.\n\n\"I think Nathan and Daniel might have been 15 [or] 16 when we did a number of videos in the school about up-and-coming people and the two guys were interviewed and, at that stage, they said they would like to go to the Olympics and Paris was their target.\n\n\"I look forward to digging that interview out again and presenting it to the two boys because now - here we are - that reality has set in and not only is Daniel Olympic champion, he's also Olympic record holder,\" Mr Clarke told RT\u00c9's Morning Ireland.\n\nHe added that everyone at St Patrick's Grammar School is still \"on the crest of a wave\".\n\n\"It's just absolute wonderful for primarily Daniel and Nathan and his other brother Ben who also went to St Pat's - and also his Mum, Dad, sister and family.\n\nMr Clarke added: \"It's just an absolutely fantastic achievement and it's just reward for the efforts he's put in since he was a kid.\"\n\nThe swimmer's trademark confidence was not immediately evident, according to Mr Clarke, who said that he was \"pretty understated\" and a diligent student.\n\n\"Our school, like a lot of schools, is dominated by Gaelic sports and the two boys weren't interested in Gaelic sports, but they were highly respected swimmers,\" he said.\n\nMr Clarke praised the work ethic of both Daniel and his twin brother Nathan while they were studying for their A-level exams and also attempting to qualify for the Tokyo Games in 2020.\n\n\"They went to Dublin, they trained twice, and they kept an ear to the ground and kept contact with the school and the teachers.\n\n\"And on occasions they changed their 6am swim session to 5am so that they could be finished an hour earlier to get up to the school from Dublin to catch up the teachers who were good enough to give [up their time],\" he said.\n\n\"There was very close contact between ourselves and Swim Ireland and we're very happy. Ultimately Covid delayed the Tokyo Olympics by a year and that allowed the two boys to qualify and of course Daniel did.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Swim Ireland's High Performance Director Dr Jon Rudd Mr Wiffen's gold medal win \"inspire generations\" of young people.\n\nSpeaking on the same programme, Dr Rudd said he thanked Mr Wiffen for what he had done for the next generation of young swimmers after his win.\n\n\"We know that Olympic medals are difficult to come by and gold ones don't come around that often.\n\n\"He is thoroughly deserving of this because of his application and his commitment but the inspiration that this will provide to tens of thousands of young people for generations going forward is very difficult to measure,\" Dr Rudd said.", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", I've done it - that's all I want to say!\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down.\n\n\"I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\n\n\"It feels incredible. Andrew Bree said it just as I want to say it -'lights, camera, action' - that's exactly what I did - I'm writing myself into the history books!\"\n\nThe identical twin joins Mona McSharry's as a medal "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/tearful-wiffen-makes-irish-history-with-olympic-gold/article_9d1a8007-188a-51cb-9bfe-8450de61c2b0.html", "title": "Tearful Wiffen makes Irish history with Olympic gold", "body": "Daniel Wiffen made history Tuesday as the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming gold medal, shedding tears as the enormity of the achievement sunk in.\n\nThe 23-year-old hit the wall first in 7min 38.19sec, the fifth-fastest time ever, to be crowned 800m freestyle champion in La Defense Arena.\n\nThe only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic pool came at Atlanta in 1996 when Michelle Smith collected three.\n\nWiffen, the first Irish male swimmer to win a medal of any colour, couldn't hide his emotions when the national anthem played as he stood on top of the podium.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope that nobody's gonna see that,\" he said.\n\n\"But, yeah, it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at an Olympics before, and it's just crazy to say that it was me standing on a number one podium here for the first time.\"\n\nWiffen, who also won the 800m at the world championships in Doha this year, came home ahead of American defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) and Tokyo silver medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri (7:39.38) of Italy.\n\nHe took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired and was reeled in.\n\nPaltrinieri made at a move at 600m and led to the final turn before Wiffen came roaring back to rewrite the history books.\n\nMore from this section Musk's superhuman vision promise is dangerous: researchers 4 Moms Share Back-to-School Shopping Tips That Actually Work Protests erupt in Caracas against Maduro's disputed election win: AFP\n\n\"To be fair, normally I do only train one way and that's just to try hold on, burn everybody out in the middle,\" he said.\n\n\"But I knew I Olympics is completely different. You don't know how you're going to feel in the first 100.\n\n\"So really, my first part of the race was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place, I was just so nervous.\n\n\"But luckily I had a good enough speed to keep it going and I was still in the race. Then my goal was to keep building.\"\n\nWiffen paid tribute to his identical twin brother Nathan, also a distance swimmer who missed out on qualification for Paris, for urging him on.\n\n\"I tell you what, the only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" he said.\n\n\"I've dreamed of this every day of my life.\n\n\"I know that I seem very confident on the outside, but there's always that little tiny feeling that, you know, can I do this?\"\n\nmp/gj", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-438767880", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:50:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:50:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T20:39:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/political-leaders-across-island-ireland-203929539.html", "title": "Political leaders across island of Ireland hail history-maker Daniel Wiffen", "body": "Political leaders across island of Ireland hail history-maker Daniel Wiffen\n\nDavid Young, PA\n\n30 July 2024 at 9:39 pm\n\nPolitical leaders across the island of Ireland have hailed history-maker Daniel Wiffen after his gold medal victory in the Olympic swimming pool.\n\nWiffen, from the village of Magheralin in Northern Ireland, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nThe 23-year-old has become the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first-ever male swimming gold medallist.\n\nThe last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB Hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little Pengelly congratulated the swimming hero.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement.\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris described Wiffen's performance as \"masterful\".\n\n\"On behalf of the entire country, hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen,\" he said.\n\n\"Daniel, you did it - Olympic gold and an Olympic record.\n\n\"The 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete. He's a world champion and now an Olympic champion, and it was our privilege to witness it.\n\n\"This is a family affair and I can only imagine the joy of Rachel, Jonathan and Nathan this evening. This is your victory too.\n\n\"Congratulations Daniel, we can't wait to see what you do next.\"\n\nDeputy premier Micheal Martin described the win as an \"outstanding performance\".\n\n\"A breathtaking race and a new Olympic record,\" he said.\n\n\"What an achievement for Daniel and his family.\"\n\nRichard Archibald, interim chief executive officer of Sport NI, said: \"After a 36-year wait Daniel Wiffen is bringing an Olympic gold medal home to Northern Ireland.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are immensely proud of Daniel and his achievements.\n\n\"We are proud to have supported Daniel at the start of his career through our National Lottery funded athlete award. His progress over the last few years has been incredible, with European and World titles as well as a coveted world record and now an Olympic record.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to us all and I am sure his win will encourage many young people across Northern Ireland to try their hand at swimming. With two more events to come the sky is the limit for Daniel and we wish him all the very best.\"\n\nWiffen's victory came a day after Sligo's Mona McSharry clinched a dramatic Olympic bronze medal I'm there to get the job done and hopefully finish it in the final.\n\n'I said before, any lane has a chance. I'll be looking at everybody, I'll be doing my homework tonight, see how everybody swims it, making sure I'll be one of the best there tomorrow night.'\n\nHe reckoned he was at 95 per cent in winning this morning, and observers expect him to compete for gold here in La Defense Arena.\n\nBut he insisted himself that any step on the podium will satisfy him.\n\n'Any medal is good,' he said.\n\n'It's my first race here, it's my first time being in contention for an Olympic medal so I'll take any medal, whatever colour, and then we got another two races after this and I'm looking forward to the one in the Seine, especially.'\n\nThat is a reference to the swim marathon that he hopes to compete in next week, but before then there is bigger business to attend to - and the Armagh man is taking their stunning football final success as a good sign.\n\n'Yeah Armagh won, my birthday is on July 14, Bastille Day, what is it, 100 years since Ireland competed in Paris? {"uri": "8250165474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "07:39:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T07:39:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T07:38:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://extra.ie/2024/07/30/sport/sport-extra/daniel-wiffen-international-superstar", "title": "Paris Olympics: Ireland's Daniel Wiffen in place to be an international superstar", "body": "Beyond times and records, there are less obvious signals that you are in the presence of a star.\n\nAfter every event at the Olympics, athletes are obliged to go through an area called the mixed zone. This is where media interviews are conducted, and every competitor is expected to stop if requested.\n\nReporters mostly congregate along national lines, and it's not common for an Irish athlete to attract attention from beyond the press from these shores.\n\nOne exception has been in rowing, where their status as defending champions makes the men's lightweight doubles of Paul O'Donovan and Fintan McCarthy international news.\n\nAnother was in the La Defense Arena, shortly after midday here in Paris yesterday.\n\nThe swimmers from the last of the four heats in the men's 800m freestyle were coming through in dribs and drabs, and the Irish written press were waiting for Daniel Wiffen to finish his broadcast interviews.\n\nWe were soon joined by American journalists, eager for any tidbit they could gather about Wiffen. There were reporters there, too, who were servicing the official Olympic media service, which dispatches quotes and reports to all media here, and which is relayed by news agencies around the world.\n\nWiffen is big news in the world of swimming, a place where the biggest nations traditionally hold sway.\n\nThat was immediately apparent on arrival at the venue yesterday morning.\n\nThe La Defense Arena is stunning, a remarkable footprint containing sport and business facilities to the west of Paris. It is enormous, with an IFSC-type commercial area to one side. If a company built an indoor arena containing a sports stadium beside the IFSC in the Dublin docklands, you would have an approximation of this place.\n\nRacing 92 have their home here and, in an Olympic-inflected twist, they left the Stade Olympique Yves-du-Manoir for here. That was the stadium used for the Paris Olympics of 1924.\n\nThe Arena and all areas around it were packed with fans yesterday morning. Americans and Australians predominated, reflective of how dominant those countries are in swimming.\n\nThere were plenty of Chinese visitors, too, but when Ellen Walshe, Danielle Hill and Wiffen took to the pool on their turns, clusters of tricolours appeared.\n\nThe noise was terrific, but when any French entrant appeared, it hit new levels.\n\nSwimmers often maintain that they don't hear the noise when they are competing. They are hearing this.\n\nThe place nearly came apart on Sunday night when home star Leon Marchand won gold in the men's 400m individual medley. 'I always said before that I never hear the crowd when I'm swimming; that one I could hear 100 per cent,' said Wiffen.\n\n'There were a lot of Irish support. I saw a lot of tricolours in the stand, so pretty happy.'\n\nHe had good reason to be after a display in the heats of the 400m individual medley that saw him finish as fastest qualifier.\n\nComing after his world record-breaking and world titles of recent months, it makes him a firmer favourite to take Ireland's first gold tonight.\n\n'I was more nervous than I was before the World Championships, but that's just the Olympics, a different kind of level,' he said.\n\n'But I dealt with it quite well. A bit nervous around the first 100m, but then I settled in.'\n\nHis ambitions for tonight are also helped by the failure of one of his main rivals to make the final. As well as Wiffen, Sam Short of Australia and America's Bobby Finke were regarded as the main contenders, but Short missed out.\n\nWiffen's strong performance means he gets lane four in tonight's final (8.02pm).\n\nThe advantage of a central lane is the perspective it gives of swimmers on either side.\n\n'I'm a middle swimmer,' he said. 'I like to hold a fast pace no one else can hold. I don't know some of the names in the final, I'll need to look out for them; I'm not going to make the mistake in the 400m final in 2021 when some of them won from outside lanes.'\n\nHe wished Ellen Walshe and Mona McSharry well in their finals last night, but his evening was to be spent off his feet after a 'good feed', and then studying the opposition.\n\nWiffen is the subject of fevered anticipation at home, and it's striking to see him figure so prominently in discussions within the sport, too.\n\nIreland has no rich tradition of swimming. There's plenty of contentious history, of course, but there is not the kind of immersion in and understanding of the sport that there is in other places.\n\nA trip to an Olympic swimming event is a riotous introduction to its status. The colour and the noise may be found at other disciplines, too, but under a closed roof the environment is greatly heightened.\n\nThere is severe doubt about whether boxing will make the roster in Los Angeles in 2028, which feels unthinkable given its place in Irish history.\n\nIt is dispensable at the Olympics the way all but a handful of sports are and, along with athletics, swimming is one of the immovable anchors of the Games.\n\nThe progression of Walshe and McSharry to finals, the excellent performance by Danielle Hill in getting to a semi-final, and of course Wiffen's startling promise are helping us to understand that a little better.\n\n'Completely different,' Wiffen said of the build-up here compared to the 2020 Games.\n\n'In Tokyo I was just there really, qualified and just tried to keep progressing.\n\n'The past three years have been a blast for me, improving by 15 seconds in the 1500m every time I swam in the water, PB-ing in every international.'", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-439298702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:27:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:27:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:21:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/utv/2024-07-31/masterful-history-maker-daniel-wiffen-celebrates-olympic-gold", "title": "'Masterful' history-maker Daniel Wiffen celebrates Olympic gold", "body": "Political leaders across the island of Ireland have hailed history-maker Daniel Wiffen after his gold medal victory in the Olympic swimming pool.\n\nWiffen, from the village of Magheralin in Northern Ireland, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nThe 23-year-old has become the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first male swimming gold medallist.\n\nHe said: \"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say! \"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down - I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out. I heard none of the crowd - just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\" \"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"\n\nThe last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nOnly an hour after Wiffen's success another Northern Ireland swimmer secured a gold medal.\n\nWhile Jack McMillan did not participate in the Olympic 4x200m freestyle final that was won by Team GB swimmers Matt Richards, James Guy, Tom Dean and Duncan Scott, the 24-year-old from Co Down still secured a medal having swum for the team in the qualifying heats.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly congratulated both swimmers.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement.\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris described Wiffen's performance as \"masterful\".\n\n\"On behalf of the entire country, hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen,\" he said.\n\n\"Daniel, you did it - Olympic gold and an Olympic record.\n\n\"The 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete. He's a world champion and now an Olympic champion, and it was our privilege to witness it.\n\n\"This is a family affair and I can only imagine the joy of Rachel, Jonathan and Nathan this evening. This is your victory too.\n\n\"Congratulations Daniel, we can't wait to see what you do next.\"\n\nDeputy premier Micheal Martin described Wiffen's win as an \"outstanding performance\".\n\n\"A breathtaking race and a new Olympic record,\" he said.\n\n\"What an achievement for Daniel and his family.\"\n\nRichard Archibald, interim chief executive officer of Sport NI, said: \"After a 36-year wait Daniel Wiffen is bringing an Olympic gold medal home to Northern Ireland.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are immensely proud of Daniel and his achievements.\n\n\"We are proud to have supported Daniel at the start of his career through our National Lottery funded athlete award. His progress over the last few years has been incredible, with European and World titles as well as a coveted world record and now an Olympic record.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to us all and I am sure his win will encourage many young people across Northern Ireland to try their hand at swimming. With two more events to come the sky is the limit for Daniel and we wish him all the very best.\"\n\nOn McMillan's achievement, he added: \"Jack played an integral role in the team securing their spot in tonight's final with the fastest qualifying time.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are proud to have supported Jack's journey to success through our Sport NI Sports Institute and National Lottery-funded Athlete Award.\"\n\nWiffen's victory came a day after Sligo's Mona McSharry clinched a dramatic Olympic bronze medal for Ireland in the final of the women's 100m breaststroke.\n\nCatch up with the latest UTV
