"news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/tearful-wiffen-makes-irish-history-with-olympic-gold/article_5ac525c6-623c-50c1-9fa6-4f841fcc9549.html", "title": "Tearful Wiffen makes Irish history with Olympic gold", "body": "Daniel Wiffen made history Tuesday as the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming gold medal, shedding tears as the enormity of the achievement sunk in.\n\nThe 23-year-old hit the wall first in 7min 38.19sec, the fifth-fastest time ever, to be crowned 800m freestyle champion in La Defense Arena.\n\nThe only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic pool came at Atlanta in 1996 when Michelle Smith collected three.\n\nWiffen, the first Irish male swimmer to win a medal of any colour, couldn't hide his emotions when the national anthem played as he stood on top of the podium.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope that nobody's gonna see that,\" he said.\n\n\"But, yeah, it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at an Olympics before, and it's just crazy to say that it was me standing on a number one podium here for the first time.\"\n\nWiffen, who also won the 800m at the world championships in Doha this year, came home ahead of American defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) and Tokyo silver medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri (7:39.38) of Italy.\n\nHe took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired and was reeled in.\n\nPaltrinieri made at a move at 600m and led to the final turn before Wiffen came roaring back to rewrite the history books.\n\n\"To be fair, normally I do only train one way and that's just to try hold on, burn everybody out in the middle,\" he said.\n\n\"But I knew I Olympics is completely different. You don't know how you're going to feel in the first 100.\n\n\"So really, my first part of the race was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place, I was just so nervous.\n\n\"But luckily I had a good enough speed to keep it going and I was still in the race. Then my goal was to keep building.\"\n\nWiffen paid tribute to his identical twin brother Nathan, also a distance swimmer who missed out on qualification for Paris, for urging him on.\n\n\"I tell you what, the only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" he said.\n\n\"I've dreamed of this every day of my life.\n\n\"I know that I seem very confident on the outside, but there's always that little tiny feeling that, you know, can I do this?\"\n\nmp/gj\n\nMore from this section\n\nInvestigation finds at least 973 Native American children died in US government boarding {"uri": "8252224165", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:18:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:18:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:17:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.belfastlive.co.uk/sport/daniel-wiffens-parents-react-sons-29648262", "title": "Daniel Wiffen's parents react to son's Olympic gold medal success", "body": "The parents of gold medal swimmer Daniel Wiffen have spoken of their pride at his history-making win at the Olympics.\n\nWiffen, who grew up in the village of Magheralin, near Lurgan, Co Armagh, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nOnly an hour after Wiffen's success another Northern Ireland swimmer secured a gold medal.\n\nREAD MORE: NI man wins Olympic gold medal 'after 36 year wait'\n\nREAD MORE: Who is Daniel Wiffen? Inside life of Magheralin Olympic sensation\n\nWhile Jack McMillan did not participate in the Olympic 4x200m freestyle final that was won by Team GB swimmers Matt Richards, James Guy, Tom Dean and Duncan Scott, the 24-year-old from Co Down still secured a medal having swum for the team in the qualifying heats.\n\nEarlier, Wiffen, 23, became the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first male swimming gold medallist.\n\nPrior to his gold medal swim, the last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nHis parents Rachel and Jonathan were in the La Defense Arena to witness the thrilling win.\n\nOther family members, including Wiffen's twin brother Nathan - a talented swimmer in his own right - were also there.\n\nNathan and Daniel's love of the water started when they were just three months old when their parents took them along to Water Babies classes.\n\n\"It was just electric,\" mum Rachel told BBC Radio Ulster.\n\n\"We were very, very high up, so we were way away from the pool, and I had a bit of a wobble at 400 metres, and I was thinking this isn't going how I thought it was going to go.\n\n\"And then that last 50m it was just amazing. Just he did everything he was going to do. It was just brilliant.\"\n\nHis dad Jonathan said: \"Stroke after stroke, we were watching him, we're watching the board, we're watching the time, we're watching each other. We're sort of saying how are the others doing?\"\n\nHe added: \"By the last 150 metres, we were all on our feet. All the people around us were cheering Daniel on and shouting for him in the stadium. It was absolutely amazing.\"\n\nMeanwhile, McMillan's brother Leo said the fact he did not get his medal on the podium did not take away from his amazing performance in the heat.\n\n\"He really didn't have any nerves and neither did I going into it, I just have full confidence in him,\" he told Radio Ulster.\n\n\"I thought he was going to do really well and he did. We were absolutely ecstatic last night and even this morning. I'm just so proud of him. Obviously, it would have been nice to see him stand on the podium, but the performance itself in the heat was amazing. And he really did put on a show.\"\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly have congratulated both swimmers while Taoiseach Simon Harris and Tanaiste Micheal Martin hailed Wiffen's achievement in becoming Ireland's first ever male swimming gold medallist.\n\nSign up to our free sports newsletter to get the latest headlines to your inbox.", {"uri": "2024-07-439296810", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:26:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:26:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:19:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/just-electric-parents-share-pride-091933373.html", "title": "'It was just electric': Parents share pride in gold medal swimmer Daniel Wiffen", "body": "'It was just electric': Parents share pride in gold medal swimmer Daniel Wiffen\n\nDavid Young, PA\n\n31 July 2024 at 11:19 am\n\nThe parents of gold medal swimmer Daniel Wiffen have spoken of their pride at his history-making win at the Olympics.\n\nWiffen, who grew up in the village of Magheralin, near Lurgan, Co Armagh, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nOnly an hour after Wiffen's success another Northern Ireland swimmer secured a gold medal.\n\nWhile Jack McMillan did not participate in the Olympic 4x200m freestyle final that was won by Team GB swimmers Matt Richards, James Guy, Tom Dean and Duncan Scott, the 24-year-old from Co Down still secured a medal having swum for the team in the qualifying heats.\n\nEarlier, Wiffen, 23, became the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first male swimming gold medallist.\n\nPrior to his gold medal swim, the last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nHis parents Rachel and Jonathan were in the La Defense Arena to witness the thrilling win.\n\nOther family members, including Wiffen's twin brother Nathan - a talented swimmer in his own right - were also there.\n\nNathan and Daniel's love of the water started when they were just three months old when their parents took them along to Water Babies classes.\n\n\"It was just electric,\" mum Rachel told BBC Radio Ulster.\n\n\"We were very, very high up, so we were way away from the pool, and I had a bit of a wobble at 400 metres, and I was thinking this isn't going how I thought it was going to go.\n\n\"And then that last 50m it was just amazing. Just he did everything he was going to do. It was just brilliant.\"\n\nHis dad Jonathan said: \"Stroke after stroke, we were watching him, we're watching the board, we're watching the time, we're watching each other. We're sort of saying how are the others doing?\"\n\nHe added: \"By the last 150 metres, we were all on our feet. All the people around us were cheering Daniel on and shouting for him in the stadium. It was absolutely amazing.\"\n\nMeanwhile, McMillan's brother Leo said the fact he did not get his medal on the podium did not take away from his amazing performance in the heat.\n\n\"He really didn't have any nerves and neither did I going into it, I just have full confidence in him,\" he told Radio Ulster.\n\n\"I thought he was going to do really well and he did. We were absolutely ecstatic last night and even this morning. I'm just so proud of him. Obviously, it would have been nice to see him stand on the podium, but the performance itself in the heat was amazing. And he really did put on a show.\"\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly have congratulated both swimmers while Taoiseach Simon Harris and Tanaiste Micheal Martin hailed Wiffen's achievement in becoming Ireland's first ever male swimming gold medallist.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News"}, "authors": {"uri": "8251875752", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:33:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:33:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:32:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://extra.ie/2024/07/31/sport/sport-extra/olympics-daniel-wiffen-gold-medal", "title": "Paris Olympics: Daniel Wiffen pays tribute to family following gold medal triumph", "body": "Daniel Wiffen paid tribute to his family following his electric gold medal win in the men's 800m freestyle at the Paris Olympics.\n\nHaving come through his heat in a winning time of 7:41.53 seconds on Monday, the expectations were high for the The Magheralin man ahead of the final.\n\nAnd he put on a blistering display on Tuesday night to secure Ireland's first gold medal of the 2024 Games.\n\nWiffen was third at the 50 metre mark and only grew stronger as the race went on.\n\nHe nosed into second place 250 metres in and took the lead at the halfway point of the race before a thrilling finale saw him show great resilience and power to fend off Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri to come home first in lane four.\n\nSpeaking to RTE afterwards, he acknowledged his newfound title.\n\n'I mean amazing...I mean, what's my name? - Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion,' he said.\n\n'Sorry, it's really good, I cant believe it.\n\n'I want to thank everybody else - my brother Nathan and my parents, and my whole coaching staff in Loughborough - and the Irish team.\n\n'I couldn't do it with out anybody. I'm not alone out there [in the pool]. {"uri": "2024-07-438769542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "20:52:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T20:52:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:39:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.kentonline.co.uk/news/national/political-leaders-across-island-of-ireland-hail-history-maker-daniel-wiffen-124355/", "title": "Political leaders across island of Ireland hail history-maker Daniel Wiffen", "body": "Political leaders across the island of Ireland have hailed history-maker Daniel Wiffen after his gold medal victory in the Olympic swimming pool.\n\nWiffen, from the village of Magheralin in Northern Ireland, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nThe 23-year-old has become the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first-ever male swimming gold medallist.\n\nThe last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB Hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nThe 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little Pengelly congratulated the swimming hero.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement.\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris described Wiffen's performance as \"masterful\".\n\n\"On behalf of the entire country, hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen,\" he said.\n\n\"Daniel, you did it - Olympic gold and an Olympic record.\n\n\"The 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete. He's a world champion and now an Olympic champion, and it was our privilege to witness it.\n\n\"This is a family affair and I can only imagine the joy of Rachel, Jonathan and Nathan this evening. This is your victory too.\n\n\"Congratulations Daniel, we can't wait to see what you do next.\"\n\nDeputy premier Micheal Martin described the win as an \"outstanding performance\".\n\n\"A breathtaking race and a new Olympic record,\" he said.\n\n\"What an achievement for Daniel and his family.\"\n\nRichard Archibald, interim chief executive officer of Sport NI, said: \"After a 36-year wait Daniel Wiffen is bringing an Olympic gold medal home to Northern Ireland.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are immensely proud of Daniel and his achievements.\n\n\"We are proud to have supported Daniel at the start of his career through our National Lottery funded athlete award. His progress over the last few years has been incredible, with European and World titles as well as a coveted world record and now an Olympic record.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to us all and I am sure his win will encourage many young people across Northern Ireland to try their hand at swimming. With two more events to come the sky is the limit for Daniel and we wish him all the very best.\"\n\nWiffen's victory came a day after Sligo's Mona McSharry clinched a dramatic Olympic bronze medal all making the same joke as flags are raised after US swimmer Bob Finke secures silver in 800m freestyle", "body": "A trio of flags raised after the men's 800m freestyle had a number of people making jokes about Catholics in the northeastern United States.\n\nThe event saw an Irishman, Daniel Wiffen, take gold, an American, Bob Finke take silver, and an Italian, Gregorio Paltrinieri, take bronze.\n\nSo when the trio of flags were hoisted, it did not take long for jokes to come flooding in on social media.\n\n'Average Catholic school on the East Coast,' wrote one person on Twitter.\n\nAnother added: 'THE DEPARTED (2006)', in reference to the epic crime thriller movie set in Boston that focuses on Irish-Italian relations in the US and features Leonardo Di Caprio, Matt Damon, Jack Nicholson and Mark Wahlberg.\n\nThis trio of flags set off a series of tweets about Catholics in the northeastern United States\n\nDaniel Wiffen of Ireland (centre) pipped Bob Finke (left) and Gregorio Paltrinieri (right) to gold\n\nWiffen became the first Irishman to win gold in swimming at an Olympics\n\nOne fan was thinking exactly the same thing, writing: 'WORLD NEEDS PLENTY A BARTENDERS!!' - a famous line from the movie.\n\nOne viewer went along the same lines as they posted: 'BROOKLYN (2015),' a romantic film starring Saoirse Ronan who plays a young Irishwoman Eilis Lacey moving to the New York borough looking for work in the 1950s before she meets Italian-American Tony Fiorello.\n\nLacey is then told at a dinner with Fiorello's family by his younger brother that Italians don't like the Irish as they battled for jobs and housing in the US.\n\nOn Tuesday night, the three nations stood side-by-side on the podium, and the joke was not lost on one X user as they wrote: 'As an Irish-Italian (ex) catholic in new jersey... yeah.'\n\nMeanwhile, one viewer simply saw the image of the three flags and claimed: 'This is brilliant!!'\n\nInside the pool, it was a thrilling battle between Wiffen, Finke and Paltrinieri that went down to the final few metres.\n\nJokes were made about the relations between the Irish and Italians in the US after Tuesday's race, with one fan referring to the movie 'Brooklyn' that stars Saoirse Ronan (pictured)\n\nWith 100 metres to go it looked like Italy were set for the third gold medal in swimming when Paltrinieri took the lead, but Wiffen came storming back to touch first in a new Olympic record time.\n\nWiffen, who hails from County Armagh, became the first male swimmer from Northern Ireland to win an Olympic gold medal for Ireland.\n\nIt was also Ireland's first gold medal in the pool since 1996.\n\nHe stood at the top of the podium as Amhran na bhFiann - the Irish national anthem - played at a men's swimming event for the first time, and he could be back there again over the coming days.\n\nWiffen is due to compete in the 1500m freestyle and the open-water swimming event in Paris.\n\nUSA's Finke, who won gold in the 800m freestyle at the Tokyo Olympics, had to settle for silver this time around after an impressive final 50 metres, while it was bronze for Paltrinieri - who nabbed silver behind Finke in {"uri": "8252070953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:44:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:44:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:44:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/31/daniel-wiffens-delighted-parents-reflect-on-electric-olympic-night/", "title": "Daniel Wiffen's delighted parents reflect on 'electric' Olympic night", "body": "Rachel Wiffen tells of 'bit of a wobble' during dramatic Olympic final in Paris\n\nThe morning after Daniel Wiffen gloriously claimed Ireland's first gold medal of the Olympic Games in Paris, the swimmer's delighted mother, Rachel Wiffen, said: \"It's lovely to say you're the mum of an Olympian\".\n\n\"We're over the moon,\" she told RT\u00c9 radio's Morning Ireland on Wednesday while Daniel's father, Jonathan, said they were \"still reeling\" from their son's achievement. The family had spent the night celebrating with staff from Swim Ireland.\n\nThe Wiffens said they woke on Wednesday to numerous messages of congratulations from family, friends and acquaintances. \"We're only getting to see them now, so it's making me very emotional,\" said Ms Wiffen.\n\nThe family had been \"quite calm\" during the race, she said. The atmosphere was \"electric\" but at about the 400m stage she admitted she had \"a bit of a wobble\" and she did not know how the race was going to go. \"I knew it was going to be close.\" The last race that his parents had attended was in Doha when Daniel won in the World Championships after leading comfortably for much of the race. \"As a parent, that's the best position to be in, because you just know when they're that far in front, it's definitely going to be a win.\"\n\nWhen the whole family embraced Daniel after his win, Ms Wiffen said she told her son that they were very proud of him. She said she had been surprised at the weight of the Olympic medal.\n\n\"I would have been happy with a medal of any colour, but deep down we wanted gold.. He was quite clear in his interviews [before the race] that he wanted gold. You don't go into a race to lose.\"\n\n[ Ireland united in joy: Daniel Wiffen's Olympic gold reaches across the divideOpens in new window ]\n\nIt had been a very special moment when Sarah Keane of Swim Ireland presented the medal to Daniel. \"She turned around and gave us a big wave. So that was a very special moment, too, for her, Daniel, the family.\"\n\nThe best moment for Jonathan Wiffen was when Daniel and his twin Nathan embraced after the win. \"It was just lovely.\"\n\n\"They are very, very close. I know Nathan and Daniel speak when they're not together, almost hourly on FaceTime, and he speaks with his other brother and sister as well, quite regularly.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", {"uri": "8252414694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "12:09:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T12:09:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T12:08:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://extra.ie/2024/07/31/news/irish-news/daniel-wiffen-gold-olympics", "title": "Daniel Wiffen eyeing up more gold after smashing Olympic record", "body": "Daniel Wiffen had the nation on the edge of its seat on Tuesday night as he smashed an Olympic record in the men's 800m freestyle, securing Ireland's first gold medal of the Games.\n\nIn a thrilling race, the 23-year-old Armagh man thundered through the water, reeling in Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri and holding off a late charge from American Bobby Finke, to achieve a record-breaking time of 7:38:19.\n\nIt is the second medal for Ireland after Sligo's Mona McSharry secured a bronze in the 100m breaststroke on Monday.\n\nFailing to hide his smile, a breathless Wiffen said afterwards: 'I couldn't do it without my family, I wasn't alone out there.\n\n'I was looking for Finke all the time, I was looking over at Bobby Finke but I was not losing in the last 50 metres, I've been practising for that all year. Now I can say I am one of the best ever.'\n\nSpeaking poolside, a jubilant Wiffen added: 'I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight, but yeah, it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say! I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down? I heard my brother shout for me as soon as I walked out.\n\n'I heard none of the crowd, just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head. I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting \"Finked\" - I'm glad to say I haven't been \"Finked\", so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\n\n'It feels incredible. I'm writing myself into the history books!'\n\nWiffen - under coach Andi Manley at Loughborough University, where he is studying - became the first Irish man in history to win an Olympic swimming medal. Later he shed tears on the podium as Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann rang out in La D\u00e9fense Arena.\n\nSeconds after his triumph, hundreds of supporters took to social media to congratulate him, including T\u00e1naiste Miche\u00e1l Martin. 'Outstanding performance by Daniel Wiffen to win gold for Ireland this evening,' he said. 'Have just arrived in Paris and delighted to catch the race with our embassy team and sports administrators.'\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris said: 'On behalf of the entire country, hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen. Daniel, you did it - Olympic gold and an Olympic record. The 800metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a oncein-a-generation athlete.\n\n'He's a world champion and now an Olympic champion and it was our privilege to witness it. This is a family affair, and I can only imagine the joy of Rachel, Jonathan and Nathan this evening. This is your victory too.'\n\nWiffen's Olympics are not over, as he is going for another gold in the 1500m freestyle.\n\nAnd Ireland could soon have another medal in the bag, with 2020 gold winner Kellie Harrington set to fight on Thursday in a last-eight boxing match in which she can secure at least a bronze.\n\nThe Dubliner continues takes on the Colombian Angie Valdes Pana. Boxing fans will be able to watch a special screening of the fight at the Diamond Park Basketball Court in Dublin 1 from 4.30pm today.\n\nYesterday was another action-packed day of highs and lows for our Irish Olympians, who strove to make their country proud. In rowing, Philip Doyle and Daire Lynch booked their place in the final of the men's double sculls, taking place on Thursday.\n\nDoyle, from Belfast, said the race took a toll on his body, and that 'if your body isn't hurting coming through an Olympic semifinal, you're not doing it right'.\n\nThe pair are up for the main event on Thursday morning where they face reigning world champions Netherlands, Spain, Romania, New Zealand and the United States in the race for the gold.\n\nAt the canoe slalom, Kildare paddler Noel Hendrick advanced to the K1 semi-final, ranking 19th overall. The 26-year-old finished in a time of 90.68 seconds, with just one penalty for touching the fifth gate.\n\n'I had to put down the fastest run that I possibly could so it was freeing in a way, but also I just attacked all the way to the bottom and I'm really pleased,' he said afterwards.\n\nHowever, the Irish men's hockey team were left dejected after suffering their third loss in Paris.\n\nDespite making 13 shots during the 60-minute game, Mark Tumilty's men simply could not get the ball past India's star goalie PR Sreejesh, losing 2-0.\n\nHowever, all is not lost for the Irish side as they still have an opportunity to reach the quarterfinals, providing they beat Argentina on Thursday and New Zealand on Friday.\n\nIn boxing, Meath's Jennifer Lehane, 25, met a very experienced Chinese fighter on her Olympic 54kg debut, and ultimately lost 5-0 to Yuan Chang. However, she said the experience will only drive her on further.\n\n'I've never fought before as many people before in my life and in such an amazing venue,' she said. 'To hear so much support coming from the crowd was just incredible and I'll be forever grateful for that experience alone.'", "source": {"uri": "extra.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "Extra.ie"}, {"uri": "8251821492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "05:51:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T05:51:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T05:50:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/31/ireland-united-in-joy-daniel-wiffens-olympic-gold-reaches-across-the-divide/", "title": "Ireland united in joy: Daniel Wiffen's Olympic gold reaches across the divide", "body": "Daniel Wiffen's Olympic gold medal has united both traditions in Ireland in celebration like few events in Irish sporting history.\n\nWiffen, from the little village of Magheralin on the Down/Armagh border, is being claimed by the whole of Ireland.\n\nHe is the first individual athlete from Northern Ireland to win a gold medal since Mary Peters won the pentathlon at the Munich Olympics in 1972. Before Monday, the last Olympic gold medals won by competitors from the North had come courtesy of Jimmy Kirkwood and Stephen Martin, part of the Great Britain team that won gold in hockey at the Seoul Olympics in 1988.\n\nDeputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly was quick off the mark on X. \"Amazing!! Well done Daniel Wiffen - Northern Ireland's first individual gold since Lady Mary Peters in 1972! (and from Lagan Valley too!) What a result!\"\n\nBBC Northern Ireland warmed to the theme, also on X. \"36 years of waiting is over Daniel Wiffen wins gold in the 800m freestyle final. The first athlete from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold since 1988.\"\n\nWiffen's victory came on the same day as Belfast swimmer Jack McMillan won gold with Team GB in the men's 4x200m freestyle relay.\n\nThe North's First Minister Michelle O'Neill reached across the divide to congratulate both athletes. \"An historic day at the Olympics for local athletes, as Daniel Wiffen from Armagh and Jack McMillan from Belfast both win gold medals in swimming.\"\n\nArmagh has waited more than 22 years for sporting success and suddenly there was an All-Ireland and an Olympic gold medal within two days.\n\nArmagh GAA's official account reflected the ecstasy in the county. \"ARMAGH GOES GOLD AGAIN Here Daniel Wiffen's twin can be seen watching the Armagh game on Sunday before watching his brother grab Gold at the Paris Olympics today!! Well done to Daniel Wiffen! The pride of Armagh (past pupil of St Pat's Armagh) & Ireland along with our county players.\"\n\nSt Patrick's Grammar School in Armagh city has seven of the senior football squad who returned the Sam Maguire for the first time in 22 years.\n\nWiffen himself finally settled the argument as to whether he was from Armagh or Down by saying after winning gold. \"What can we say? We're All-Ireland champions and Olympic gold medallists. What a great county ...\"\n\nCongratulations from the Republic's politicians for Wiffen's achievement came firstly from President Michael D Higgins, who described it as a \"wonderful achievement of which he can be so proud\".\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris said Ireland was \"hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen. {"uri": "8251263005", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:56:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:56:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:55:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.newstalk.com/news/olympics-daniel-wiffen-takes-gold-for-ireland-in-800-metre-freestyle-1750631", "title": "Olympics: Daniel Wiffen takes Gold for Ireland in 800 Metre Freestyle | Newstalk", "body": "Ireland's Daniel Wiffen has won gold in the Men's 800 Metre Freestyle final at Paris 2024 in an Olympic record time.\n\nThe 23-year-old is Ireland's second medallist at the games after team mate Mona McSharry claimed bronze in the pool last night.\n\nWiffen, under coach Andi Manley at Loughborough University where he's studying, becomes the first ever Irish man in history to win an Olympic swimming medal.\n\nHe stormed to gold in a time of 7:38.19 - setting a new personal best, national record, and European record by a full second in the process.\n\nWiffen's performance also set a new Olympic record. knocking over three seconds off the previous one of 7:41.28 set by Mykhalo Romanchuk of Ukraine in Tokyo 2020.\n\nIn a nail-biting race Wiffen beat American Bobby Finke into second place, who touched in a time of 7:38.75, with Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri claiming bronze in 7:39.38.\n\nSpeaking poolside afterwards a jubilant Wiffen said: \"I don't think a lot of people actually believed me that I was going to do it tonight but yeah it was incredible. I've done it - that's all I want to say.\n\n\"I was so nervous, that's the most nervous I've ever been for a race but do you know what calmed me down? I heard by brother shout for me as soon as I walked out.\n\n\"I heard none of the crowd just him, and that's what calmed me down, and really levelled my head.\n\n\"I'm not going to lie, there's this whole saying going around that I'm getting 'Finked' - I'm glad to say I haven't been 'Finked\" so obviously pretty happy to get my hand on the wall first.\"\n\n\"It feels incredible. Andrew Bree said it just as I want to say it -'lights, camera, action' - that's exactly what I did - I'm writing myself into the history books,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "newstalk.com", Northern Ireland's First Individual Gold Since 1972", "body": "We saw the final of the men's 800m freestyle unfold tonight at the 2024 Olympic Games in Paris, France and the top contenders brought us a race to remember.\n\nWiffen was one of the favorites entering this final, owning the European Record with his mark of 7:39.19 established at the 2023 World Championships.\n\nBut Finke has proven a formidable competitor, having won this event 3 years ago at the 2020 Olympic Games in Tokyo.\n\nWiffen's time of 7:38.19 hacked exactly a second off his former European Record but also produced a new Olympic Record, easily overtaking the 7:41.28 Ukrainian Mykhailo Romanchuk put on the books in Tokyo.\n\nWith this gold medal, Wiffen became the first Irish Olympic champion in a swimming event in history.\n\nAdditionally, the Loughborough-trained Wiffen represents the first Northern Ireland athlete to top the Olympic podium across all sports since Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood accomplished {"uri": "8249154206", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "15:17:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T15:17:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T15:17:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/were-very-very-proud-daniel-wiffens-former-principal-says-swimmer-could-add-to-armagh-schools-sporting-glory-with-olympic-medal/a647290114.html", "title": "'We're very, very proud' - Daniel Wiffen's former principal says swimmer could add to Armagh school's sporting glory with Olympic medal", "body": "Swimmer Daniel Wiffen could add an Olympic medal to the haul of silverware heading home to Ulster this week, as he has stormed through to the 800m freestyle final in Paris.\n\nSt Patrick's Grammar School in Armagh which boasts seven of the senior football squad who returned the Sam Maguire to the Orchard County for the second time in history, while past pupil and world champion Daniel Wiffen has an Olympic medal within his grasp.\n\nThe 23 year-old won his heat in the 800m freestyle this morning and became the fastest qualifier with a time of 7:41.53 seconds, earning the man - who hails from the Down village of Magheralin - a place in Tuesday night's final.\n\nSt Patrick's principal Dominic Clarke said the school community is \"so proud\" as Armagh prepares to welcome the All-Ireland winners home and all eyes now turn to the podium in Paris, where an impressive and \"controlled\" 800m freestyle heat brings Wiffen even closer to his medal hopes.\n\nWiffen, who holds the world record in the 800m freestyle, will also compete in the 1500m free and in the historic 10km open swim in the Seine as part of his Olympic odyssey.\n\nHis twin brother Nathan, an accomplished swimmer in his own right, is \"an integral part of the whole thing and always has been\", said Mr Clarke, who recalls how both boys would wake at 5am to complete early morning swim sessions before school.\n\n\"When Covid was about to hit, the two boys were doing their A Levels and they had an opportunity to go to the National Aquatic Centre to go near enough to full-time swimming - and the family were obviously a wee bit concerned about the exams - and I remember saying at the time, 'You can do your exams any time, the opportunity to qualify for this Olympics may only come around once.'\"\n\nDaniel reached the grade to qualify for a scaled-back Olympics in Tokyo in 2021, his \"taking off\" point.\n\nSuccess in the Commonwealth Games, the European Championships and the World Championships -where he set the world record - has him well-placed for Paris.\n\n\"It shows the measure of the two boys that they did tough exams - they both did maths at A Level and both study computing - and put that alongside an almost professional training schedule. Their diligence and time management and application just can't be questioned,\" he said.\n\nThere is a \"great sense of pride\" around the twins at St Patrick's, where eyes are \"firmly\" on Paris as Daniel prepares for the 800m freestyle final and his 1500m freestyle heat.\n\n\"They are great kids. We're very, very proud of them,\" Mr Clarke said. \"We facilitated them as best we could, but their rise in swimming is down to their own dedicated and huge support from home, from their club, from the school.\n\n\"Swimming would be very much a minority sport in schools, but the two boys definitely raised it to a higher level, people would have been aware they were breaking Irish records even {"uri": "8252700532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:09:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:09:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/everyone-is-going-want-to-be-a-daniel-wiffen--swim-ulster-chief/", "title": "'Everyone is going want to be a Daniel Wiffen' - Swim Ulster chief", "body": "Stephen Cuddy described an incredible evening with Wiffen and Jack McMillan's swimming gold medals and said more could come.\n\nOlympic swimming gold medallist Daniel Wiffen has been described as an incredible role model for generations to come.\n\nNorthern Ireland had been without Olympic gold since 1988.\n\nBut that all changed when Wiffen and Jack McMillan won two gold medals within an hour during the swimming competition at the La Defense Arena in Paris on Tuesday night.\n\nWiffen, 23, from Magheralin close to Lurgan in Co Armagh, won gold in the men's 800m freestyle event competing for Team Ireland, while McMillan from Belfast won gold as part of the Team GB men's 4x200m freestyle relay team at the La Defense Arena.\n\nChief executive of Swim Ulster Stephen Cuddy described an amazing evening.\n\nHe also said there could be more medals to come with the competition continuing.\n\n\"We had an inkling that these two guys could do something special, but to get two gold medals in the one night within an hour of each other was something really spectacular,\" he said.\n\n\"Northern Ireland hasn't had a gold medal since 1988, so to add two to that, and then see Hannah (Scott) win another gold medal in the rowing, it's spectacular. It's quite surreal really.\n\n\"We're proud swimming was able to lead the way.\n\n\"Swimming obviously is not front and centre like golf or football or Gaelic Games or rugby, so it's a bit surreal seeing my Facebook and Twitter feed congratulating Daniel.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's not as if he's had people go before him that have led the way for him, he's led the way for everyone else.\n\n\"Everyone is going to want to be a Daniel Wiffen.\n\n\"Kids need role models and goodness me I don't think we could have a better role model than Daniel because he speaks very well, he's full of belief, he's just a really good news story in Ireland.\n\n\"Young swimmers starting off in Bangor, Lisburn, Ards or Larne, or any of those big clubs, have Olympic medallists to look up to now.\"\n\nLooking ahead, Mr Cuddy said he wouldn't rule Sligo's Mona McSharry out of adding to her 100m breaststroke bronze medal, as she takes part in the 200m breaststroke final on Wednesday evening, while Wiffen is set to compete in the 1,500m freestyle on Sunday.\n\n\"I would be hopeful that it'll perhaps not just be the three medals coming back,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251341244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:25:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:25:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:02:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13690543/Political-leaders-island-Ireland-hail-history-maker-Daniel-Wiffen.html", "title": "Political leaders across island of Ireland hail history-maker...", "body": "Political leaders across the island of Ireland have hailed history-maker Daniel Wiffen after his gold medal victory in the Olympic swimming pool.\n\nWiffen, from the village of Magheralin in Northern Ireland, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nThe 23-year-old has become the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first male swimming gold medallist.\n\nThe last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nThe 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete Taoiseach Simon Harris\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nOnly an hour after Wiffen's success another Northern Ireland swimmer secured a gold medal.\n\nWhile Jack McMillan did not participate in the Olympic 4x200m freestyle final that was won by Team GB swimmers Matt Richards, James Guy, Tom Dean and Duncan Scott, the 24-year-old from Co Down still secured a medal having swum for the team in the qualifying heats.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly congratulated both swimmers.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement.\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nOn McMillan's gold medal, they added: \"Well done to Jack and his @TeamGB\n\nteammates who have secured gold medals following the 4x200m freestyle relay. What an incredible Olympics for our local swimmers so far.\"\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris described Wiffen's performance as \"masterful\".\n\n\"On behalf of the entire country, hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen,\" he said.\n\n\"Daniel, you did it - Olympic gold and an Olympic record.\n\n\"The 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete. He's a world champion and now an Olympic champion, and it was our privilege to witness it.\n\n\"This is a family affair and I can only imagine the joy of Rachel, Jonathan and Nathan this evening. This is your victory too.\n\nIreland\u00b4s Daniel Wiffen stands for the national anthem after winning the men\u00b4s 800m freestyle final (John Walton/PA)\n\n\"Congratulations Daniel, we can't wait to see what you do next.\"\n\nDeputy premier Micheal Martin described Wiffen's win as an \"outstanding performance\".\n\n\"A breathtaking race and a new Olympic record,\" he said.\n\n\"What an achievement for Daniel and his family.\"\n\nRichard Archibald, interim chief executive officer of Sport NI, said: \"After a 36-year wait Daniel Wiffen is bringing an Olympic gold medal home to Northern Ireland.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are immensely proud of Daniel and his achievements.\n\n\"We are proud to have supported Daniel at the start of his career through our National Lottery funded athlete award. His progress over the last few years has been incredible, with European and World titles as well as a coveted world record and now an Olympic record.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to us all and I am sure his win will encourage many young people across Northern Ireland to try their hand at swimming. With two more events to come the sky is the limit for Daniel and we wish him all the very best.\"\n\nOn McMillan's achievement, he added: \"Jack played an integral role in the team securing their spot in tonight's final with the fastest qualifying time.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are proud to have supported Jack's journey to success through our Sport NI Sports Institute and National Lottery-funded Athlete Award.\"\n\nWiffen's victory came a day after Sligo's Mona McSharry clinched a dramatic Olympic bronze medal for Ireland in the final of the women's 100m breaststroke.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_record", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": {"uri": "8251390827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:51:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:51:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:49:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2024/07/31/olympics--ireland039s-wiffen-wins-men039s-800m-freestyle-gold-at-paris-2024-updated", "title": "Olympics | Ireland's Wiffen wins men's 800m freestyle gold at Paris 2024 (updated)", "body": "PARIS, July 30 (Xinhua) -- Ireland's Daniel Wiffen set a new Olympic record to clinch gold in the men's 800m freestyle at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday.\n\nWiffen surged home in the last 25 meters to win in seven minutes 38.19 seconds, smashing the previous Games record held by Ukraine's Mykhailo Romanchuk by more than three seconds. The result marked Ireland's first gold medal of the Games.\n\nBobby Finke of the U.S. took silver in 7:38.75, and Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri claimed bronze in 7:39.38.\n\n\"I always knew it was going to come. I didn't know what event it was going to be in, but I knew I was going to win one of them,\" a confident Wiffen said after the race. \"For it to be my first event is even better. I don't [know] how to sum it up, to be honest. Incredible.\"\n\n\"I knew exactly how the race was going to pan out. It was always going to be on my left, so I was looking that way the whole race,\" the 23-year-old added. \"Towards the end, I'm not going to lie. I knew I was going to win in the last 150 [meters]. {"uri": "8251379529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:37:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:37:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:36:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.leitrimobserver.ie/news/national-news/1567821/political-leaders-across-island-of-ireland-hail-history-maker-daniel-wiffen.html", "title": "Political leaders across island of Ireland hail history-maker Daniel Wiffen", "body": "Political leaders across the island of Ireland have hailed history-maker Daniel Wiffen after his gold medal victory in the Olympic swimming pool.\n\nWiffen, from the village of Magheralin in Northern Ireland, triumphed in the men's 800 metres freestyle final in Paris on Tuesday evening, setting a new Olympic record in the process.\n\nThe 23-year-old has become the first gold medallist from Northern Ireland for 36 years and Ireland's first male swimming gold medallist.\n\nThe last athletes from Northern Ireland to win Olympic gold were Stephen Martin and Jimmy Kirkwood, who were part of the winning Team GB hockey team at Seoul in 1988.\n\nWiffen is the first individual gold medallist from Northern Ireland since Mary Peters triumphed for GB in the pentathlon at Munich in 1972.\n\nOnly an hour after Wiffen's success another Northern Ireland swimmer secured a gold medal.\n\nWhile Jack McMillan did not participate in the Olympic 4x200m freestyle final that was won by Team GB swimmers Matt Richards, James Guy, Tom Dean and Duncan Scott, the 24-year-old from Co Down still secured a medal having swum for the team in the qualifying heats.\n\nStormont First Minister Michelle O'Neill and deputy First Minister Emma Little-Pengelly congratulated both swimmers.\n\n\"This is truly a momentous occasion for Daniel and for local sport,\" they said in a joint statement.\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first medal of the Games for our athletes and he set a new Olympic record. It was a fantastic performance by the @TeamIreland swimmer.\"\n\nOn McMillan's gold medal, they added: \"Well done to Jack and his @TeamGB\n\nteammates who have secured gold medals following the 4x200m freestyle relay. What an incredible Olympics for our local swimmers so far.\"\n\nTaoiseach Simon Harris described Wiffen's performance as \"masterful\".\n\n\"On behalf of the entire country, hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens, I would like to send our absolute admiration and congratulations to Daniel Wiffen,\" he said.\n\n\"Daniel, you did it - Olympic gold and an Olympic record.\n\n\"The 800-metre freestyle final in Paris was one for the ages and Daniel's technique, power and grit under pressure confirms him as a once-in-a-generation athlete. He's a world champion and now an Olympic champion, and it was our privilege to witness it.\n\n\"This is a family affair and I can only imagine the joy of Rachel, Jonathan and Nathan this evening. This is your victory too.\n\n\"Congratulations Daniel, we can't wait to see what you do next.\"\n\nDeputy premier Micheal Martin described Wiffen's win as an \"outstanding performance\".\n\n\"A breathtaking race and a new Olympic record,\" he said.\n\n\"What an achievement for Daniel and his family.\"\n\nRichard Archibald, interim chief executive officer of Sport NI, said: \"After a 36-year wait Daniel Wiffen is bringing an Olympic gold medal home to Northern Ireland.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are immensely proud of Daniel and his achievements.\n\n\"We are proud to have supported Daniel at the start of his career through our National Lottery funded athlete award. His progress over the last few years has been incredible, with European and World titles as well as a coveted world record and now an Olympic record.\n\n\"He is an inspiration to us all and I am sure his win will encourage many young people across Northern Ireland to try their hand at swimming. With two more events to come the sky is the limit for Daniel and we wish him all the very best.\"\n\nOn McMillan's achievement, he added: \"Jack played an integral role in the team securing their spot in tonight's final with the fastest qualifying time.\n\n\"At Sport NI we are proud to have supported Jack's journey to success through our Sport NI Sports Institute and National Lottery-funded Athlete Award.\"\n\nWiffen's victory came a day after Sligo's Mona McSharry clinched a dramatic Olympic bronze medal for Ireland in the final of the women's 100m breaststroke.", "source": {"uri": It was amazing.\n\n\"I think I have heard the national anthem more than a lot of people - it is my sixth time hearing it this season. So it is kind of crazy.\n\n\"I am just so happy.\"\n\nWiffen paid tribute to his twin brother Nathan - who he said had been calling him five times a day - and family after the race, adding \"It's amazing, just having them here... seeing them makes it so much better.\"\n\nNathan, who missed out on qualification, had helped Daniel train en route to his gold medal glory in Paris.\n\nThe 23-year-old had already shown his elite mentality after his win and compounded with a bullish predicition as he prepares to compete in two more events before the tournament's end.\n\nWiffen will {"uri": "8251235612", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "19:32:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T19:32:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T19:31:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/magheralins-daniel-wiffen-becomes-first-northern-irish-athlete-to-win-olympic-gold-since-1988/a84243612.html", "title": "Magheralin's Daniel Wiffen becomes first Northern Irish athlete to win Olympic Gold since 1988", "body": "Northern Ireland's 36-year wait for an individual gold medal at the Summer Olympics is over.\n\nMagheralin's Daniel Wiffen joined Lady Mary Peters and hockey stars Jimmy Kirkwood and Stephen Martin in the history books with a stunning performance inside La Defense Arena.\n\nThe Ireland swimmer stormed to victory in the 800m Freestyle Final in Paris with a time of 7.38.19, just 0.56 ahead of silver medalists American Bobby Finke. Wiffen's time set a new Olympic record. Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri took the bronze medal after leading the race for much of the way.\n\nThe 23 year-old is just the fourth person from Northern Ireland to win a gold medal at the Summer Games, and the first to strike gold in an individual event since Mary Peters won the Pentathlon in Munich in 1972.\n\nWiffen is also the first athlete raised in Northern Ireland to win an Olympic title in the green of Ireland.\n\nThe 800m Freestyle world champion qualified fastest for the final with an impressive time of 7:41.53 in Monday's heats.\n\nWiffen has a realistic chance of winning a second medal this weekend. He will compete in the heats of the 1500m on Saturday morning, with the final set for 5.36pm on Sunday evening. He is also the current world champion over that distance.\n\nThe Irish swimmer will round-off his Olympic journey on Friday August 9 when he competes in the Men's Swimming Marathon.", "source": {"uri": "8251882261", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:38:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:38:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:37:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/tearful-daniel-wiffen-makes-irish-history-with-olympic-gold", "title": "Tearful Daniel Wiffen makes Irish history with Olympic gold", "body": "PARIS - Daniel Wiffen made history on July 30 as the first Irishman to win an Olympic swimming gold medal, shedding tears as the enormity of the achievement sunk in.\n\nThe 23-year-old hit the wall first in 7min 38.19sec, the fifth-fastest time ever, to be crowned 800m freestyle champion at the La Defense Arena. The only other gold won by Ireland in an Olympic pool came at Atlanta in 1996 when Michelle Smith collected three.\n\nWiffen, also the first Irish male swimmer to win a medal of any colour, could not hide his emotions when the national anthem played as he stood on top of the podium.\n\n\"I don't normally cry, so I really hope that nobody's gonna see that,\" he said.\n\n\"But, yeah, it did come out of me, and it's obviously just a special moment.\n\n\"I've never heard that national anthem at an Olympics before, and it's just crazy to say that it was me standing on a No. 1 podium here for the first time.\"\n\nWiffen, who also won the 800m at the World Championships in Doha in 2024, came home ahead of American defending Olympic champion Bobby Finke (7:38.75) and Tokyo silver medallist Gregorio Paltrinieri (7:39.38) of Italy.\n\nHe took control at 400m after Australia's Elijah Winnington went out hard but tired and was reeled in. Paltrinieri made at a move at 600m and led to the final turn before Wiffen came roaring back to rewrite history.\n\n\"My first part of the race was absolutely terrible. My stroke was all over the place, I was just so nervous,\" he said.\n\n\"But luckily I had a good enough speed to keep it going and I was still in the race. Then my goal was to keep building.\"\n\nThe Irishman paid tribute to his identical twin brother Nathan, also a distance swimmer who missed out on qualification for Paris, for urging him on.\n\n\"I tell you what, the only voice I heard in the crowd was my twin brother Nathan's,\" he added.\n\n\"I've dreamt of this every day of my life. I know that I seem very confident on the outside, but there's always that little tiny feeling that, you know, can I do this?\"\n\nIn other events, Australian Kaylee McKeown crushed Regan Smith to extend her reign over the 100m backstroke, while Great Britain capped the night session on Day 4 by retaining their men's 4x200m freestyle relay crown.\n\nBritain's late triumph was their first gold medal of the Paris swimming meet and condemned the United States to a second straight day without a title. Instead, the Americans had to settle for minor medals in all three events.\n\nMcKeown's strong back-end pace made the difference again as she mowed down Smith and American bronze-winner Katharine Berkoff to retain her own 100m title in an Olympic record time of 57.33sec.\n\nIn the relay the quartet of James Guy, Tom Dean, Matthew Richards and Duncan Scott then kept the gold medal in British hands, beating the Americans by 1.35sec, with Australia taking the bronze. Daniel Wiffen secures first place and breaks Olympic record in swimming final", "body": "It's gold and an Olympic record for the Irish swimmer Daniel Wiffen, who smashed the final and managed to beat his conteders in a closely-contested 800 metres final.\n\nWhile it had looked like Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri had worked his way into position and was going to hold off Wiffen and Finke, the Irishman turned on the power, utilising his big kick to power home for glory.\n\nThe swimmer, from Magheralin in County Down, hit the finish line at 7 minutes and 38.19 seconds, smashing the previous Olympic record.\n\nThe time is also the fifth-fastest time ever recorded in the 800m swim.\n\nThere were high hopes for Wiffen ahead of his trip to Paris, with the swimmer recently breaking the {"uri": "8252259404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:38:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:38:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:38:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jul/31/ireland-basks-in-glory-of-olympic-swimming-success", "title": "Ireland basks in glory of Olympic swimming success", "body": "Daniel Wiffen won gold in 800m freestyle 24 hours after Mona McSharry's bronze in 100m breaststroke\n\nNorthern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland have been basking in the glory of Daniel Wiffen's Olympic swimming success.\n\nOn Tuesday night the English-born and Northern Ireland-raised athlete - who swims for Team Ireland - powered his way to gold medal success and an Olympic record in the 800m freestyle final.\n\nHis success came just 24 hours after another Irish swimmer, Mona McSharry, won bronze in the 100m breaststroke final.\n\nThe Irish president, Michael D Higgins, described Wiffen's performance as \"a wonderful achievement\" while the taoiseach, (Irish prime minister) Simon Harris, said on X that the entire country \"is hoarse from screaming at their televisions and computer screens\".\n\nNorthern Ireland's first minister, Michelle O'Neill, and deputy first minister, Emma Little-Pengelly, described Wiffen's gold medal performance as \"a truly momentous occasion\".\n\n\"Not only has he secured NI's first Olympic gold medal in 36 years, it is also the first of the Games for our athletes, and he set a new Olympic record,\" they added.\n\nIt has also been a good week for the school Wiffen attended.\n\nSaint Patrick's grammarschool in Armagh city provided seven of the county's squad that won the GAA all-Ireland football final against Galway on Sunday.\n\nThe school principal, Dominic Clarke, told RT\u00c9 radio that everyone at the school was still \"on the crest of a wave\" after Wiffen's win.\n\n\"It's just an absolutely fantastic achievement and it's just reward for the effort he's put in since he was a kid,\" he added.\n\nMany people in Ireland were struck by the confidence of the swimmer before the final.\n\nIn interviews afterwards he said: \"My birthday is on Bastille Day and it's 100 years since Ireland first competed at the Olympics. There was meant to be a storm at nine o'clock, and I'll tell you what, it was the 100 metre freestyle.\"\n\nWatched on by his family including his twin brother, Nathan, who is also a swimmer, Wiffen came from behind, took the lead, and fell behind again before storming past his rivals to victory.\n\nBack home, radio and television stations had live broadcasts from swimming clubs and places associated with Ireland's first male gold medal winner in the sport.\n\nWiffen follows in the footsteps of Michelle Smith de Bruin who won three golds at the 1996 Atlanta games, but a shadow was cast over her achievements after she was banned for four years for manipulating an anti-doping sample by deliberate contamination with alcohol.\n\nAnd he may not be finished yet, with at least one more event to come.\n\n\"We're not done here. I can't wait for the 1500 metres freestyle. The family had spent the night celebrating with the staff from Swim Ireland.\n\nFollowing their late night, the family had awoken to numerous messages of congratulations from family, friends and acquaintances.\n\n\"We're only getting to see them now, so it's making me very emotional,\" added Ms Wiffen.\n\nThe family had been \"quite calm\" during the race, she said. The atmosphere was \"electric\" but at about the 400m stage she admitted she had \"a bit of a wobble\" and she did not know how the race was going to go. \"I knew it was going to be close.\"\n\nThe last race that his parents had attended was in Doha when Daniel won in the World Championships where he had been far in front.\n\n\"As a parent, that's the best position to be in, because you just know when they're that far in front, it's definitely going to be a win.\"\n\nWhen the whole family embraced Daniel after his win, Ms Wiffen said she told her son that they were very proud of him. She said she had been surprised at the weight of the Olympic medal.\n\n\"I would have been happy with a medal of any colour, but deep down we wanted gold. He was quite clear in his interviews (before the race) that he wanted gold. You don't go into a race to lose.\"\n\nIt had been a very special moment when Sarah Kane of Swim Ireland presented the medal to Daniel. \"She turned around and gave us a big wave. So that was a very special moment, too, for her. Daniel, the family.\"\n\nThe best moment for Jonathan Wiffen was when Daniel and his twin Nathan embraced after the win. \"It was just lovely.\"\n\n\"They are very, very close. I know Nathan and Daniel speak when they're not together, almost hourly on FaceTime, and he speaks with his other brother and sister as well, quite regularly.\"\n\nThe Principal of St Patrick's Grammar School in Armagh has told of his delight at the haul of medals by former pupils in recent days with Daniel Wiffen's gold at the Olympics and seven past pupils were also members of the All-Ireland winning Armagh football panel.\n\n\"Sport plays a very, very big part in the school. And this is definitely a big, big lift for the whole school community and in the city and all around. So we're over the moon. We're very, very happy,\" he told RT\u00c9 radio's Morning Ireland.\n\nMr Clarke said that Daniel Wiffen's Olympic medal win was a \"just reward\" for all the efforts he and his twin Nathan had put in since they were teenagers. A number of years ago they participated in an interview for the school during which they stated their ambitions to go to the Olympics.\n\n\"I look forward to digging that interview out again to present that to the two boys because now here we are. A new reality has set in. And not only is Daniel Olympic champion, he's also Olympic record holder. And as he said himself, there's more to come. So we're just absolutely delighted for Daniel, Nathan and all of his family. And we're very, very, very proud here.\"\n\nThe Wiffen brothers had been very diligent in their swim training and had also applied themselves to their studies, he said.
