{"uri": "8251147061", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "18:17:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T18:17:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T18:15:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/northern-ireland/excitement-mounting-as-armagh-man-daniel-wiffen-goes-for-gold-in-swimming-final-6GG2T2ANHVDNFCLGQ2XXZCIMIE/", "title": "Excitement mounting as Armagh man Daniel Wiffen goes for gold in swimming final", "body": "The Mageralin man will be off the blocks just after 8pm as he competes in the 800m freestyle final\n\nExcitement is mounting ahead of this evening's 800 metre men's freestyle final as Daniel Wiffen attempts to win Team Ireland's first gold medal of the Olympics.\n\nThe 23-year-old from Magheralin in Co Armagh, the world record holder at the distance, is the bookie's 10/11 to win after recording the fastest time in the semi-finals.\n\nDaniel's swimming club, Larne, is hosting a watch party at Portmuck Bay near Islandmagee while all his family have decamped to Paris for the games.\n\nEveryone in Magheralin, which straddles the border of Armagh and Down, is hoping for victory, said Catriona Hughes, chair of the local community association. There is no gathering planned to watch the final but something might be happening on his return, Ms Hughes said.\n\nCurrently studying in Loughburough University and training as a member of their elite program under coach Andi Manley, Daniel is hoping to follow Mona McSharry on to the podium after her third place finish in the 100m breast stroke on Monday\n\nAnother Larne Swimming Club member, Newtownabbey's Danielle Hill, is also competing in the games, qualifying for the semi finals in the 100m backstroke but missing out on a final spot. She will compete in the 50m freestyle heats on Saturday, while Daniel will be focussing on the 1500m freestyle on the same day.\n\nJack McMillan, from Belfast, swims in a final this evening as a member of Team GB's 4x200m relay team.\n\nDaniel, a former pupil at St Patrick's Grammar in Armagh City, won the 800m and 1500m freestyle gold at the World Aquatic Championships in Doha in February.\n\n\"If I didn't come away with a medal I would be very disappointed,\" Daniel said ahead of the Olympics.\n\n\"Going in with the times that I've produced, with my PBs (personal bests), they would just put me on the podium if I can replicate them. I've done it time and time again so we'll just keep doing what we are doing.\"\n\nAll of the Wiffen family have travelled to Paris for the games, including twin brother Nathan who narrowly missed on Olympic qualification. Mother Rachel and father Jonathan along with siblings Ben and Beth are also in Paris.\n\nDerry McVeigh, of Silver Hatch Sports, which represents both Daniel and Nathan, said the family is incredibly close and supportive.\n\n\"Daniel will be in camp but the relationship between the members of the family is that they will be on to each other five or 10 times a day,\" Mr McVeigh said.\n\nHe added that the swimmer brings \"incredible positivity\" to the camp, that he has \"real leadership qualities\" and a \"can do it\" attitude.\n\nBrother Ben, six years older and a one time Irish 1500 metre medallist, was an early inspiration to the twins and is now a swimming coach in Enniskillen.\n\nRachel and Jonathan Wiffen, originally from Liverpool and Leeds respectively, moved to Magheralin when the twins were two.\n\nMr Wiffen spent some years working abroad so much of the work of helping to develop the twins' talent fell to their mother.\n\nWhile they were growing up, the both trained twice a day, three days a week, and once a day three other days, then with competitions at the weekends.\n\nMr Manley, Daniel's head coach at Loughborough University, said the swimmer knows how his rivals will swim and that they have covered \"all the 'what if' scenarios\" to ensure he has reached peak performance.\n\n\"Anything can happen, but in terms of what we're focusing on, it's just going to be delivering the best race possible for him,\" said Mr Manley.\n\n\"We know how his rivals will swim it. We've been talking about that a lot over the last 18 months, in terms of all the 'what if' scenarios, and how to go about that. But I think he's at a level now where he shouldn't be fearful of anyone.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252240439", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:28:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:28:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:27:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/news/northern-ireland/who-is-daniel-wiffen-the-armagh-swimmer-who-snapped-up-gold-at-the-olympics-2M77XEXOXFGXRHHPQFIOF3CAZE/", "title": "Who is Daniel Wiffen? The Armagh swimmer who snapped up gold at the Olympics", "body": "Wiffen won gold on the fourth day of the Paris Olympics breaking a series of records in the process\n\nThe Magheralin-born swimmer was confident after his first swim in Paris, confidently remarking he thought his time would have been \"a little faster\". He went on to do just that in the final, snagging a gold medal in the men's 800m freestyle final, breaking a series of records in the process.\n\nHere's what you need to know about the Olympic gold medallist.\n\nThe 23-year-old was born in London but moved to Magheralin, on the border between Co Down and Co Armagh, when he was two-years-old.\n\nDaniel and his identical twin brother Nathan started swimming locally with Lurgan SC before moving to Lisburn SW for age-group swimming.\n\nNathan is also a world-class swimmer in his own right, and is a multiple Irish gold medallist.\n\nDaniel then moved to the club at Loughborough University, where he studies IT and Business, becoming a distance superstar.\n\nHis first major medal was a Commonwealth silver in the 1500m freestyle in 2022.\n\nA year later he placed fourth in both the 800m and 1500m at the World Championships in 2023, with a new European record in the 800m. Later that year, he won three gold medals at the European SC Championships, breaking Grant Hackett's world record.\n\nIn February 2024, he became the first Irish swimmer to medal at a World Championships and won double world titles in the 800m and 1500m. On his Olympic debut in Tokyo, he set new Irish records in the 800m and 1500m freestyle.\n\nDaniel blazed home in a time of 7:38.19 - setting a new Olympic record in the process as well as a new personal best, national record and European record by a full second.\n\nIn a nail-biting finale the he beat Tokyo 2020 gold medallist American Bobby Finke into second place, with Italian Gregorio Paltrinieri taking bronze.\n\nHe became the first athlete from the north to win an Olympic gold medal in 36 years, and the first individual gold medallist since 1972.\n\nHe also became the first Olympian from the north to win Olympic god for Ireland and the first Olympian from Team Ireland to win a gold medal in swimming since 1996.", "source": {"uri": "irishnews.com", "dataType": "news", Magheralin is on the border of Armagh and Down, and while both counties may claim him, he is happy to add Armagh's All-Ireland final triumph on Sunday as more fuel for his bid for Olympic medals in the coming days.\n\nWiffen could even add more medals to his tally in the days to come as he competes in the 1500m freestyle and 10km open water. The 7:39.19 he set when finishing fourth in last year's World Championships in Fukuoka stands as a European record.\n\nHe made it to tonight's final by posting the third-fastest 800m time of his career, earning him the opportunity to become the first Northern Irish athlete to win Individual Olympic gold since Lady Mary Peters' pentathlon win in 1972.\n\nThe final will be live on RT\u00c92 and {"uri": "8251020847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "16:39:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T16:39:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:37:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/he-told-me-he-was-going-to-swim-in-the-olympics-one-day-ex-coach-hails-daniel-wiffen-as-irish-swimming-star-goes-for-gold-in-paris/a924582906.html", "title": "'He told me he was going to swim in the Olympics one day' - ex-coach hails Daniel Wiffen as Irish swimming star goes for gold in Paris", "body": "Irish swimmer Daniel Wiffen has shown a \"relentless ambition\" that puts an Olympic medal well within his grasp, his former swimming coach has said.\n\nThe 23-year-old from Magheralin, Co Down, who holds the world record in the 800m freestyle, will compete in the Olympic final just after 8pm tonight.\n\nHe is considered one of Ireland's greatest gold medal hopes at the games, where he could follow bronze medallist Mona McSharry onto the podium after her stellar performance in the 100m breaststroke final last night.\n\nStan Sheppard, a coach at Lisburn Swimming Club, where Daniel and his twin brother Nathan honed their talents, said the Olympian has always had a fierce, competitive drive that has now brought him within reach of a medal.\n\nMr Sheppard had taught both boys to swim some years before they joined the club in 2012, something he had not realised until they came to him and told him how they remembered those early lessons.\n\n\"Daniel was always very confident and ambitious, he has always backed himself and he has always been a worker,\" said Mr Sheppard.\n\n\"He probably said to me when he was a kid, 'I'm going to swim in the Olympics one day, I'm going to break a world record,' those sorts of things.\n\n\"He would have said it and it might have been a wee bit tongue and cheek, but he has always had this relentless ambition to improve and be better and be the best. He set himself up for what might seem like unrealistic tasks but he would go after them with a steely determination that is very rare.\n\n\"He definitely does have the mentality of someone who could be an Olympic champion, there is no doubt about that.\"\n\nMr Sheppard said children watching the Paris Olympics at home will now be looking up to Wiffen - and bronze medallist McSharry - and see the success they have found in swimming.\n\n\"It's tangible. The kids can see these people that live and breathe on the island of Ireland, who spent their formative years here and were able then to bridge across into high performance centres and be world-class athletes,\" he said.\n\nWiffen is well-placed to earn a place on the podium, with final preparations ensuring that he is in a position to \"deliver the best race possible\" in the pool in Paris.\n\nHis head coach at Loughborough University, Andi Manley, said Wiffen has studied the type of race his rivals will swim, and they have covered \"all the 'what if' scenarios\" to ensure he has reached peak performance.\n\n\"Anything can happen, but in terms of what we're focusing on, it's just going to be delivering the best race possible for him,\" said Mr Manley.\n\n\"We know how his rivals will swim it. We've been talking about that a lot over the last 18 months, in terms of all the 'what if' scenarios, and how to go about that. But I think he's at a level now where he shouldn't be fearful of anyone.\n\n\"We've done the work and he's ready to go and swim real fast. And we just need it all to happen in that seven and a half minutes on the night.\"\n\nAn occasion like an Olympic final is rare, an event so filled with emotion, pressure and expectation that many athletes can allow it to get the better of them.\n\nSpeaking on his way to Paris to watch Wiffen attempt to take home a medal, Mr Manley was confident the swimmer will \"step up\" in the arena, with a walk-out in front of 15,000 spectators \"all adding to his performance rather than taking away\".\n\n\"It has been phenomenal. He has just consistently gotten better year-on-year,\" said Mr Manley. \"He has momentum coming into this, he is a guy on an upward trajectory and it has all been part of our plan with the goals we have set along the way.\"", "source": {"uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Belfast Telegraph"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8252608342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "14:09:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T14:09:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T14:09:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/sport/paris-2024/2024/0731/1462858-paris-2024-wiffen-hardly-slept-after-olympic-gold-win/", "title": "Paris 2024: Wiffen hardly slept after Olympic gold win", "body": "Olympic gold medallist Daniel Wiffen said he hardly slept after his 800m freestyle triumph.\n\nThe 23-year-old Armagh man stormed the final stretch in the La Defense Arena to clinch gold in an Olympic record time last night.\n\nAfter receiving his medal on the podium, Wiffen said he went straight into anti-doping and then the swim-down before treating himself to some pizza.\n\n\"We left the pool at 12.30am, got back into the dining hall, had a couple slices of pizza, then tried to go to bed - did not happen,\" he said.\n\n\"Got to bed at about 3.30am and woke up at 7.30 this morning. I didn't get too much sleep but that's not surprising.\n\n\"I watched it (the race) before I went to sleep because I knew I wouldn't sleep so I watched it and I'm very happy, it was paced to perfection, that's all we can ask for.\"\n\n\"Words can't describe how you feel when you wake up and next to your pillow is an Olympic gold medal,\" he added.\n\nWiffen's family - including his twin brother Nathan - were poolside to witness his stunning victory.\n\nHe said: \"It was amazing to see my twin brother in the crowd, you can't ask for more than that, then my whole family being there.\n\n\"Words just can't describe, seeing my mum crying and that setting me off. And the national anthem, tears going down my face. I've kind of forgotten it because it's gone so quick, but it's so cool.\n\n\"My parents have been driving me to 4.30am practice, it's been a relentless journey. I've been doing this since I was at least 12-years-old and they kept doing it for me and they're the reason I'm here today.\n\n\"They're a massive part, and that's why I say it's never an individual sport, swimming, I've got this whole support network behind me.\"\n\nRead more: Meet Daniel Wiffen - Ireland's gold medal winning swimmer\n\nWiffen will now be eyeing more success in the 1500m freestyle, with the heats due to start on Saturday morning.\n\nHe said he will return to training tonight and temporarily put his 800m win \"under the bed\".\n\n\"I'm taking it in my stride, the 1500 is in a couple of days. Today is about getting all the emotions out and then tonight I'll get back to training. I wanted to swim this morning, I miss the pool already.\n\n\"I'm going to refocus, forget about this race, put it under the bed after this morning and I'll revisit it when I'm finished,\" he added.\n\nWatch the 2024 Olympic Games with 14 hours of televised action on RT\u00c92 and RT\u00c9 Player each day.\n\nListen to extensive radio coverage on RT\u00c9 Radio 1 and 2fm's Game On and follow each moment from Paris on RT\u00c9.ie, the RT\u00c9 News app and all RT\u00c9 digital platforms. Sinead O'Carroll Reports from Paris\n\nHIS GESTURE TOLD the crowd at La Defense Arena in Paris that he was going to write himself into the history books over the next eight minutes.\n\nBut he told reporters after taking gold in the 800m men's freestyle Olympic final that it had been written in the stars all along.\n\nAnd he came with evidence:\n\nWhen he emerged from the call room this evening, the only voice he heard in the crowd was that of his twin brother Nathan. He said it calmed him, levelled his emotions.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n14 July is his birthday and Bastille Day. And it's been 100 years since Ireland first competed - and that was in Paris.\n\nThere was a storm due tonight at 9pm. \"We're renaming that storm, Storm Daniel,\" he told his coach earlier, remarking at the timing of his final.\n\nAnd, lastly on his list of fate, were his fellow county men who walked up the steps of the Hogan Stand just last Sunday to collect the Sam Maguire.\n\n\"What can you say, we're All-Ireland champions and Olympic gold medalists - what a great county,\" he said tonight.\n\nArmagh GAA didn't miss a beat, celebrating his achievement on X.\n\n\"Well done to Daniel Wiffen! {"uri": "8252518798", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "13:13:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T13:13:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T13:12:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.irishnews.com/sport/i-was-absolutely-screaming-so-i-hope-he-could-hear-me-daniel-wiffens-family-revel-in-golden-moment-in-paris-HPWQO2ME4FCJBNGWZKJBHYEPBI/", "title": "'I was absolutely screaming so I hope he could hear me': Daniel Wiffen's family revel in golden moment in Paris", "body": "Magheralin swimmer has already claimed 800m gold, and hopes to add 1500m at weekend\n\nTHE Billy Billy bar just outside Le Defense Arena has seen an Irish invasion in recent days - with the family of Daniel Wiffen family popping Champagne to celebrate his incredible exploits in the pool.\n\nJust 24 hours before friends and family of Mona McSharry had partied into the early hours after the Sligo swimmer claimed Ireland's first medal of Paris 2024 with a brilliant bronze in the 100m breaststroke.\n\nAnd Wiffen raised it up another gear when he took gold in the 800m freestyle event to bring the arena to its feet. Watching from the wings was twin brother Nathan, who expected it to be a clearer win for his brother after a dramatic finish saw Wiffen just hold off defending American champion Bobby Finke.\n\n\"Maybe at 300 I was like 'oh it's a bit close here, I thought it would be way more'. But on the last 200 to 100 I was like 'ah he's got it in the bag here', because he had a good place, strategic placing in terms of who was behind him and who was in front of him.\"\n\nThe Magheralin man admitted nerves had seen him struggle to find his stroke in the opening 300m, but said the sound of Nathan's voice helped him settle into the race.\n\n\"I heard about his interview - I thought that was a pretty nice thing to say.\n\n\"I was absolutely screaming, so I hope he could hear me to be absolutely honest. To go on to the race, what they always say is champions adapt and he is Olympic champion and he adapted to win.\n\n\"That's a pretty good thing to say you're Olympic champion.\"\n\nThe 23-year-old shed a tear as Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann rang out around a packed arena, with his family following suit in the stands.\n\n\"My eyes start welling up any time I see a newspaper article or anything now,\" said dad Jonathan.\n\n\"Every time I read something or see something, my eyes start filling up. I wouldn't say I was an emotional guy, I was the same Nathan was at the European Championships and came fourth, my eyes were welling up then.\n\n\"It's just dream stuff to see your kids do so well. It's just phenomenal.\"\n\nAnd it was reward too for Jonathan and wife Rachel who, even when he was working in India for six years, ferried the twins across the country to sow the seeds for what unfolded on Tuesday night.\n\n\"There were weekends I was working in India, Rachel was up and down to Limerick for a competition, it was just everything to keep it going. Then I'd come back and Rachel would go 'you're doing mornings now', so I'd go and start work while they were swimming at five in the morning.\n\n\"Somebody said to me that they both had the chance to go an Olympics, so one of the reasons Daniel and Nathan didn't really come out [to India] was because of the swimming... I thought 'I don't want to take them out there and ruin their chance of going to the Olympics'.\n\n\"I know coaches always say that to kids, but if they've got a chance, do I want to ruin that? So I just commuted from India. It's having that determination and that strength to say 'hold on, that's what we want to do'.\n\nNext up is the 1500m heat on Saturday morning, with Wiffen planning to add a remarkable second gold to his ever-growing collection.\n\n\"Let's hope he can re-focus for that,\" smiled Nathan, \"I'll wind him in.\"", "source": {"uri": "irishnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish News"}, {"uri": "8251344034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "21:04:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T21:04:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T21:04:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/2024/07/30/a-very-golden-night-in-irish-sporting-history-leaves-many-in-tears/", "title": "A very golden night in Irish sporting history leaves many in tears", "body": "'He hasn't gone to the legs, it's all about the arms,\" John told us, at which point the nation was hollering 'GO TO THE LEGS' at their telly screens\n\nSam Maguire on Sunday, an Olympic gold medal on Tuesday, they'll be worn out from the celebrating in Armagh. \"Are you sensing a momentous night in Irish sporting history,\" Joanne Cantwell had asked Gr\u00e1inne Murphy. \"I ...... think so,\" she replied, with a small bit of trepidation, no more than ourselves gripped by our national inclination to resist losing the run of ourselves.\n\nBut as it proved it was indeed a momentous - and very golden - night in Irish sporting history.\n\nO'Connell, O'Donnell and now Wiffen, our history is peppered with high-achieving Daniels, but with all due respect to The Liberator and the Wee fella from Kincasslagh, they never blew seven opponents out of an Olympic swimming pool.\n\nIn fairness to Andrew Bree, he had a notion Wiffen would do just that. \"He will absolutely relish the moment, this is like Russell Crowe walking into the stadium, Gladiator style. 'Are you not entertained?'\"\n\nWe were. But as Andrew put it after, \"I nearly passed out - thanks Mr Wiffen.\" Did you ever see a race like it?\n\nJohn Kenny warned us from the off not to panic if Wiffen started at a leisurely-ish pace, that he'd rev it up as the race progressed, but then Elijah Winnington and Ahmed Jaqouadi took off like trains leaving our lad in third, a position he lost when Sven Schwarz overtook him. Panic? Too right.\n\n\"He hasn't gone to the legs, it's all about the arms,\" John told us, at which point the nation was hollering \"GO TO THE LEGS\" at their telly screens, and he must have heard our sage advice, because by the halfway point he was in the lead.\n\n\"DON'T DISCOUNT PALTRINIERI,\" John howled, which was daft because the Italian was nowhere to be seen. And then he tried to multiply our heebie-jeebies by pointing out that \"FINKE IS A DANGEROUS LAST 100m SWIMMER!\" Nuts, he was closer to drowning than competing for a medal.\n\nAnd then Paltrinieri took the lead and Finke was threatening to deny Wiffen even a silver.\n\nThereafter. He's some boy, this lad. He waltzed in to the arena like he was heading for a stroll in the local park, his twin Nathan reassuring Clare MacNamara pre-race that he'd be completely chilled about it all. They are, incidentally, the most identical twins known to man, calling to mind their appearance on The Late Late Show a while back. \"For all you know, I'm actually Nathan,\" Daniel said to Patrick Kielty. Which would have led you to wondering was that Nathan in the pool and Daniel cheering him on from the stands.\n\nThose last couple of pool lengths? Epic is too light a word, Wiffen's efforts belonging to the ages, utterly magnificent.\n\n\"What did we just witness,\" asked Joanne, Gr\u00e1inne laughing at the spectacle she had just witnessed, in an entirely disbelieving kind of way, Andrew with his head in his hands. \"What's going on,\" he asked, Joanne revealing that he spent the concluding spell of the race slapping his legs and Gr\u00e1inne's.\n\nHe thought the gold was gone. \"But then with about 125 to go, he bounces off the wall, ba ba ba ba, see ya!\" Which was a perfect summary of how it all ended, really. \"It was,\" said Gr\u00e1inne,\" a perfect race\", although our heart rate monitors might beg to differ.\n\nWhen Wiffen spoke to RT\u00c9 immediately after the race there wasn't a bother on him, like he never had a moment's doubt that he could do what he just did. \"Now I can say I'm one of the best ever,\" he said with the gentlest of smiles.\n\n\"Even the make-up artist upstairs said I've never met a more confident person in my life,\" Andrew laughed.\n\nMedal ceremony time. We don't get to hear Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann a whole lot at these Olympic occasions, so John was entirely lying when he said \"you're crying, I'm not crying\". The bulk of us, you'd guess, were in floods. Even the Wiffen man. He might have entered that pool knowing he would win, but the realisation that he'd done just that left him in tears. {"uri": "8251429547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "22:34:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T22:34:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T22:33:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.businessnews.com.au/article/2024-Paris-Olympics-Wednesday-wrap", "title": "2024 Paris Olympics: Wednesday wrap", "body": "Australia enjoyed another successful day of swimming, while the women's rugby sevens team narrowly missed out on a bronze medal.\n\nAn outpouring of raw emotion - both happiness and sadness - prevailed across several venues at the 2024 Paris Olympic Games on Wednesday morning.\n\nAt a jam-packed Stade de France, Australia's women's rugby sevens team left the field heartbroken, after being defeated 19-14 by the US in the bronze medal match.\n\nStill stung from their 21-12 semifinal defeat against Canada a few hours earlier, the Australians looked to have done enough, following a try to Maddison Levi with less than 90 seconds left to play.\n\nNeeding to travel 85m to tie the game, US jet Alex Sedrick broke a tackle in the shadows of her own goalposts and raced clear to cross under the posts at the other end as time expired.\n\nWhile the Australians players fell to the turf and pondered the agony of defeat, the American players and their coach Emilie Bydwell - the only female rugby sevens coach at the tournament - came to terms with the fact following Sedrick's converted try that they had achieved something which no other US women's rugby sevens team had ever done previously.\n\nMeanwhile at the at the Paris La Defense Arena, swimming success continued for Australia and several prominent European nations.\n\nIn the women's 100m backstroke final, 23-year-old Kaylee McKeown stormed home in the final 25 metres to win gold for Australia, outlasting American duo Regan Smith and Katharine Berkoff and setting a new Olympic record, 57.33 seconds, in the process.\n\nWhile her speed played an integral part, McKeown's lunge for the wall to grab victory was equally significant, given how close her rivals were.\n\nWinning bronze was also clearly a special moment for Berkoff, also 23, given her father David is a four-time Olympic swimming medalist.\n\nTeam Ireland also has a new hero, with Daniel Wiffen claiming gold in the men's 800 metre final.\n\nIn doing so, Wiffen, who has also represented Northern Ireland at the Commonwealth Games, became the first male Irish swimmer to win a medal of any colour at an Olympic Games.\n\nFrom the outset, this final was absorbing.\n\nAustralia's Elijah Winnington set the pace early from lane six - although by the halfway mark, it appeared to be a race of three between Wiffen, Italy's Gregorio Paltrinieri and US talent Bobby Finke.\n\nWith Paltrinieri in his sights at the home turn, Wiffen lifted his intensity in the dying seconds to not only win but also set a new Olympic record of 7min:38sec.19.\n\nMollie O'Callaghan also continued her good form, qualifying for the women's 100m freestyle final on Thursday morning, around 2.30am WST, in lane three alongside compatriot Shayna Jack.\n\nOther Australian swimmers to keep an eye on are Zac Stubblety-Cook and Joshua Yong, who will both participate in the men's 200m breastroke final, which is scheduled around 4.30am.\n\nIn the 4x200m men's freestyle relay final, Australian quartet Flynn Southam, Thomas Neill, Max Giuliani and Elijah Winnington finished with bronze behind Great Britain and the US.\n\nAmerican gymnast Simone Biles also added to her incredible legacy, after securing her eighth medal at an Olympic Games.\n\nBiles acquired her fifth gold medal after playing an integral part in the US claiming victory in the women's team gymnastics final.\n\nOverall Medal tally (Wednesday, 6am WST)\n\nJapan (seven gold, two silver and four bronze) leads the medal table, with China in second.\n\nAustralia is in third - with six gold, four silver and one bronze.\n\nBasketball\n\nAustralia will need to defeat Greece on Friday evening at 7.30pm WST in order to push for a spot in the men's quarter finals, after falling 93-83 to Canada on Tuesday night.\n\nFootball\n\nAll men's pool matches were completed, with the biggest upset in Pool C, with Egypt upsetting Spain 2-1.\n\nThe following quarter final match ups have been confirmed and will be held over Friday night and Saturday morning at various famous football venues across France: Morocco v US, Japan v Spain, Egypt v Paraguay and France v Argentina.\n\nHockey\n\nIt was a tough outing for Australia's men's team, the Kookaburras, who fell 6-2 to tournament favourites Belgium at Yves du Manoir Stadium.\n\nTom Boon scored a hattrick for the victors, who are aiming to defend their Tokyo 2020 title.\n\nThe loss means the Kookaburras sit third in Pool B, with added importance now in terms of their next clash against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\nRugby Sevens\n\nAlthough they withstood an incredible defensive display from Canada in the women's rugby sevens gold medal match, ultimately New Zealand's class once again rose to the surface.\n\nLeading by two points with only a few minutes left and camped in Canadian territory, the 'Black Ferns Sevens' were inspired by co-captain Sarah Hirini, who broke through Canada's defensive rearguard.\n\nThis attack eventually resulted in the pacy Stacey Waaka being fed a teasing pass out wide - with her try ensuring the team could conduct a celebratory post-game haka.\n\nShooting\n\nNathan Hales took out the men's trap shooting final for Great Britain and also set a new Olympic record, hitting 48 shots out of 50.\n\nQi Ying finished with silver for China, while Australia's James Willett came sixth.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8251895012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "06:47:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T06:47:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T06:46:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://www.thesun.ie/sport/13515710/bbc-irish-daniel-wiffen-tweet-800m-gold-medal-olympics/", "title": "BBC enrage Irish fans with Daniel Wiffen tweet after astounding 800m gold medal", "body": "BBC SPORT copped significant flak for a tweet about Daniel Wiffen's victory in the men's 800 metre freestyle final.\n\nThe County Armagh swimmer justified his supreme confidence pre-race by setting a new Olympic record when the lights shone brightest.\n\nBut in the aftermath of his stunning success, a spotlight was also shone on a tweet issued by BBC Sport.\n\nIt read: \"History in Paris! Daniel Wiffen becomes the first athlete from Northern Ireland to win an Olympic gold medal since 1988.\"\n\nWhile factually accurate and certainly not the most offensive example of an Irish person's success being co-opted by Britain the tweet did still provoke plenty of exasperated replies.\n\nThey pointed out that the 23-year-old is very much a member of Team Ireland.\n\nThe irony of him being draped in the tri-colour while shedding tears to Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann was not lost on people either.\n\nOne reply stated: \"And he does it as an Irish athlete and Irish man. Standing under the Irish flag.\n\n\"Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann playing out. The tri-colour being raised.\"\n\nWhile another slagged the British broadcaster by quipping: \"You lads are in for some shock when you hear Amhr\u00e1n na bhFiann in a few minutes (Irish flag emoji).\"\n\nSimilarly, Eoin clarified: \"Ireland, representing Ireland, not NI, not UK. Let it go, it's sad to see.\"\n\nLastly, Alan agreed: \"Irish athlete. First medal for an Irish man to win in the pool (Irish emoji).\"\n\nThe double world champion spoke of his pride of being a member of Team Ireland immediately afterwards.\n\nHe told RTE: \"I mean amazing...I mean, 'What's my name? - Daniel Wiffen, Olympic champion.\n\n\"Sorry, it's really good, I cant believe it.\n\n\"I want to thank everybody else - my twin brother Nathan and my parents, and my whole coaching staff in Loughborough - and the Irish team.\n\n\"I couldn't do it with out anybody. I'm not alone out there. That was such a good effort.\"\n\nIn an epic three-way duel, he held off the challenge of Bobby Finke - 800m and 1,500m champion in Tokyo - and Rio 1,500m gold medalist Gregorio Paltrineri.\n\nBut that should have come as no surprise as anyone who watched his walkout as he mimed scribbling in a book as he signalled what he was going to do.\n\nThe young phenom added: \"I know everybody loves to see my walk-outs.\n\n\"I wrote my name in the history books on my walk-out, and I definitely backed it up with my swim in the pool.\n\n\"What can I say? It's just amazing. I did tell everybody I was going to do it before, so it's just good to see it on paper.\n\n\"I'm just stuck for words because it's such a big achievement for me.\n\n\"I've dreamed of this every day of my life and I know that I seem very confident on the outside, but, you know, there's always a little percentage of you thinking, 'Can I do this?'\"\n\nWiffen will go again in the 1500m freestyle before dipping his toe into the 10km for the first time - once it does take place in the River Seine as he has said he doesn't want to do it outside of Paris.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.ie",
